-FzvcEyNWVwiB_c66Ibz.description: DEEZ NUTS NIGGA. The T-80UK is a command variant of the T-80U, equipped with additional R-163-50K and R-163-U radios, TNA-4 land navigation system, TShU-1-7 Shtora countermeasures system, electronic fuze-setting device that permits use of Ainet shrapnel round, a meteorological sensor, laser warning receivers, Agava-2 thermal sight which provides a 2,600-metre night acquisition range, fire control and Auxiliary power unit. It is used by regimental and battalion Commanding Officers.
-FzvcEyNWVwiB_c66Ibz.name: T-80UK

recognising_features.t80uk_2a9yzy5cvfbuv5iftwau.jpg: The T-80UK remains mostly the same as the T-80U, the most prominent differences are the Shtora system, which is the 2 boxes on the front turret and also the laser warning sensors above the main armament. The addition of a thermal sight replacing the older night sight, this also adds to the removal of the IR searchlight. The addition of the meteorological sensor at the rear of the turret.
recognising_features.t80uk_jqm6y0lsonc9kea2zzvh.jpg: Here you can see the Shtora-1 IRCM boxes on the turret front, they appear smashed. This tank was abandoned and later destroyed during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Shtora ‘eyes’ can be personified for recognition, some say the turret looks like a frog, the boxes being the eyes.
recognising_features.t80uk_ktvm1gyryvesi4z3kf3f.jpg: When the Shtora-1 is switched on, it gives a prominent red glow from each box. Due to these being IR these are easily sighted through standard issue NVG’s or any IR night sight. This is photographed on a T-90A although the same view will be seen for T-80UK as well when switched on.

04BoHDNX7T2GWk_cfhcI.description: The T-72B is a second generation of the upgrade of the T-72 MBT, the upgrades include an upgraded 2A46M MA, an upgraded FCS, upgraded gun stabilisation, also the capability to fire the 9M119 Svir/AT-11 Sniper GLATGM, a thicker and newly designed composite armour on the turret front and hull front, a new powerpack developing more HP. Later production models came from the factory with Kontakt-1 fitted directly to the tank.
04BoHDNX7T2GWk_cfhcI.name: T-72B

recognising_features.t72b_3uz7t46m86gsrfjffn64.jpg: Here you can see the 1K13 sight, it provides a good indicator that its T-72B and not a T-72B1.
recognising_features.t72b_fb7vjng1gm1fle0uoxzj.jpg: The T-72B has much thicker turret armour, as seen here, you will also notice the smoke grenade dischargers have moved positions to the left side of the turret in a cluster of 8, in a row of 3-3-2.
recognising_features.t72b_w1bqval8cmma46rcfwkg.jpg: The T-72B later production models began to leave the factory with Kontakt-1 ERA fitted, across the turret front and hull front. When compared to other tanks the ERA almost looks poorly fitted, almost like they were trying to fit it in any place possible.

0aJ09PX4ySC663U9sYnQ.description: The 9A85 "Gladiator" Launcher Loader Vehicle (LLV) is used in conjunction with the 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR. It can use its crane to reload the TELAR and also engage with its missiles from the TELAR's radar illumination.
0aJ09PX4ySC663U9sYnQ.name: 9A85 LLV

recognising_features.9a85_qm8k1yns3ufwn8sw8ab9.jpg: This angle shows the missile racks for the 4 x 9M83 "Gladiator" surface-to-air missiles and its crane in the raised position. The chassis remains the same as the rest of the S-300V family.
recognising_features.9a85_wkpy9hfd2yzuqtfmx2b9.jpg: The 9A85 LLV has a crane to reload both itself and the 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR.

0arhk2pxYLBwGxcj5uE4.description: The 2F77M, based on the KamAZ-4310B series 6x6 utility vehicle, transports and loads the 9M311 missiles. A 2S6 Tunguska battery typically utilises up to three of these vehicles for support.
0arhk2pxYLBwGxcj5uE4.name: 2F77M Transloader

recognising_features.2f77mtransloader_vl75gc0rmvuphr2q44po.jp: 2F77 using its crane to load a 2K22 Tunguska.
recognising_features.2f77mtransloader_whjb8tmlhae75mf07qu3.jp: The 2F77 Transloader can be easily recognised by the presence of a loading crane at the back of the vehicle, although this feature can be concealed using the typical KaMAZ-4310 series covering. One distinctive characteristic that sets it apart from other KaMAZ logistical vehicles is the pair of racks capable of holding up to 8 x 9M331 variant missiles, which are utilised by the 2S6.

0k-TEOsOIQiTL6XnImuZ.description: The T-64A is a Soviet MBT introduced in the early 60’s, a much more advanced tank than the previous T-62, one that shocked the west, it included a number of revolutionary new features including an autoloader, composite armour, a compact engine and transmission layout, a complex suspension system and a smoothbore gun. The autoloader began the Russian standardisation of a 3 man crew, this meant designers could do away with a large profile and heavy weight, whilst still retaining the heavy armour and weapon.
0k-TEOsOIQiTL6XnImuZ.name: T-64A

recognising_features.t64a_48c4x0jxueyzfy5ky3jw.jpg: Turret, the T-64A moves away from the classic frying pan shape due to the use of composite armour, you can see it has much thicker cheek armour. It has an IR searchlight to the left of the gun, directly above the IR searchlight is the TPD-43 gunners primary sight, with the NV sight behind that. The CMDR sits on the right, with the GNR on the left. The snorkel is stowed at rear of the turret laterally. Sometimes they are fitted with stowage bins as seen on this photo.
recognising_features.t64a_52c3lieekclxssk3q8nc.jpg: Hull, The hull has a heavy sloping front glacis, with a prominent V shape splash plate for the driver, the driver has a single vision periscope, there are 3 prominent lines running down the mud guards. The suspension is of a distinctive design, it has 6 small ‘pork pie’ roadwheels, equally spaced throughout with 4 top rollers (visible when the side skirts are removed).
recognising_features.t64a_tl6lmxkerrsl6vnu1sfe.jpg: The rear view of the T-64A, the exhaust is fitted at the rear, given the tank is commonly confused with the T-72 it is a key feature to note that the thermal signature is at the rear from the exhaust, not the side like the T-72.

0wAmOu2-GDBlM3OW40w3.description: The FV4333 Stormer HVM is a British Short Range Air Defence (SHORAD) system. It is a modified version of the CRVT, Stormer is longer than the original and designed for support tasks. The missile has low detection due to its passive method of target acquisition, although fairly short ranged, this gives it much more survivability on the battlefield. It is capable of firing High Velocity Missiles and Marlet guided missiles.
0wAmOu2-GDBlM3OW40w3.name: Stormer HVM

recognising_features.stormerhvm_6gsz5hbmszsttwx56i85.jpg: The drivers hatch is on the left and the front plate has 4 easily recognisable stowage bins for servicing equipment.
recognising_features.stormerhvm_aa9vxdqtyttpt20uvrcl.jpg: The system uses the Air Defence Alerting Device (ADAD) to acquire targets, the circular object seen on top of the missile launch assembly. It also has a thermal sighting assembly mounted on the front right part of the roof, it is rectangular with the bottom left corner cut out.
recognising_features.stormerhvm_miua0pzkcjrb75aajkx4.jpg: The key identifying feature of the HVM stormer is the missile launcher assembly, it contains 8 pods, in banks of 4. At the rear of the vehicle there is a single door, flanked by a stowage bin on the left and space for a spare roadwheel on the right.
recognising_features.stormerhvm_zyyrkl454dd0s11z6w1j.jpg: The Stormer platform is a longer version of the British CRVT hull. It has 6 road-wheels in a tight configuration with the drive sprocket at the front. The hull is sloped at the front 1/3rd of the vehicle.

0yqGD4RucBAq-Yi8NKEo.description: The 2S1 Gvozdika is a fully amphibious Soviet self-propelled howitzer. It is armed with a 122mm 2A18 howitzer, the same as D-30, and has a range of up to 21.9km. The 2S1's modified MTLBu hull is fully NBC proof. The 2S1 has been replaced in Russian Land Forces by the 2S19 Msta.
0yqGD4RucBAq-Yi8NKEo.name: 2S1 Gvozdika

recognising_features.2s1gvozdika_3vae3ppwr7hv7dg4zntx.jpg: The 2A18 is a relatively short barrelled Artillery system and a key recognising feature is that the barrel does not extend forward of the MTLBu chassis.
recognising_features.2s1gvozdika_5qdz6c64vm5ys3upiex4.jpg: The turret of the 2S1 is a distinctive U-shape. The front is rounded and the rear is straight. The rear of the turret has two rollers with distinctive protective grates above.

1k9SMUMR5xCFqjc52TpC.description: The M-84A is a Yugoslav MBT, based on the T-72M and appearing visually similar, though it possesses many improvement over the T-72M. The M-84A has a fire control system, 1000hp engine, improved composite armour, amongst other upgrades. Interestingly all of the parts were produced indigenously in Yugoslavia, leaving no reliance on imported parts. The M-84A forms the backbone of the Serbian mechanised brigades.
1k9SMUMR5xCFqjc52TpC.name: M-84A

recognising_features.m84a_mmt5i2lyrq7ndlf46npb.jpg: The M-84A looks very similar to a T-72A or a T-72M, but the main defining features are on the turret. There is a cylinder behind the gun, which is the meteorological sensor for the fire control computer, the large DNNS-2 gunners day/night sight in front of the gunners hatch and the lack of an IR searchlight. The gunners sight is different to that of a T-72 due to it being larger, but also the fact it doesn't have the typical T-72 'doghouse' TPD-K1 sight. I recommend you use the compare feature between this and the T-72A to understand the differences between the two.

2WM0crMwLe8qycFIBp36.description: The Pantsir missile system, NATO reporting name SA-22 'Greyhound' is an upgrade to the Tunguska. It is a short range SAM designed to protect ground forces from attack by low flying aircraft, helicopters and cruise missiles. Like the 2K22 it is armed with both missiles and 30mm cannons, however the fire control systems are vastly improved, allowing it to track up to 20 targets and engage 3 simultaneously.
2WM0crMwLe8qycFIBp36.name: Pantsir S1

recognising_features.pantsirs1_gsg773hdh0hbi30osy5u.jpg: The Pantsir is mounted on the KAMAZ-6560 8x8 truck chassis.
recognising_features.pantsirs1_tk97gdf4iimi82qa7ydt.jpg: The weapon consists of 2 x  6 pod missile launchers which can move independantly in banks of three. The 30 mm cannons flank the rectangular radar at the rear of the turret. There is a circular tracking radar at the front of the system.

2f2T5OqxdA3p0fd-ps0j.description: The BTR-MDM is a replacement for aging BTR-D, albeit slowly. It is made to be the main troop transport for the VDV, with the BMD’s providing fire support, it is based on the older BTR-MD, in line with VDV vehicles it is air transportable.
2f2T5OqxdA3p0fd-ps0j.name: BTR-MDM

recognising_features.btrmdm_5tsk4ryw4dfvpiia76qc.jpg: The BTR-MDM has the same hull from the BMD-4M, this time the turret is removed and the superstructure is raised to accommodate more dismounts. The driver's position remains essentially the same, this time the hatch to the left of him is now a full cupola for the commander. The exhaust is on the same place as the BMD-4, in the form of a rectangular slit. There is also a ball mount for the PKTon the right upper frontal hull.
recognising_features.btrmdm_ax7ycb28q0iobkljfgwv.jpg: The superstructure slopes downwards to the rear hull, where it flattens out towards the end; there is a prominent gap in the rear centre.
recognising_features.btrmdm_m69f6bj484rme1ffstvq.jpg: The hull is boat shaped to keep the amphib features, the upper glacis plate is heavily sloped, it has 2 banks of 2 SGD’s with 2 headlights either side. The sides are flat and are not sloped.

2iKSYLZy2qLyw87FPKbG.description: The 9A83 "Gladiator" Transporter Erector Launcher and Radar (TELAR) is the launcher for the 9M83 "Gladiator" surface-to-air missiles. It can illuminate and guide its own rockets or take targeting data from the 9S32 "Grill Pan" radar, it also provides guidance for the "Gladiator" missiles from the 9A85 LLV.
2iKSYLZy2qLyw87FPKbG.name: 9A83 TELAR

recognising_features.9a83_dm837wtp3v0aw7qmas5z.jpg: The 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR has 4 missiles, compared to the 2 carried by the 9A82 "Giant".
recognising_features.9a83_zmxrojdv6dxqqdv0dplf.jpg: A close up of the 9A83's illumination and guidance radar. The presence of this radar determines whether the vehicle is a 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR or a 9A85 "Gladiator" LLV.

2ulW1nTJKGIKhPDLapWJ.description: The Ka-52 'Alligator' is a Russian attack helicopter. It is an upgraded system to the earlier Soviet Ka-50 'Black Shark'. It is a twin-seater aircraft, with the primary role of battlefield recconanissance. It is armed with a 30mm cannon and 6 hardpoints which enable a variety of rockets and air to ground missiles to be fitted. It was the first helicopter to have a pilot ejection system. The Egyptian export model is known as the Ka-52 'Nile Crocodile'.
2ulW1nTJKGIKhPDLapWJ.name: Ka-52

recognising_features.ka52_c9qfu1zf0abnywdgus7g.jpg: The air intakes have black covers to protect the engines from flying debris or bird strike. The winglets sit directly beneath the intakes and each has 3 hard points for attaching a variety of different weapons, sensors or external fuel tanks.
recognising_features.ka52_e3z9e7rk09ibb4klmsam.jpg: The Ka-52 is a very distinctive helicopter, since it has twin rotor blades. The nose of the aircraft has a lighter coloured domed cover, with a round camera pod beneath.
recognising_features.ka52_ea193k4k3l9cpey7nmbk.jpg: The Ka-52 has a single rudder with no tail rotor. Two forward angled stabilisers sit on the tail boom.

3ACH0a24vIi8vUXT-BwD.description: The BM-30 Smerch is a heavy multiple launch rocket system (MLRS) mounted on the MAZ-543M or MAZ-79111 chassis. It has a maximum range of 90km and can fire its 12 rockets in 20 seconds. It is the heaviest tactical artillery rocket launcher beneath the ballistic missile launchers.
3ACH0a24vIi8vUXT-BwD.name: BM-30 Smerch

recognising_features.bm30smerch_bymmu65q5ptmdyfvj6v7.jpg: The BM-30 chassis is an 8 wheeled heavy truck, with 12 rocket tubes mounted on the rear. The drivers cab is on the left of the vehicle, with a flat cut-out on the right housing the engine. There is a windowed control unit behind the cab.
recognising_features.bm30smerch_ccptyai8oo721lnt6u6h.jpg: BM-30 moments before it was destroyed by a TB-2 in the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict in 2021.

3F5jGGJi-fONivcCQfm5.description: The 2K22 Tunguska, NATO reporting name SA-19 'Grison', is a short ranged surface to air system. It has a self contained tracking and fire control radar and is armed with 8 x  9M311 missiles and 2 x 30mm 2A38M cannons. It is designed to engage low level aircraft, helicopters and cruise missiles. The system is mounted on the GM-5975 chassis and is also designed as the 2S6 artillery system on the GRAU index. There is an upgraded system that uses the Pantsir's 57E6 missile.
3F5jGGJi-fONivcCQfm5.name: 2K22 Tunguska

recognising_features.2k22tunguska_rtnuf0vgcf6uo2wsq6gi.jpg: The Tunguska's turret is unique. The 30mm cannons are large and flank the commanders hatch. The  missile launchers sit below the cannons, and are rectangular with each holding 4 missiles. There is a circular tracking radar on the front of the turret.
recognising_features.2k22tunguska_z961v591cqpc5fgvgri7.jpg: The 2K22 is mounted on GM-5975 chassis which has 6 evenly spaced road wheels with gaps between each wheel and the final drive at the rear. The driver's hatch is on the left, above a steep splash plate. The sides of the chassis are straight, with a box-shaped rear end.

3ODMHTzj0izWrNBAsx9_.description: The 9K55 Grad-1, or NATO's M1976, is a Soviet Cold War multiple rocket launcher. A lighter version of the BM-21 Grad, it was designed for Soviet naval infantry, utilising the 9M28 artillery rockets. Built on the ZiL-131 6x6 tactical trucks, its distinct feature is a 36-tube launcher, in contrast to BM-21's 40 tubes. These 122mm rockets have a range of 15 km. Although fast-moving at 80 km/h, its soft skin design offers minimal protection. Introduced in 1976, around 500 units were produced, primarily for Soviet naval infantry. Its post-Soviet service is largely in Russia, with some in ex-Soviet states.
3ODMHTzj0izWrNBAsx9_.name: 9P138 Grad-1

recognising_features.9p138grad1_70borztm0j641zf9bq3q.jpg: The 9K55 weapon system on the Grad-1 is mounted on the ZiL-131 truck chassis. This can be identified from the BM-21 by the thinner vertical line separating the two windshields and the horizontal sections on the base of the grill. There is also a cutout in the rocket pods at the bottom centre, meaning the Grad-1 has 4 less rockets than the BM-21.

3ZQgp8WnrkQjZzje6awJ.description: The Murmansk-BN is a Russian strategic level EW complex, designed to disrupt communications in the high frequency (HF) radio band (3 MHz to 30 MHz). It is optimised to target the U.S. HF Global Communications System (HFGCS). It is designed to interfere with tactical, operational and strategic communications. Each Murmansk-BN antenna group consists of four 105 ft (32 m) telescopic masts that are interlinked to create a single, large array. The arrays are controlled by Kamaz trucks, it takes several days to set up, once set up the Murmansk-BN has a range of upto 5000km, in theory it could essentially ‘cover’ the whole of europe. It has been deployed in Kaliningrad, near the Finnish border and also the Crimea.
3ZQgp8WnrkQjZzje6awJ.name: Murmansk-BN

recognising_features.murmanskbn_07wlebpr5qjzd5nnw3s9.jpg: The Murmansk-BN’s working configuration is a semi circle, it is easy to spot on satellite photos when running with it being such a large array.
recognising_features.murmanskbn_dr61srq6wgi3lgm3wsln.jpg: Once fully set up, the masts are tall but recognisable due to the telescopic design, getting skinnier as it gets to the top. Between each of the 4 masts is a cable antennae, giving a large web-like appearance.
recognising_features.murmanskbn_e9e50opyj3v1ja4lsdyl.jpg: The Murmansk-BN is mounted on Kamaz-6350 8x8 Trucks, the trucks are adapted for use with the system, they have stabilising arms on each side to hold the vehicle in place. The mast has a spool towards the bottom.
recognising_features.murmanskbn_lvaaur8o2vvxqsg28rt3.jpg: Here you can see a battery of Murmansk-BN’s set up on a satellite image, this particular one was photographed in Sevastopol, the Crimea.
recognising_features.murmanskbn_q4bn92qpdy9mgcwz7zus.jpg: Inside the command post of the Murmansk-BN.
recognising_features.murmanskbn_txw2etjts1fw1z6uw2sr.jpg: Ground level photograph of a Murmansk-BN battery, this can give the appearance of 4 cranes from a distance, remembering the telescopic masts is a key feature.

3y2Z_8abFmgkMtcDZQXw.description: The SNAR-10 is a ground surveillance radar variant of the MTLB with a 1RL127 radar, NATO designation 'Big Fred'
3y2Z_8abFmgkMtcDZQXw.name: SNAR-10

recognising_features.snar10_81wyujnwtmiww5eyov60.jpg: Here is the SNAR-10 with the radar raised.
recognising_features.snar10_cplnf3jfkm81w4kfcznx.jpg: The SNAR-10 is a 1RL127 radar mounted on a fully traversable turret on an MTLB APC, it is hugely recognisable by the huge turret with the radar fitted on the top. It is commonly found with reconnaissance and artillery reconnaissance units.
recognising_features.snar10_om2ovwunlf8vovhl5gxw.jpg: Here is a crude attempt at disguising the SNAR-10 as some kind of tank or IFV.

47qJxbH73aj0LvVSgkWo.description: The Belorussian T-72BME is a heavy upgrade of the T-72A, it is being trialled for both the Belorussian armed forces, Kazakhstan have also shown interest in the programme. The upgrades include the ESSA-72U fire control system, a thermal sight, which looks very similar to the Russian Sosna-U sight, a meteorological sensor which also looks very much like the Russian DVE-BS crosswind sensor, an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU), Kontakt-1 ERA, bar armour at the rear, improved turret stowage with a bustle rack and a new VHF radio system. It still retains the older V-84MS engine, not choosing the much more powerful V-92 engine series seems to be a common theme of Belorussian T-Series upgrades.
47qJxbH73aj0LvVSgkWo.name: T-72BME

recognising_features.t72bme_hd90efmk1kjqyb42upd4.jpg: The T-72BME has the outward appearance of a T-72AV, the big giveaways are the lack of IR searchlight, thermal sight and the crosswind sensor mounted on top of the turret, the SGD bank is on the left side of the turret and appears to be placed further forward and further out than on most other T-Series tanks, on the hull there is bar armour covering the rear quarter as well as 2 rubber flaps on the lower glacis plate, there are also LED lights for the driver now, with one light on either side of the glacis plate.
recognising_features.t72bme_l3lnmu6q5pmgz7h0x67k.jpg: The rear of the turret is completely different to a normal T-72, with the new bustle rack covered with ERA it can look from the side like a ZTZ-99A, it will make the turret appear longer and less like a T-Series tank, but remembering the Kontakt-1 blocks and the clamshell Kontakt-1 design on the turret front is the way to positively identify this model. It is also worth noting that the turret retains the standard T-72 side bins.
recognising_features.t72bme_z604osx6cm0fb811s50e.jpg: At the rear left of the vehicle is a box, it seems to be a part of the APU addition of the upgrade package, this box isnt visible on any other T-Series tank.

4gmAYBl3wInNPHalpXxh.description: The KamAZ-63968 Typhoon-K is a Russian 6x6 mine resistant ambush protected infantry mobility vehicle, the vehicle is part of the Russian Typhoon programme, the main goal of the program is to design a unified platform for all Russian armored wheeled vehicles. The KamAZ-63968 Typhoon-K itself is well protected with composites up to 14.5mm. The Combat Information and Control System (CICS) GALS-D1M to monitor and control the operation of the engine, calculating machines roll, tilt, road speed, location, etc. The independent hydropneumatic suspension allows the driver to change the ride height on the road, using remote control within 400 mm. KAMAZ-63968 is equipped with five cameras for review the troop unit and cockpit. The vehicle can be fitted with an RWS, typically with a PKT.
4gmAYBl3wInNPHalpXxh.name: KamAZ Typhoon-K

recognising_features.kamaztyphoonk_62bt6up67eri5rozp3r7.jpg: Seen here is the vehicle with the RWS fitted.
recognising_features.kamaztyphoonk_bzxvjvowgmgaco8tv6bf.jpg: Seen here are the roof hatches for the dismounts, they also have a ramp for exiting the rear, which provides a much quicker means of dismounting.
recognising_features.kamaztyphoonk_ltflnlcu3r0m022ai735.jpg: Recognising the Kamaz-63968 is pretty simple, starting with the chassis the 6x6 format is different to most trucks, with 2 roadwheels at the front with an upside down triangular stowage bin separating them, then there is a large gap between the 2nd and last roadwheel. On the side of the vehicle are 2x vision blocks and a ladder, in front of the ladder is a grille. Moving to the cab there are footsteps for the crew, with armoured doors and small windows on the sides, the front windows are large and have a small line separating the two, the front of the cab is smooth with no grilles and has 3 lines which meet in the centre. The headlight clusters are low down on the cab.

4gvm9l3-Nucss3nFcVnz.description: The Vityaz DT-10P(amphibious variant) is a Russian articulated all-terrain vehicle, designed for usage in remote and extreme conditions, commonly found in the Russian Far East, Far North and the Arctic Regions. They can also be used as recovery vehicles due to the high pull ratio, they also have a very low ground pressure, which is useful for preventing the detonation of mines. The vehicles are used by Russian Army units in extreme climates, as well as civilian companies who use them for logging in the Far East and also scientific companies who conduct scientific research in extreme climates like the Arctic as well as remote and isolated regions like the Northern Islands of Russia. Some vehicles were used in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mostly by the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade. This and the DT-30 series are commonly confused, it is key to remember that the DT-30 is larger and longer than the DT-10. More than a hundred Vityaz vehicles are used in Russia for the transportation of cargo, such as: blocks, cranes and even towers for power lines in hard to reach regions. They serve rescue teams in extreme conditions. When a natural disaster occurs, there are no roads, the Vityaz all-terrain vehicle is a great help.
4gvm9l3-Nucss3nFcVnz.name: DT-10P

recognising_features.dt10p_cuqy86mix8qsq2v8sudy.jpg: In typical fashion with the Vityaz DT series, the P version has a different front end. It has 4 windows instead of 3, has larger side doors, exhausts are large ovals on the upper side(they're covered in this image by fabric). There are also 3 headlights on the roof and the frontal cab is more flat at the front, with less sloping.

about.operators: Bahrain,Benin,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Botswana,Brazil,Ireland,Kenya,Malawi,Morocco,Nepal,New Zealand,Oman,Portugal,Spain,Thailand,Turkey,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,United States of America

4h6ImpXf7dzfNrsBrD95.description: The L118 light gun is a 105mm towed howitzer built by Royal Ordnance, now BAE systems. The British weapon system was brought out to replace the older pack howitzers and rival the 122mm D-30. Despite being a small calibre, it out performs the Soviet D-30 in every aspect and has been exported worldwide. It's small size allows the L118 to be air lifted via helicopter and towed by light wheel vehicles, it is for this reason it is favoured by the airborne and commando units of the British Army & Royal Marines.
4h6ImpXf7dzfNrsBrD95.name: L118

recognising_features.l118_2xifpjhjfjazlh0pfbdc.jpg: The L31 barrel has no fume extractor. Earlier variants have a single baffle muzzle break, however most have double baffles. A key recognising feature of the L118 is the horizontal cylindrical tank that sits above the breech assembly. It is part of the recoil system and tapers on each side, a bit like a divers oxygen tank.
recognising_features.l118_ja13ckhaid4bt97asqdk.jpg: The M118 is the American variant, used by thier airborne forces. Note the shorter barrel and single baffle muzzle break.
recognising_features.l118_raos04cb9gi4mh7qepm4.jpg: To bring the gun in or out of action, a wheel must be removed to rotate the barrel. A well trained crew can bring the gun into or out of action in less than 50 seconds.
recognising_features.l118_rrbnv8xbi0b3yjm1o8nd.jpg: When the gun is being towed a long distance, it is rotated 180 degrees. It is still identifiable by the recoil system and cylindrical trials.
recognising_features.l118_tpufpwv0zmywfyv0bi5s.jpg: The gun has two wheels that sit each side of the cradle, that connects the ordnance (barrel & breech) to the trials. The trials are cylindrical and form a tear drop shape, at the thinnest part of the tear sits the towing eye.
recognising_features.l118_y2wgszymiramvpyw8hnz.jpg: The L31 has a sliding breech block, seen here in the open position. More of the recoil system can be seen here. The two tubes that flank each side of the barrel, in this photo they have red bolts - although this varies by unit.

5Nf0fXLFpu3K73VRd77F.description: The 9S457-1 is the command post vehicle for the S-300V missile system. It works by coordinating the detection tracks given by the 2S15 and 2S19 radars and distributing them to the S-300V TELARs for engagement. It is mounted on the Object 834 chassis, which is the same base vehicle as the 2S9 Pion.
5Nf0fXLFpu3K73VRd77F.name: 9S457-1

recognising_features.9s4571_d4hirjnuqtdx04xq0s32.jpg: The command post is mounted on the same modified 2S7 Pion chassis, named 'Object 834'. The key and obvious recognising feature for the 9S457-1 is the lack of any radar, missiles or associated equipment. The mast is large with an star shaped antenna.

5XAFKjvss9-UCK8TzZ94.description:
The BMM-80 is a BTR-80 based medical vehicle, there are three platforms that comprise one unit, these consist of the following:
BMM-1 Battlefield ambulance for first aid & MEDEVAC ops to either the BMM-2 or BMM-3.
BMM-2 operates as the battalion mobile medical station.
BMM-3 operates as the brigade mobile medical station.
The vehicles are only differentiated by the internal equipment. The equipment and medicine set ensures the delivery of first aid at stationary position and on the move. The vehicle has a folding tent to be attached to the vehicle at any side door. Up to 12 casualties can be accommodated in the tent.
5XAFKjvss9-UCK8TzZ94.name: BMM-80

recognising_features.bmm80_jy3i807v6thf0srw6tiv.jpg: The BMM-80 is based on the BTR-80 UNSh (Unified Chassis), which is a BTR-80 with a much larger and taller superstructure. The front of the hull is the same as the BTR-80, on the upper frontal hull there are 2 extra windows with armoured shutters, above it is a turret. The hull sides, are widened and consist of two triangular foot steps in between the front 2 roadwheels, there is also a large door behind the 2nd roadwheel. It is common to see stretches and/or tents mounted on top of the vehicle.

5bhjyVKXcAhwSOe7tn3q.description: The T-72AV is a T-72A with Kontakt-1 ERA fitted, this enhances the tanks resistance to chemical energy munitions over the standard T-72A. It entered service in 1985.
5bhjyVKXcAhwSOe7tn3q.name: T-72AV

recognising_features.t72av_fzi66bpnr8hjotrgrjl9.jpg: The hull ERA is similar to other T-Series tanks with it being fitted across the front glacis with gaps for headlights and towing eyes.
recognising_features.t72av_j7e0rr0tjuswivjtkxjn.jpg: This is a T-64BV, which the T-72AV is easily confused with. You can see the difference in ERA layout across the turret, remember that T-64BV has a double brick clamshell, T-72AV has a single brick clamshell mount.
recognising_features.t72av_klkxior2mfgwrq1euh4t.jpg: The T-72AV shares most of its recognising features with the T-72A, apart from the Kontakt-1 fitted, this gives it a distinctive appearance. The bricks are fitted in a single brick clamshell design, this is key feature to help with recognising it against other T-Series tanks with Kontakt-1.

5e7ogAu7SUFKbWX4F4di.description: The 9K317M Buk-M3, NATO designation SA-27 'Gollum', is an upgraded system to the Buk M2. It uses the improved 9M317M missile, which is an upgrade of the 9M38. The system uses the same 9S36 integral radar, although it has had huge software upgrades. It increases the engagement range of the system to 70km.
5e7ogAu7SUFKbWX4F4di.name: 9K317M Buk-M3

recognising_features.9k317mbukm3_9ip5h0vxwdqra2bplmib.jpg: The Buk-M3 TEL is distinctive in the fact that it holds two banks of 6 missiles, again in the cylindrical tubes.
recognising_features.9k317mbukm3_qnlfjpf0ph31i5c413cz.jpg: The key recognising feature of the Buk M3 are the newer 9M317M missiles, they are no longer in the open but instead are deployed in 6 cylindrical tubes.
recognising_features.9k317mbukm3_zywp1z1uedbnnhwqyc77.jpg: There is an additional, smaller, rectangular radar above the 9S36 - this is unique to the M3.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Albania,Algeria,Angola,Argentina,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Bhutan,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Bulgaria,Burkina Faso,Cambodia,China,Colombia,Republic of the Congo,Republic of the Congo,Croatia,Cuba,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Germany,Guinea,Guinea-Bissau,Hungary,India,Iran,Iraq,Kazakhstan,Kyrgyzstan,Latvia,Laos,Libya,Lithuania,Maldives,Mexico,Mali,Moldova,Mongolia,Mozambique,Nepal,North Korea,Pakistan,Peru,Poland,Romania,Russia,Serbia,Slovakia,Somalia,Sudan,Syria,Turkey,Turkmenistan,Tajikistan,Ukraine,United States of America,Uzbekistan,Venezuela,Vietnam

5hNnygTN7M5YN47i9il8.description: The Mil Mi-8, NATO reporting name 'Hip', is Soviet era multi-role helicopter. It is the most widely exported and used military helicopter worldwide. It has multiple variants but the base Mi-8 'Hip-B' is used primarily for troop transport and aerial C2.
5hNnygTN7M5YN47i9il8.name: Mi-8

recognising_features.mi8_508eugat6exucd25b6ce.jpg: The Hip has a rounded fuselage with twin air intakes above the cockpit. There is a third intake directly beneath the rotor mast. Large, circular exhaust ports sit beneath the rotor mast, on the upper portion of the fuselage. There are 5 circular port windows in the passenger compartment.
recognising_features.mi8_8cjtriqsngnykgltxfta.jpg: The tail boom is straight, and extends from the top of the fuselage. There is a single stabiliser on the connection from boom to rudder, with the tail rotor being on the starboard (right) side.
recognising_features.mi8_p58eko54o3hab4ackd9z.jpg: The Mi-8 cannot retract its landing gear. There are two single wheels at the rear of the fuselage and a single double wheel beneath the cockpit. There is a cylindrical muffler running along the base of the fuselage on each side.

6Ce0fNzZVaL3cu_JqmiX.description: The T-72B Obr.1989 is an upgrade of the T-72B, the most prominent feature being the armour upgrade, consisting of a Kontakt-5 ERA package.
6Ce0fNzZVaL3cu_JqmiX.name: T-72B Obr.1989

recognising_features.t72bobr.1989_jhzf9onr4yjrp8m08do7.jpg: The T-72B Obr.1989 is a T-72B with Kontakt-5. It is recognisable by this, remember the T-72B has Kontakt-1 bricks all over the tank. This now has the Kontakt-5 blocks across the turret front, they are distinguishable by the sideways ‘V’ shape. There are 4 of these mounts on the right side of the gun and 4 on the left.
recognising_features.t72bobr.1989_weq7hej6h267np6k6z9x.jpg: A noticeable feature is also the gaps between the ERA and the main gun, leaving a portion of the turret cheeks exposed. On the right side of the gun is an IR searchlight, this is a good feature to ID against the T-72B3, which does not have an IR searchlight, instead having 5 ERA blocks on the right side. The T-72B Obr 1989 is distinguishable from the T-72BA by the lack of the DWE-BS meteorological sensor.

6Pkmck4c-m49K3D43tru.description: The IMR-2 is a Soviet/Russian engineering vehicle, its main purpose is to clear obstacles and dig trenches, it is based on the T-72 hull. The IMR-2 saw heavy use in the 1986 Chernobyl Disaster, most of the vehicles that were used are currently buried due to the heavy amount of radiation they absorbed.
6Pkmck4c-m49K3D43tru.name: IMR-2

recognising_features.imr2_1orz5o3a7dl6hzjtmora.jpg: The IMR-2 is easily remembered by the pneumonic ‘I Move Rocks’. In the centre is a tall cupola for the commander with vision blocks giving 360 degrees FoV. Directly mounted on the rear of his cupola is a large crane arm, when stowed it runs parallel to the vehicle, the claw attachment hangs off the rear or can be folded. Down the side there are 3 stowage boxes for tools and equipment.
recognising_features.imr2_nfmfy1uznmii7gbzu27m.jpg: The front blade is typically raised when not in use, as seen here. Note that the IMR-2 is rarely seen with side skirts, they are barely ever fitted.

6bY9frHfGT1fpoKOErl5.description: The BTR-4 is a Ukrainian self produced IFV, it represents a change in production from KMDB and looks more western, comparable to the Tpz Fuchs German APC, it can have an array of weapon modules fitted.
6bY9frHfGT1fpoKOErl5.name: BTR-4

recognising_features.btr4_8odc4mgwvh8ialh7bio4.jpg: This BTR-4 has the GROM turret system.
recognising_features.btr4_mb2titotvsr00ilt1v7j.jpg: The BTR-4 can be fitted with different turrets, this one has the Shkval module. The turret is similar to the BTR-3U. It has the ZTM-1 30mm cannon with the prominent rails around the gun. The 3 SGD’s are on either side of the gun. The Shkval module is usually fitted with bar armour as seen here.
recognising_features.btr4_nn0q7jw84ucmayw3sz6u.jpg: The hull of the BTR-4 is unlike standard BTR’s, the frontal hull has large windows with covers that can be opened and closed, the lower boat shaped hull is still reminiscent of the BTR-80. Moving to the side the driver and commander have doors now rather than hatches, there is an air intake on the front right side and the side doors have been omitted and replaced by rear doors.
recognising_features.btr4_rm5a36o29paxborqq681.jpg: The exhaust is on the left side, the cylinder you see in the centre. The roadwheels are equally spaced at the front, broken up between the 2nd and 3rd with a triangle box, the 3rd and 4th are also broken up with a box, there are 2 propellers at the rear on either side behind the last roadwheel.

7GunFaXfRWTE7Ij_6ifH.description: The T-80UM2 is a prototype from the 1990’s, it was a T-80U with a Drozd APS complex fitted, it is unknown how many were produced but one example was destroyed in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, it may be the only copy. Although a prototype, it was evidently in service with the Russian Army, more specifically the 4th Guards Tank Division.
7GunFaXfRWTE7Ij_6ifH.name: T-80UM2

recognising_features.t80um2_6xz5983akzi955s23zho.jpg: Above the slug launchers the rectangle is the doppler radar, the large square box behind the launchers is the equipment control box for the radar.
recognising_features.t80um2_cg489r9trwz26kppdjmy.jpg: The T-80UM2 is exactly the same as the standard T-80U, the main difference is the Drozd APS which look like ‘ears’ fitted to the side of the turret, there are 2 mounts for the slug launchers with 4 holes on either side of the turret.
recognising_features.t80um2_f8va5rf5gmiv9i59r0x3.jpg: Here is what could have been the same T-80UM2 on its way to an exercise in Belarus, pre-war.
recognising_features.t80um2_q7qj8ntbzhumb4ci30gz.jpg: The photo confirming the destruction of the T-80UM2 in Ukraine.

7j_B2Q5m_NWyHTy6MTig.description: The 2S7 Pion (later upgrade variant known as the 2S7M Malka) is a 203 calibre self-propelled howizter. It has an impressive range of 37km for standard ammunition and up to 50km with rocket assisted projecties. The firing range is so far that the howitzer can re position after firing the first round and be well out of counter battery range by the time the rounds impact. The 2S7 is supported by
7j_B2Q5m_NWyHTy6MTig.name: 2S7 Pion

recognising_features.2s7pion_dckms0g8bfequz0r98ud.jpg: The rear of the 2S7 has a cage, presumably to keep operators safe whist travelling on top of the vehice.
recognising_features.2s7pion_ila7ffe4m292x8mbq6yk.jpg: The 2S7 Pion/Malka is mounted on an extended T-80 chassis with 7 evenly placed roadwheels. The final drive is on the front. The 2A44 gun is longer than the chassis and extends over the front when in the lowered position.
recognising_features.2s7pion_nicr7w14af6qll5sh6ec.jpg: The rear of the 2S7 has a large spade which can be lowered into the ground to stablise the gun whilst firing.
recognising_features.2s7pion_sal9gzi9m99jlxwih4il.jpg: The 2A44 gun is easily distinguishable by the fact it is the longest in service artillery barrel on a SPG. It has no fume extractor or muzzle break. The barrel clamp secures it to the T-80 chassis approximately half way along the barrel.

8PRSCZR0qrYrxfH4Cmln.description: The T-72B3 is the workhorse of the Russian Ground Forces, equipping most of the armoured brigades, it is an extensive overhaul of the tank, it has an upgraded gun, new Kalina FCS, Sosna-U TI sight, new engine, new sighting systems, new twin pin tracks to name a few new features. These upgrades bring it close to the T-90A in terms of firepower and protection.
8PRSCZR0qrYrxfH4Cmln.name: T-72B3

recognising_features.t72b3_dzcf86fdamnoy71yw3ro.jpg: The T-72B3 is extensively modified, as you will see here. It has new tracks and a new layout of Kontakt-5. You may see photos of T-72B3’s with long side skirts and cage armour, those variants are T-72B3 Obr.2016’s to save confusion.
recognising_features.t72b3_n5rjedgdi5q3i0qo8r7v.jpg: You will see the new upgrades to the turret, the new Kontakt-5 ERA, the lack of IR searchlight indicating a TI capability, also the new Sosna-U sight on the left side of the turret, the ERA has gaps in between the bricks, unlike T-90A which fit snugly together.
recognising_features.t72b3_tlyn49qem92ozsej5xh2.jpg: This is a T-72B3 through a thermal sight (turret is traversed rearwards).
recognising_features.t72b3_yk70gfcotwvhb07endlz.jpg: With this photo from bellingcat, it highlights the Sosna-U sight and the meteorological sensor, these are good features to help you recognise it against a separate model.

8Z4F3krp0WoVqEfJr2Pt.description: The ZTZ-96 stems from the PLA's urgent need to modernise it's tank fleet, with Gulf War One (1991) showing that the ZTZ-88 was obsolete, along with the T-80U appearing in the USSR at the time, the PLA desperately needed a new tank to keep up with modern warfare. Continued delays in China's third generation MBT development meant the PLA had no choice but to continue development of the ZTZ-85 family, leading to it becoming the ZTZ-96. The design was aided when China obtained a T-72 from Romania. The ZTZ-96 was the first Chinese tank to be fitted with a 125mm main armament, it also boasted modern features like composite armour and a welded turret. Today, along with it's upgraded variants (ZTZ-96A/B) forms the backbone of the PLA's combined arms battalions in the heavy combined arms brigades. Despite all the upgrades, the tank is still relatively underpowered when compared to NATO and Soviet tanks from the same era.
8Z4F3krp0WoVqEfJr2Pt.name: ZTZ-96

recognising_features.ztz96_4z5jiwkahbl7apmdhskz.jpg: The side of the tank is relatively low profile with the running gear taking up the majority of the side profile, there are 6 roadwheels with a prominent gap in between the 2nd and 3rd roadwheels, the final drive is at the rear.
recognising_features.ztz96_af87pdq1kt26txncvwkw.jpg: The turret side has a stowage rack towards the rear, the tanks exhausts are two small holes at the rear side, as seen here, this is where you will get a prominent thermal signature.
recognising_features.ztz96_mo8fpoqwsxi3p055fi5t.jpg: The ZTZ-96 steps away from the previous iterations of PLA tanks which generally look like T-55's, this tank instantly strikes as being more modern and advanced than it's predecessors. The turret front is flat with a slight angling, the frontal sides are angled towards the front of the turret, with smoke grenade banks fitted on either side of the turret with 6 smoke grenades in each bank. The gunners sight is on the right side as you look at it, with the commanders cupola on the left. The frontal hull is sloped with a thin splash plate halfway down, there is a single headlight on the left and an IR one on the right, the driver has 2 periscopes and is sat on the right side of the hull as you look at it.

8dkdz4MRtxEtiF4tlpsa.description: The Namer is a heavy-APC based on the Merkava 4 chassis, built from the experience of the IDF converting MBT's into APC's like they did with the Centurions converted to Nakpadon's and Nagmachon's, there came the idea to create a newer heavy APC based on the Merkava. Apparently they are more heavily armoured than the Merkava 4 MBT's. According to the IDF, the Namer is the most heavily armoured vehicle in the world of any type, this is displayed in the fact that it weighs nearly the same as a Merkava 4, but without a turret. It shares the same battlefield management system as the Merkava tanks it works with. Some of the latest production Namer's include Trophy APS.
8dkdz4MRtxEtiF4tlpsa.name: Namer

recognising_features.namer_b0dhio12qp7tgzs32w6f.jpg: The Namer has a large hull, with heavy sloping on both the front and sides, with an RWS system on the right side, commanders hatch next to it on the left. The commanders hatch has 360 vision provided by periscopes, as well as an FN-MAG pintle mount. The driver sits in front of the commanders hatch with a single large periscope facing forwards, and two smaller ones either side.
recognising_features.namer_zclyrb7hhybac67nxrtd.jpg: The rear of the vehicle has a single ramp/door for dismounts which opens downwards, on either side of the door are two large boxes shaped extensions, making the door appear quite inset.

932F6-7Gz5KKC-uDWI1U.description: The Ural-4320 is a general purpose 6x6 truck, produced for the USSR Armed Forces. It comes in several variants, including armoured vehicles like the Ural-VV. Speed, power and range depend on the engines used, the data in the specifications tab are for the YaMZ-238M2 naturally-aspirated 14.9l V8 diesel.
932F6-7Gz5KKC-uDWI1U.name: Ural-4320

recognising_features.ural4320_s5otcitcyh1s1yynefz6.jpg: A good recognising feature is the black air intake on the right side, mounted atop of the mudguard.
recognising_features.ural4320_v8abz4ckxh1v45zgiz1w.jpg: The Ural-4320 is visually quite similar to the Ural-375D, though it is much larger and has barely any interchangeable parts between the two. The cab is very similar, though the grille is much larger and the lines on the grill are thicker than on the 375D, the engine compartment is also much larger and wider. The vehicle also has a much higher ground clearance, as you can see here with the gap between the ground and the vehicle.

941oAokC2J1IVkGwOSV4.description: The T-80BVM is a modernised T-80BV, fitted with a new Relikt ERA armour package, which reportedly reduces APFSDS effectiveness by 50%, it has a new 2A46M-4 Gun, Sosna-U sight, a newer GT engine and is reportedly fitted with a passive CM system. It was first shown in 2017 and entered service in 2018. It is sometimes called the T-80BVM Arctic, it’s also incorrectly called a T-80BV Obr.2017.
941oAokC2J1IVkGwOSV4.name: T-80BVM

recognising_features.t80bvm_7ov0xmsyw52cobxtbjy4.jpg: Along with the T-80BV, the T-80BVM is mostly reserved for use by units in the Far North, or Far Eastern regions of Russia, as it’s more suited to these biomes with the GT engine that performs better in the cold than the diesel powered T-72/T-90’s.
recognising_features.t80bvm_9slfig7sqeslscau8es3.jpg: I find a good recognising feature of the T-80BVM Is that the turret had a very distinctive ‘flying saucer’ shape due to the Relikt armour package.
recognising_features.t80bvm_g6h30wbixfltr0suwk3d.jpg: You will notice the extreme thickness of the ERA blocks on the hull, bringing the front glacis plate almost inline with side fuel panniers. The Tank now has long side skirts with bar armour at the rear, the same that you see fitted to T-72B3 Obr.2016
recognising_features.t80bvm_qvln7fk8sbpk62qpkq9f.jpg: The T-80BVM is almost unrecognisable now, with the completely new turret armour package. You will notice the changes, the large Relikt armour blocks that have no gaps in between them, there is a block which faces upwards more then the rest on the left side of the gun, the new Sosna-U thermal sight replacing the old IR sight, the meteorological sensor behind the sight which shows it has a modern FCS.
recognising_features.t80bvm_zvofeyzqyhro8tizy1kv.jpg: Close up of the turret showing the armour layout, including the new sighting systems.

99PjXE_Wr4ZUcLHKLMHO.description: The T-80BV Obr.2022 looks strikingly similar to the T-80BVM, but it isnt, the T-80BVM received Relikt, fire control upgrade, Sosna-U thermal sight etc. The difference here is that the T-80BV Obr.2022 has received Relikt, 1PN96MT-02 thermal sight and no other upgrade, so it is essentially an up-armoured T-80BV with a thermal sight. One of the most significant parts of BVM upgrade is Sosna-U, however these tanks have instead 1PN96MT-02 2nd gen thermal sight.  The T-80BV Obr.2022g also retains 1G42 gunner's sight (T-80BVM has PDT next to Sosna-U). This indicates these tanks were actually made from T-80BV. Hopefully this saves the confusion. Credit to @buschmodelar on twitter for the images and information on this vehicle.
99PjXE_Wr4ZUcLHKLMHO.name: T-80BV Obr.2022

recognising_features.t80bvobr.2022_f5ve8jfoljwm9v6mxomu.jpg: Notice also that T-80BVM Obr.2022g has received new armoured cover for Sosna-U optic, again demonstrating the difference between the two upgraded variants.
recognising_features.t80bvobr.2022_xv1girfgbz1o7nr18apk.jpg: As you can see here the 1G42 gunners sight is retained, with the 1PN96MT-02 thermal sight behind it. Though on the T-80BVM the 1G42 sight would be omitted and the Sosna-U is much larger than the 1PN96MT-02 sight.

9R3CVJSCISswA6KrPWi2.description: The M1 Abrams is the primary MBT series of the United States of America. The M1A1 is upgraded from the M1. New features include pressurised CBRN system, new stowage layout, new blow-off panels and the new M256 120mm smoothbore gun, hugely increasing lethality.
9R3CVJSCISswA6KrPWi2.name: M1A1

recognising_features.m1a1_2xga2zz0p1i80ipqjq8p.jpg: M1 Abrams thermal left side view.
recognising_features.m1a1_4emnb4s7m0kizvwsnz34.jpg: The M1A1 Abrams has a quintessential modern western tank design, heavily sloping armour, low hull with a large turret, straight lines and angled armour due to the fitting of composites. The turret has very slab like flat cheeks, the 120mm gun has a prominent fume extractor which is bulbous towards the top rather than cylindrical, the gun also has an MRS system at the end indicating advanced FCS. The way that you can identify an M1A1 to later models is via the lack of a commanders panoramic sight. The smoke grenade dischargers are fitted to the immediate turret sides, giving an ‘ears’ like appearance, although they’re covered in this photo.
recognising_features.m1a1_azsyoni9ujxmfoxfl345.jpg: The gunner has a prominent raises box sight, moving on to the hull the driver is sat centrally with 3 periscopes, the hull superstructure is raised towards the rear to accommodate for the GT engine. The tracks have a modern dual pin design similar to that of Challenger 2, it has 7 roadwheels with a prominent gap between the 1st and 2nd, the rest are equally spaced, with a cutout for the final drive at the rear. A thing I’ve always noticed personally is the periscopes have a purple/pink/red tint on them depending on lighting, you may see this in some photos.
recognising_features.m1a1_nd3n4tjtfcjei5j0j43j.jpg: The rear of the M1 shows the engine louvres and exhaust for the GT engine, notice the rear lights are in circular covers. You can also see the bustle rack at the rear for stowage.

9a8NdCLIWpNGQND_SUZD.description:
The MTU-72 is a Soviet/Russian armoured bridgelayer based on the T-72 hull, it is used by engineers to bridge wet crossings in order for other armoured vehicles to move over, bridge specs are as follows.
Single span:20m
The bridge has a gap crossing of 18m. An interesting feature of the MTU-72 is that it lays the bridge horizontally, rather than vertically like most western vehicles, this is so it is harder to spot when laying the bridge.
9a8NdCLIWpNGQND_SUZD.name: MTU-72

recognising_features.mtu72_gcwb42gtinl4yddxepmb.jpg: An interesting feature is that the MTU-72 lays the bridge horizontally rather than vertically like most western bridgelayers, this makes it much harder to spot. So to conclude on this, western bridges go up, Russian bridges go down.
recognising_features.mtu72_p5r8h4yqhufhga31x8yj.jpg: The MTU-72, like any other bridgelayer, is instantly recognisable for what it is,the bridge has the edges folded inwards on top of the largest part of the bridge. The bridge has 6 holes, with 2 larger holes paired together in the centre. The hull is that of a T-72, the road wheels are equally spaced, with the exhaust at the rear left.
recognising_features.mtu72_t48b3qaq7sineo9msam5.jpg: Seen here is a British Titan AVLB, note the way it bridges vertically.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Albania,Algeria,Angola,Argentina,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Bhutan,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Bulgaria,Burkina Faso,Cambodia,China,Colombia,Republic of the Congo,Republic of the Congo,Croatia,Cuba,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Germany,Guinea,Guinea-Bissau,Hungary,India,Iran,Iraq,Kazakhstan,Kyrgyzstan,Latvia,Laos,Libya,Lithuania,Maldives,Mexico,Mali,Moldova,Mongolia,Mozambique,Nepal,North Korea,Pakistan,Peru,Poland,Romania,Russia,Serbia,Slovakia,Somalia,Sudan,Syria,Turkey,Turkmenistan,Tajikistan,Ukraine,United States of America,Uzbekistan,Venezuela,Vietnam

9pFDU0yoo_lyS_kv8Qej.description: The Mil Mi-8TV, NATO reportingn name 'Hip-C', is an armed version of the base Mi-8. It is used for close air support as well as recconassiance roles in addition to being able to carry 24 passengers.
9pFDU0yoo_lyS_kv8Qej.name: Mi-8TV

recognising_features.mi8tv_ks9y0vfjo77h925va8ic.jpg: The only difference visually between the Mi-8 and Mi-8TV is the addition of weapon pylons on either side above the mufflers. Each pylon has 2 hardpoints, allowing a total of 4 weapons to be added.

9tCNG18fNSoEDc56D4oQ.description: The 9S18M, NATO reporting name 'Snow Drift', is the target acquisition radar used in the Buk family of surface to air missiles. It has an acquisition range of 160km and passess targets to the Buk TELARs for to engage with thier integral tracking and guidance radar.
9tCNG18fNSoEDc56D4oQ.name: 9S18M1

recognising_features.9s18m1snowdrift_4b3n0gbcswil73uazaf8.jpg: The Snow Drift is mounted on the same modified GM-569 chassis as the TELARs and TELs of the wider Buk family. The 9S112 consists of a large rectangular radar with a smaller rectangle above it, angled slightly forward.
recognising_features.9s18m1snowdrift_joreza7c7pckm20257n3.jpg: There is a mast above the cab of the vehicle, for communicating target tracks to the TELAR vehicles.

9yEuPIE0dtDIx1Czr3Tb.description: The GAZ Tigr-M is a modernised version of the GAZ Tigr protected mobility vehicle, It featured a new YaMZ-534 diesel engine, a new armoured hood, air filter installation and the replacement of the rear hatch with a larger square hatch. The GAZ Tigr-M is mainly used by VDV as well as some other specialist units of the Russian Army.
9yEuPIE0dtDIx1Czr3Tb.name: GAZ Tigr-M

recognising_features.gaztigrm_jym1c49r8ospaa972a75.jpg: The GAZ Tigr-M is mainly recognisable by the large bulge on the bonnet/hood of the vehicle, due to a newer engine. The other feature is the Arbalet-DM RWS (Remote Weapon Station) fitted to the vehicle as well, most standard GAZ Tigr's have a pintle mount, although some Tigr-M's do as well, but this is slightly rarer to see and is only in early production models of the M.

AhnTblUWYY-2HMw_o_e3.description: The BM-21 Grad is a 122mm multiple launch rocket system (MLRS) that has been in continuous service since 1963. It is mounted on a Ural-4320 chassis. The system can fire a variety of 122mm rockets, all under the umbrella designation of M-21OF. It is the most widely distributed MLRS in the world.
AhnTblUWYY-2HMw_o_e3.name: BM-21 Grad

recognising_features.bm21grad_8vb9c6yy2jiibwbcqla7.jpg: A BM-21 captured in Ukraine in 2022. Note the make-shift armour on the windows made out of logs to protect against small arms and RPG attack.
recognising_features.bm21grad_hzsrct1we6wr7kgupjf5.jpg: The Ural-4320 chassis has 6 wheels (3x3) with the BM-21 rocket system mounted on the flat bed to the rear. The system has 40 launch tubes in rows of 10. Although there are some variations to the system, it is easilty distinguishable from other Soviet wheeled MLRS due to its small size.

AzSDz2pphWh4evBF6SgE.name: MT-LBVMK
AzSDz2pphWh4evBF6SgE.description: The MTLBVMK is a variant of the MTLB for use in arctic environments, it features much wider tracks than standard. It also has the turret changed and a 12.7mm KORD pintle mount fitted instead, it is used by units in Northern Russia, like the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade and the 138th Guards Motor Rifle Brigade.

recognising_features.mtlbvmk_nadq055boycup51gx4fm.jpg: As seen here the turret has been changed and the pintle mount is fitted on top of it, giving the vehicle much more lethality than the standard 7.62mm PKT it usually has fitted on the standard model. The tracks are much wider for use in the snow, despite this being a biome based modification, the vehicle was still fitted with the wider tracks when used by the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade in the summer months of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.mtlbvmk_q70bq54f65mqfxx15emf.jpg: A log is typically carried on the right side of the upper hull in case the vehicle is bogged in. The tracks again can be seen here and are much wider than standard.

BI2IKthiBf5Jx1D28ZGW.description: The BMP-1, an IFV (Infantry Fighting Vehicle) of Soviet origin, derives its designation, BMP, as an abbreviation for "infantry fighting vehicle 1." It signifies the archetype of the initial authentic IFV, combining the armament attributes of a light tank with the infantry transportation capacity, thus creating a hybrid paradigm. Its production was widespread, with a notable contemporary manufacturing presence in Romania. Additionally, the BMP-1 features a noteworthy amphibious capability, enhancing its versatility across diverse operational terrains.
BI2IKthiBf5Jx1D28ZGW.name: BMP-1

recognising_features.bmp1_00yfdl16yttjxavmnyey.jpg: Here is a close view of the driver, commanders and gunners positions.
recognising_features.bmp1_4dk1os88wjcxuco7aj6c.jpg: The driver sits at the front left with 4 periscopes, behind him sits the vehicle/section commander, moving towards the rear you’ll see there are periscopes for the dismounts as well as the teardrop shaped firing ports, the roadwheels have a prominent gap between 4th-5th and 5th 6th, the final drive is at the front indicating the engine is frontally mounted.
recognising_features.bmp1_86m5f6a4pwpzjvjf2wps.jpg: BMP-1 left hand side thermal picture.
recognising_features.bmp1_ejryfy8ke925hotbvt72.jpg: A close view of the 9M14/9M14 Missile fitted above the main gun.
recognising_features.bmp1_tjq6ywmzomenz4zhl941.jpg: BMP-2 right hand side thermal picture.
recognising_features.bmp1_vz6ssc4q4weewnuy1nwq.jpg: The BMP-1 is quite a distinguishable vehicle, you will notice the short 73mm low velocity cannon, leading to the small 1 man ‘frying pan’ turret. Above the 73mm gun you will see the 9M14/9M14 Malyutka missile,it is exposed rather than in a launch tube. The hull is boat shaped showing it’s amphibious capability, you can see the trim vane is raised in this photo.

BQVMSChaI7aJXu6IuNnc.description: The BAT-2 is an armoured tracklayer/engineering vehicle based on the T-64, although it uses a version of the T-72 diesel engine, the V-64-4. It is designed to make tracks, as well as dig ditches.
BQVMSChaI7aJXu6IuNnc.name: BAT-2

recognising_features.bat2_c7h83o81yhfdyr6o3ht1.jpg: Here is a BAT-2 with the front dozer blade removed, there are 2 prominent headlights below the windows, as well as a ladder on the side.
recognising_features.bat2_splr5ybx4c171hagxvuw.jpg: The BAT-2 is identifiable by its large front earth moving blade, when not used it is raised above the cab. The cab is prominent with its 3 front windows, the side of the vehicle has multiple boxes to stow tools. There is also a large crane that is stored down the centre of the vehicle. You may notice that the road wheels are that of the T-64, which is a good feature for recognition, they are equally spaced throughout.

BXV53IE5TWLy_LbRwnop.description: The BTR-80 is an upgraded BTR-70, There are many upgrades to the platform, it now has a single engine, 6 81mm SGD’s, a turret redesign, redesigned firing ports and a new dismount door.
BXV53IE5TWLy_LbRwnop.name: BTR-80

recognising_features.btr80_c6ok3uzkqihl4e1v4rd0.jpg: The BTR-80 differs from the BTR-70 in a number of ways, the commanders position now has a new firing port, the firing ports are circular and face forward, you can see here they are in a row along the upper hull side, on BTR-70 the firing ports are teardrop shaped and do not face forward. There is a handrail above the firing ports, the door is redesigned and now has 2 parts, the upper and lower door.
recognising_features.btr80_f8we5w8hfa3boiugwx1j.jpg: On this photo you can see the changes to the superstructure, the hull is squared off at the rear rather than sloping. The exhausts are straight down the side of the hull, the upper hull has brake lights on either side, the tear drop water jet cover remains in the same place.
recognising_features.btr80_n5lo0r8eaggqzkwtpmcz.jpg: Seen here is the door previously mentioned, a point to note is that the footsteps in between the roadwheels are now squared off at the bottom, whereas on the BTR-70 they’re rounded, although this depends on variant, it can be commonly used as a distinctive feature, using the other features alongside it.

CLFuxvwVmBV2dmdnM9OO.description: Modernised BMP-2M, fitted with new stabilisation systems for the 30mm gun, TI sight for the gunner, new ATGM and a new crew compartment, it massively enhances the lethality for such a small, light vehicle.
CLFuxvwVmBV2dmdnM9OO.name: BMD-2M

recognising_features.bmd2m_5dcq0w6qln2m6838kpds.jpg: The BMD-2M is aptly nicknamed the ‘mini-berezhok’ due to its features being reminiscent ofthe BMP-2M Berezhok, it retains the same turret and armament from the BMD-2 and adds more capabilities, the most prominent being the new 9M133 Kornet ATGM mount on the side of the right side of the turret. It contains 2 missile launch tubes, on the left side of the turret it has the new thermal sight. The hull exterior and recognising features remain the same as the standard BMD-2.
recognising_features.bmd2m_xv3g8uze1d4hqbnocbnu.jpg: For a quick reference to tell apart from the BMP-2M is the lack of launch tubes on both sides of the turret like the BMP-2M has, also the tall thermal sight is a big giveaway.
recognising_features.bmd2m_zf6tmumc9nv5lebasy09.jpg: On this close up of the turret you can see the upgrades in full display, towards the rear of the turret you can see a wind sensor, due to most photographs being at arms expos and being prototypes, there are some differences, for example on this photo there are no SGD’s fitted.

CYFbvikOyr58XJ7ctthH.description: The BTR-70 is a Soviet APC produced as the successor to the BTR-60, It improved on an array of features, including new entry/exit hatches for the dismounts, thicker armour and more firing ports, the BTR-70 retained a feature from the BTR-60 which was the twin engine design, this meant that if one engine was damaged or inoperable the other engine could still drive the vehicle alone, albeit slowly. The original prototype of the BTR-70 actually had the turret from the BMP-1, this was changed due to costs. The BTR-70 in Russian service is solely used by the Russian Naval Infantry.
CYFbvikOyr58XJ7ctthH.name: BTR-70

recognising_features.btr70_mggc3sdey1ukeo2a2a1t.jpg: The BTR-70 has a boat shaped hull in line with its amphibious capability, the front has a splash plate which is folded down normally unless preparing for a crossing. There are 2 armoured windows with shutters, seen here in the raised position, above them are periscopes for when the shutters are closed. At the front centre there is a one man conical turret with a 14.5mm KPVT and 7.62mm Coax PKT.
recognising_features.btr70_uix6jarzgcp6l9kq59n4.jpg: The side retains the boat shape, there are 4 road wheels with a prominent gap between the 2nd and 3rd road wheels to make room for the dismount door, there are 2 footsteps, in between each pair of road wheels they are triangular in shape with a squared off end. The rear of the BTR-70 slopes downwards and has 2 exhausts either side, they are cylindrical in shape, these are a good indicator for TI. There is an angled ‘teardrop’ shape at the rear centre for the water jet.

D1Um6Iv8ofO11vPYSk7R.name: ZTZ-96A
D1Um6Iv8ofO11vPYSk7R.description: The ZTZ-96A is the second generation upgrade of the ZTZ-96 MBT platform, the A upgrade brings upgrades in the form of protection, with FY-4 ERA fitted, thermal imaging for the gunner and also an engine upgrade which gives more power. Some sources state the internal electronics may have been upgraded to ZTZ-99 standards, though I cannot confirm this, the ZTZ-96 series in terms of comparison is like the T-72 in the Russian Army, with the ZTZ-99 being the T-90 equivalent.

recognising_features.ztz96a_gs148ih6jlhv3kcxoqvv.jpg: The ZTZ-96A is relatively easy to distinguish from the ZTZ-96 standard model, but it is commonly confused with the ZTZ-99 due to the similarities with the turret ERA layout, the FY-4 ERA tiles on the frontal turret provide an arrowhead shape, giving an appearance similar to the Leopard 2A6's frontal turret. The stowage racks on the side also have ERA tiles covering them. It is worth noting that the ZTZ-99's have 5 smoke grenade dischargers per bank, whereas the ZTZ-96A has 6.
recognising_features.ztz96a_p8gmn3xipxz1iii2nztw.jpg: The exhausts for this model remain on the right side, two exhaust outlets, whereas on the ZTZ-96B and ZTZ-99 the exhaust outlets are at the rear, this is pertinent to remember if thermal imaging is available.

EBVGt71K3Q4uFbsFVkzz.description: The FV511 ICV (Infantry Command Vehicle) Warrior is a command variant of the FV510 Warrior ISV with the main differences being double rear doors rather a ram operated single door, four externally mounted antennae and a different seating arrangement in the rear for map boards and so on, the Warrior FV511 is designed to be indistinguishable to the FV510 from the front and sides, therefore preventing its identification as a HVT. The radio fit of the vehicle depends on whether the vehicle is intended for Platoon, Company or Battalion level of command.
EBVGt71K3Q4uFbsFVkzz.name: FV511

recognising_features.fv511_5esgsken9y81xuto6bjv.jpg: Seen here are the doors opened, you can also see the extra antennae, which is a common theme for the majority of command orientated vehicles.
recognising_features.fv511_d4t7rgghrq0nbwzbp168.jpg: The main recognising feature of the FV511 Warrior is the rear doors, the doors are manually operated and there are 2 doors rather than one ram operated door like on the FV510. The doors open outwards and are nicknamed clamshell doors. It also has an extra antennae base.

Ehf6wtiVZO8Xf-ZPBnju.description: The 9K331 Tor, NATO reporting name SA-15 'Gauntlet' is a medium level surface to air missile system. Mounted on a 9A330 chassis the system is classified as a self-propelled transporter, launcher and radar (TLAR). It is similiar to the United Kingdom Rapier system. The missiles are guided by the integral 'Scrum half' radar system.
Ehf6wtiVZO8Xf-ZPBnju.name: 9K331 Tor-M1

recognising_features.9k331torm1_2n93wdzobuc13k7nxa6l.jpg: When the system is elevated the most obvious feature is the large square tracking radar at the front, with a circular protruding section. The target acquisition radar at the rear consists of a rectangular mesh dish. Both radars together are classed as the 'Scrum Half' radar system.
recognising_features.9k331torm1_s2es3hsk1ahtw0us98nc.jpg: The Tor-M1 has one circular sensor on the top left corner of the tracking radar as opposed the Tor-M2's dual sensors. This is a key way of identifying the difference between the two variants.
recognising_features.9k331torm1_swzwyc0p39op4zyy5pmq.jpg: Destroyed Tor-M1 seen in Ukraine in 2022.
recognising_features.9k331torm1_vfh59phkmbm06ozcsbyb.jpg: The 9A330 chassis has 7 evenly spaced roadwheels with the final drive to the rear. The hull is boat shaped at the front and flat at the rear, with a number of rectangular storage bins on either side. The weapon system, shown here depressed, is the same height as the tracks. You can make out one of the radars in the downward position.

ExbDYJ5C2RajP8Ufjm0Z.description: The 2S23 is an upgrade of the 2S9 Nona system, mounted instead on the BTR-80, and is used by Russian marines. The barrel is 120mm and only 1.8m long, making it a hybrid between a mortar and a howitzer.
ExbDYJ5C2RajP8Ufjm0Z.name: 2S23 Nona-SVK

recognising_features.2s23nonasvk_l1acf6c80bw43cj57e68.jpg: The 2S23 Nona is mounted on a BTR-80 chassis with the prominent gap between the second and third wheel. The turret sits forward on the vehicle, above the first and second wheel.
recognising_features.2s23nonasvk_w9d2au8wu6plg04jz6v6.jpg: The 2A60 barrel is short, only 1.8metres, making it more of a mortar than a howitzer. The key recognising feature is the lack of muzzle break on the end of the barrel and the tripe smoke dischargers either side on the turret.

Fctr0q4c1Z7pVHi6VkMf.description: The object 219R was accepted into Soviet service in 1978 as the T-80B, this version is essentially the base model of the T-80 series, the T-80A was never officially adopted and ended up being developed as the T-80U. The T-80B was quickly replaced with the T-80BV leaving the T-80B quite a rare sight, although some T-80B's have been sighted in Ukraine and have also been used for training of units.
Fctr0q4c1Z7pVHi6VkMf.name: T-80B

recognising_features.t80b_nnoocwaeicyyqv9o9qlq.jpg: The front plate of the T-80B is smooth, with no splash plate like on other T-Series. The driver has 3 periscopes and there are 2 rubber flaps on the lower glacis plate.The roadwheels are placed in twos, with a prominent gap between the 5th and 6th.
recognising_features.t80b_r9f33sc6lzmdgccqbv2n.jpg: On the right side in front of the commanders cupola is the GTN-12 Kobra GLATGM guidance box, the transmitter is linked to the sighting system using the 9S416-1 control system, which translates the shifting of the point of aim in the 1G42 sight to generate a command signal for the missile, thus forming a SACLOS guidance regime. The infrared bulb at the tail of the 9K112 missile is detected and tracked by the 1G42 sight. Due to the use of radio guidance, it is possible to jam the 9K112 missile during its flight. However, it does not appear that such equipment was developed or fielded by the expected enemy so this appears to be a very minor drawback. To the left of the box is a stowage box.
recognising_features.t80b_yqnj7latwkwvex7kh098.jpg: The T-80B is the earliest model of the T-80 series, therefore it has none of the later upgrades. The turret is basically a modified T-64 turret. There is a large snorkel on the rear, much larger than that of the T-72/T-90, on the left side of the turret are square stowage boxes, usually these boxes are used for callsign markings, or in this case a Russian Guards insignia. The front turret cheeks have SGD's in an uneven array with 2 on the left, 1 in the centre and 2 on the right, on the other side of the gun; due to the Luna IR searchlight there are 3 SGD's placed close together. The gunner is equipped with the TPN 3-49 IR sight, which is the small squarish shaped box with a sight cover fitted, in front of that is the 1G42 day sight, the 1G42 is much wider and taller than the TPD-K1 'doghouse' sight.

FjRi8WykMdX9RsuDoNxs.description: The PRP-4 Nard is an artillery reconnaissance vehicle, its role is to provide surveillance and location finding of enemy vehicles and also enemy artillery batteries for counter-battery fire, it is also there to talk on the artillery units for fire adjustment. It has a ‘Tall Mike’ radar, multiple sighting systems and newer radios.It has a ball mount PKTfor self-defence. The PSNR-5K Tall Mike radar has a detection range for infantry(individually or in a group) is 4km, for vehicles on the same terms, 8-10km.
FjRi8WykMdX9RsuDoNxs.name: PRP-4

recognising_features.prp4_mqokp0uh62of8qbcw2x4.jpg: The PRP-4 Nard is based on the BMP-1 Hull, the hull remains relatively the same with the main differences being the turret, for hull recognition features, refer to the BMP-1 in the IFV Section. The turret is a large 2 man turret similar to the BRM-1K, it has a small ball mount for the PKT, with 2 prominent boxes either side of the turret, like ears; they are the sighting systems, as well as the raised boxes on the top of the turret which are sighting systems as well. At the rear of the turret, there is the ‘Tall Mike’ radar system; it can be lowered and raised by the RadOp.

Fn2WAWOfLxYEPwIBIbGr.description: The R-145BM is a command vehicle based on the BTR-60PA, it is turret-less and has a large collapsible frame AZI antennae, an AMU 10 m high telescopic mast, the AB-1-P/30 auxiliary power unit for use of equipment without the main engine needing to be running, five radio sets (one R-123MT(VHF), one R-130(Shortwave), two R-111(VHF+Data) and one R-012M) as well as the TA-57 field telephone.
Fn2WAWOfLxYEPwIBIbGr.name: R-145BM command vehicle

recognising_features.r145bmcommandvehicle_h24fivuql0v313ocwrg: The R-145BM is recognisable as a command vehicle, this is due to its lack of turret and abundance of antennae systems, the large AZI antennae frame runs along the top of the vehicle, (the frame antennae does not run along the right side of the vehicle) with mounting points jutting out of the sides of the superstructure, with the large AMU-10 antennae on the right side of the upper hull. The hull itself is that of a modified BTR-60PA.

G6QvQyH_3bIYklpW-Yg7.description: The BMR-3M 'Vepr' (Boar) was developed to replace the ageing BMR-2 based on the T-54, the BMR-3M is based on the T-90 with a new welded superstructure, Kontakt-1 ERA,  strengthened armour on the belly and ECM systems to detonate magnetically fuzed mines, also radio jammers that prevent remotely controlled explosives. The vehicles are equipped with KTM-7 mine rollers with chains fitted, to detonate tilt-mast fuses, the mine clearing speed is 12kph max. There is a cargo stowage platform at the rear, as well as a 2.5t crane. The vehicle also has a system for marking cleared lanes.
G6QvQyH_3bIYklpW-Yg7.name: BMR-3M

recognising_features.bmr3m_14btqzx9q6ufpkeld2fk.jpg: The BMR-3M is instantly recognisable for being covered in Kontakt-1, the huge mine clearing system also are a giveaway to the vehicles purpose. The abundance of antennae are the ECM systems. The driver is centrally seated with a large vision block in the centre of the vehicle superstructure, the commander is seated behind him with a cupola. On both sides of the superstructure are banks of 4 SGD's, with an IR light on the right and normal light on the left, the rest of the hull remains the same as the T-90A, with the roadwheels being equally spaced throughout.
recognising_features.bmr3m_cjrr5uj9sk54zkrh7ikg.jpg: This image shows the rear of the BMR-3M and its stowage compartment, just behind the raised superstructure.
recognising_features.bmr3m_nb6w1u08cf7sm0gbmxtt.jpg: The BMR-3M can be fitted with different mine rollers depending on the situation on the ground, the exhaust is on the left side of the vehicle, in the same place as the T-90, this is where the thermal signature will mostly be received from.

GC_zbcIsQHEk6bQO_pH2.description: The GMZ-3 is an armoured minelayer, based on the GM-123 chassis, so you may notice some similiarities with other vehicles that use the GM hull, like the 2S3, 2S4 and 2S5 SPG's. This chassis is a common one on Former Soviet Union vehicles. The GMZ-3 has 4 cassettes that hold mines of various models, which are then fed to a mechanism which sets the fuze to the firing position, the mines are then placed on a conveyer belt which exits the vehicle at the rear through the dispenser. It's main focus is to create large minefields for defence.
GC_zbcIsQHEk6bQO_pH2.name: GMZ-3

recognising_features.gmz3_0o12fxty8x0fhx6f4otg.jpg: The GMZ-3 is distinctive mainly with its large mining system at the rear of the vehicle, as seen here it is in the travel position which is raised, when laying mines it will be lowered. The GM-123 hull itself will be a familiar sight due to it being the base platform of the 2S3,2S4 and 2S5 SPG's among other platforms. The front of the hull is sloped, with the driver sat on the left with 2 periscopes, the commander is behind him with a large cupola, the cupola has 4 vision blocks around it as well as a searchlight and pintle mount for an MG. To the right of the commander and driver are the engine decks. There are splash plates on the lower slope of the engine deck, there are 2 headlights on either side of the hull which sit on top of the mudguard.
recognising_features.gmz3_16nohx62q5s0kl85byxx.jpg: The exhaust is on the front right and this is where you will find a thermal signature, the roadwheels are of the old Soviet 'starfish' type, there are 3 top rollers, the final drive at the front and the 7 roadwheels with variable spacings between them. On the sides at the rear are 3 SGD's, there is also a cupola at the rear, which is sloped on either side and is sat on the right side of the vehicle, this is for the 3rd crewman to observe and manage the laying of mines.
recognising_features.gmz3_xzd1neqkepl0aeeswpo2.jpg: This image shows the 3rd crewmans position.

GCeH_qNKGGmnhGdzWlTh.description: The BTR-70MB1 is a Belorussian modification of its ageing BTR-70 fleet, it looks generally quite similar to the standard BTR-70 but has a rearranged engine compartment, it is also fitted with bar armour, the engine is new and gives the vehicle 260hp instead of 120hp, massively increasing the mobility.
GCeH_qNKGGmnhGdzWlTh.name: BTR-70MB1

recognising_features.btr70mb1_4keasaiq5a81f6oyte7h.jpg: As seen here, the rear section is completely different, the structure is raised and the exhausts are straight, following the hull and are more similar to that of a BTR-80. The structure is much higher and gives a hump appearance, whereas the standard BTR-70 has a sloped rear. The rear lights are in mounts and are on either side of the back. The water propulsion jet remains the same, with the distinctive teardrop shaped cover on the rear centre.
recognising_features.btr70mb1_h9f8ji8cg627wxkjdr35.jpg: From the front the vehicle looks like a standard BTR-70, although the rear is the biggest giveaway. This mostly applies for when, as shown here, the bar armour is not fitted. Swipe for a picture of the rear section.
recognising_features.btr70mb1_s5rh82aylgy3sq9xp0yg.jpg: Seen here on parade is the BTR-70MB1 fitted with bar armour, this is how I assess it is most likely to be seen if ever used in a conflict.

GL4XUBrOMfGC547BS9mP.description: The Mil Mi-17, known in Russia as the Mi-8M, is an improved Mi-8 'Hip' family. It has larger engines and improved rotors. It was designed for operating in higher altitude and hotter environments. In 2008, China began produce Mi-17 helicopters on licence.
GL4XUBrOMfGC547BS9mP.name: Mi-17

recognising_features.mi17_wqi01ekwcaiinwcxe4vo.jpg: The key recognising feature to differentiate the Mi-17 from the Mi-8 is the fact that the tail rotor now sits on the port (right) side of the rudder.
recognising_features.mi17_zktzmhv2s795r3i1qzc6.jpg: Another recognising feature is the addition of covers over the dual air intakes above the cockpit. Some Mi-17s also have the lower section of the cockpit in a metal cone, as opposed to glass on the Mi-8.

GYGPQP5qOdGNSpBvpwNd.description: T-62 is a Soviet MBT introduced in ‘61 as a further development of the T-55, it was the first production tank to be armed with a smoothbore gun, it prompted western militaries to begin experimenting with smoothbore as well as developing new munitions to defeat the T-62, still in use today and manufactured in very large numbers, estimated to be around 23,000 tanks.
GYGPQP5qOdGNSpBvpwNd.name: T-62

recognising_features.t62_4niani7d5n1d0r311izf.jpg: Turret, classic Soviet style frying pan shaped turret. Handrails either side for infantry to hold on. IR searchlight on the right side of the gun, sights on the left side. 2A20 gun with prominent fume extractor 3/4 of the way up the barrel.
recognising_features.t62_9ait1prguzfnl0y44154.jpg: Heavy sloping front glacis plate with a splash plate for the driver, driver sits on the left side with 2 vision periscopes.
