CES stowage down the left side with fuel tanks on the right. Exhaust cutout on the left side. Tracks are slack, first 3 roadwheels are equally spaced with prominent gaps between the 3rd-4th, 4th-5th

GyXzLnSYRHQgeX6Geu8Y.description: The 9P157-4 is a battery command vehicle for the 9P157-2 ATGM batteries, it is there to hand-off and distribute targets to the launchers, although the launchers can operate on their own.
GyXzLnSYRHQgeX6Geu8Y.name: 9P157-4 BCV

recognising_features.9p1574bcv_l7svay95vu8auao2t188.jpg: The major addition is the array of sighting systems fitted to the turret and the rear, there is no launcher on this vehicle.
recognising_features.9p1574bcv_n5nhp2s1tfwws7nongd7.jpg: The 9P157-4 (Right) is mounted on the same hull (BMP-3) but has a BMP-3 turret with the main armament removed and an armoured cover fitted, the PKTremains for self-defence.

GzWY6KrpZqbxKcRnDL-0.description: The ZSU 23-4M4 is an improved variant used by Russia & Belarus. It has an upgraded radar, sighting system and includes the addition of 9K38 'Igla', NATO designation SA-18 'Grouse'. The addition of the SAMs makes it close in capability to the 2K22 Tunguska (SA-19).
GzWY6KrpZqbxKcRnDL-0.name: ZSU 23-4M4

recognising_features.zsu234m4_ania5hrfqnrlea7y0lht.jpg: The M4 upgrade now has 2 x 9K38 'Igla' surface to air missiles mounted on the rear of the turret. It also has improved protection, including side skirts and flaps beneath the front glacis plate.

HMqxug1PDEGnsNIL4Vk9.description: The T-80BVM Obr.2022 is aimed at giving the T-80BVM more protection, in the form of more ERA on the hull sides, turret sides, turret rear and gun mantlet, the Sosna-U thermal sight also has a new sight cover.
HMqxug1PDEGnsNIL4Vk9.name: T-80BVM Obr.2022

recognising_features.t80bvmobr.2022_3g9hpp5yjswuwry987sv.jpg: This picture shows a T-80BVM fitted with Nakidka thermal cloaking, which reduces thermal signature of the tank, it hasnt been seen on T-80BVM's before, usually just T-90M's.
recognising_features.t80bvmobr.2022_jk9k02knf5fk0bnr735m.jpg: The T-80BVM Obr.2022 remains the same as the T-80BVM internally, but has an armour upgrade which covers the perceived weakspots and overall improves survivability, the UBH sideskirts as seen here now extend fully down the sides, then they have 4S22 ERA fitted over them, which isnt present here as they had just left the factory. The turret Relikt ERA receives a hanging net like on the T-90M.
recognising_features.t80bvmobr.2022_x0zsvmvq6k8q1s5ofq9l.jpg: The Sosna-U receives an upgraded sight door system as well, as shown here.
recognising_features.t80bvmobr.2022_ydtvokzdwrqm0x45g2yb.jpg: Here you can see the 4S22 boxes fitted to the hull sides, these extend all the way to the rear.

HMzH0Qa1Kt6oNUZvDE0S.description: The ZTQ-15 is a Chinese light tank operated by the PLA Ground Forces and PLA Naval Marine Corps, A purpose built light tank for use in Highlands/Wetland biomes, primarily on the border regions between China/India, envisaged for use in high altitude regions, therefore it has an oxygen generator and high powered engine. It’s light weight, powerful engine combine it for use in places the ZTZ-99 MBT would have problems. Protection is a steel composite, it also has an ERA and bar armour package seen in photos and on Chinese state media. Other equipment includes air conditioning system, oxygen-production equipment for the crew, command and control equipment, battlefield management system, and navigation suite fitted with both inertial navigation system (INS) and satellite navigation system. Due to its lighter weight, the ZTQ-15 tank can be more easily airlifted. Y-20 transport planes can only carry one ZTZ-99 tank but can carry up to two ZTQ-15 tanks and achieve long-range deployment of 7,800 kilometers. ZTQ-15 can also be paradropped by the transport aircraft. It is lightly armed, but this is purely because it will be unlikely to encounter MBT's in it's perceived AO's.
HMzH0Qa1Kt6oNUZvDE0S.name: ZTQ-15

recognising_features.ztq15_8vdlcobarmkrxpfmzi5a.jpg: The ZTQ-15 has a modern Dual Pin track design, 6 roadwheels with prominent gaps between the 1st-2nd, 2nd-3rd with a cutout at the rear for the final drive. Drivers position is on the left side of the hull, with 3 vision periscopes and what appears to be a camera in the centre, on the side near the driver there is an air intake, unsure of whether this is for the oxygen generators/engine air intake or the CBRN system.Sloping front plate with ERA on the lower front plate.
recognising_features.ztq15_cruf4w88tba24dj0aw5n.jpg: A ZTQ-15 with the ERA package.
recognising_features.ztq15_er145t4fl1ly0e18yid3.jpg: Large louvres at the rear, with two small circular exhausts on either side. The rear of the turret also has hatches to load rounds into the autoloader.
recognising_features.ztq15_pgs6413svfb4y4itmbun.jpg: 105mm MA with a fume extractor 1/4 way down the barrel, no muzzle reference system fitted to the barrel, which begs the question of how modern the FCS actually is. The turret has a similar design to the Leopard 2A5, with a clamshell like appearance from the composite armour and ERA fitting, appears to be laser warning sensors on both frontal turret corners. Gunners sight is on the left, commanders panoramic on the right, met sensor fitted to the rear left, smoke dischargers both sides at the turret rear in the bustle rack.
recognising_features.ztq15_s6unsosmou9j7c5zzbbn.jpg: An easy way to identify that the PLANMC are using the tank is the naval camouflage scheme, more can be seen on this in the camouflage section.

HxqrlIYqbD1IPnxf9H8Y.description: Utilising the MTLB platform, the ACRV M1974 (1) IV13 functions as the Battery Fire Direction Center (FDC), remaining stationed within the battery's firing configuration. Managed by the battery's senior officer from the first firing platoon, the FDC collaborates with manual fire direction computation and communication personnel. This setup enables direct radio connections with the Battery Command Observation Post (COP), Battalion COP, and Battalion FDC. Acting as a conduit, the battery's senior officer relays essential firing data to the 122mm and 152mm SP howitzers, ensuring efficient coordination in artillery actions.
HxqrlIYqbD1IPnxf9H8Y.name: 1V13

IBdZ0W6-58ySiKjcHDSQ.description: The VT-5 is a Chinese export light tank based on the ZTQ-15, the tank differs in looks slightly. This is commonly misreported as the ZTQ-15. Bangladesh is the sole operator of the tank.
IBdZ0W6-58ySiKjcHDSQ.name: VT-5

recognising_features.vt5_f26dftsa4ohcqdy94g1q.jpg: The VT-5 has a slightly different layout than the ZTQ-15 it's based on, namely the central drivers position rather than the offset position on the ZTQ-15. The exhausts are now on the rear sides of the tank instead of the rear. The turret has a different armour layout and a long cutout next to the gun, this may be the coax machine gun position, or an auxiliary sight. The turret armour and frontal hull armour is much more curved than the standard ZTQ-15.
recognising_features.vt5_iemm3aqwextrbkcryxen.jpg: Here is the ERA/Bar armour kit, it is different in layout to the ZTQ-15.

IGtF1c3Q0XB9vR550tXA.description: The Achzarit Mk.1 was always deemed to be underpowered, so the Mk.2 was upgraded with a new engine, as well as upgraded protection, mainly on the commanders cupola, as well as a remote weapon system.
IGtF1c3Q0XB9vR550tXA.name: Achzarit Mk.2

recognising_features.achzaritmk.2_iky9en63ecjwguskvov7.jpg: The cupola design varies, some have much larger vision blocks. This vehicle is fitted with an RWS (Remote Weapon System), with a .50 HMG mounted on it.
recognising_features.achzaritmk.2_qaukav6ma4fbgsta0qwc.jpg: As seen here, the Achzarit Mk.2 has an elevated commanders cupola with protective glass vision blocks, giving the commander 360 degree vision around the vehicle, without the need to expose himself.

IfBsY-2Ru87L2C3-M8Dp.description: The 2S9 Nona is a light-weight howitzer, mounted on the BTR-D chassis. The 2S9 is used by Russian Airborne troops (VDV) due to its ability to be air dropped into battle. The gun is medium range, and more than enough for supporting Airborne troops.
IfBsY-2Ru87L2C3-M8Dp.name: 2S9 Nona

recognising_features.2s9nona_9th62fqkd73hbopqcd47.jpg: The turret of the 2S9 is round with a circular bulge on the left hand side of the turret. The key recognising feature of the 2S9 is the fact that the 2A51 barrel has no muzzle break.
recognising_features.2s9nona_tf5ua924djtmncm54161.jpg: The 2S9 is mounted on the lightweight BTR-D chassis, which has 6 road wheels and the final drive at the rear.

IiEOjHqwLCPBJ19laP-9.description:
T-72BA is used to refer to several late model T-72B builds, that were stripped down, refurbished and upgraded certain parts at UralVagonZavod between 1998-2005. Because the upgrade was performed on various T-72B’s with different mounts for ERA there can be some deviation between models, but there are several features on every T-72BA. Approximately 750 were produced.
These include a new engine with an upgraded exhaust, new twin pin tracks from the T-90A (sometimes known as Vickers style tracks) and a meteorological sensor for the 1A40 FCS. 
The T72BA also has upgraded Kontakt-5 ERA.
IiEOjHqwLCPBJ19laP-9.name: T-72BA

recognising_features.t72ba_1xwed4o3joka5t7vv8ai.jpg: Here is a T-72B3, you will notice the lack of IR searchlight, the Sosna-U sighting system on the left side. A point to note is on T-72BA it has ERA bricks fitted in a 4-4 format on either side of the turret, on T-72B3 it is a 4-5 configuration due to the omitting of the IR searchlight, another point is the confusion between T-72B Obr.1989/BA and B3 with the T-90A, the way to differentiate is that on T-72’s the ERA has gaps between them, on T-90A there are no gaps.
recognising_features.t72ba_kq8nm1rjf3ppyvd5326p.jpg: The T-72BA recognising features, these will help to differentiate between a T-72B Obr.1989 and a T-72B3, it retains the IR Searchlight, unlike T-72B3 in which the searchlight is omitted, a key feature is the DWE-BS wind sensor towards the rear of the turret. The Kontakt-5 ERA will help you recognise that it is a T-72BA, not an AV/B/B1.
recognising_features.t72ba_qiag2yxv2gsexm55u895.jpg: Seen here is a T-72B Obr.1989, you will notice the lack of the crosswind sensor on the rear of the turret.

J0D0CZcFoDvIqeYNrHnB.description: The PGL-12 is the SPAAG variant of the Type-08 family of wheeled AFV's, this vehicle itself is extremely rare and hard to find photographs of, it is believed that it isn't fully in service yet and is still in trials due to the mystery and lack of information on the platform. The gun is a single 35mm cannon, it seems to be the same one from the twin 35mm's on the PGZ-09, which itself is a copy of the Oerlikon GDF gun, according to Chinese sources the gun on this model has a modified breech, which raises rate of fire from 550rpm to 1000rpm, increasing fire density, doing away with the need for two guns.
J0D0CZcFoDvIqeYNrHnB.name: PGL-12

recognising_features.pgl12_080idk68beh0382oksgz.jpg: The front of the turret has a large sight and likely fire control radar for the main gun, which is on a mount enabling it to elevate and depress with the gun.
recognising_features.pgl12_4zjx02msdfevxau40tgz.jpg: The superstructure of this variant has changed quite a bit, the drivers and commanders position is raised and contains windows rather than hatches and periscopes like on the rest of the family, the windows do have armoured shutters, the superstructure then lowers back down to provide room for the large turret, the turret is angled and has hatches on the sides, likely for loading of ammunition, there are SGD's along the bottom of the frontal turret. There is a large tracking radar which is raised at the rear of the turret, this radar can be lowered and raised. The hull raises again at the rear to accomodate the powerpack.
recognising_features.pgl12_rh5pbilyjtjovbpy1kkz.jpg: On this side of the hull there is a hatch in the centre, likely for entrance into the hull for the gunner. It looks like the exhaust is the circle towards the rear of the hull at the powerpack compartment.
recognising_features.pgl12_wtf9h6gt94bbfgqnm2o6.jpg: The rear of the vehicle has two hatches, these are likely service hatches for the powerpack compartment.

J8rNR8s6jfISwAt-stDB.description: Challenger 2 is an advancement on the Challenger 1, development began in 1986 by Vickers Defence Systems(now part of BAE). It only has 3% commonality of parts with the Challenger 1, it has many new features including TI, FCS, Main Armament and Powerpack. It has seen operational service in Kosovo, Bosnia and Iraq, in the former it performed outstandingly compared to contempary tanks in theatre.
J8rNR8s6jfISwAt-stDB.name: Challenger 2

recognising_features.challenger2_8e3twd77fri0jdq9eumq.jpg:
OES Variant
Dorchester block on the lower glacis
NERA plates across the upper glacis
Both Hull sides have NERA blocks with Bar armour across the rear quarter 
Turret has NERA blocks across the sides with bar armour across the rear quarter
ECM Module at the rear of the turret
GPMG mount replaced with RWS
recognising_features.challenger2_l3tlw1yxrw9l9avgc81v.jpg: Hull, heavy sloping across the front glacis plate, cutout for the drivers position with a single periscope. Drivers splash plate with cutouts for both headlights. 6 roadwheels with prominent gap between 3rd-4th and 5th-6th, exhausts on both sides at the rear quarter for thermal signature.
recognising_features.challenger2_oqu96bhyk7y6t0wmdaun.jpg: Turret, heavy sloping on the front with flat sides. 2 banks of 4 SGD’s either side of the gun, above the L30A1 is the mount for the TI sight, the gunners sight is on the right hand side with the commanders independent periscope behind the gunners sight.

JLAcWGG3iMEIB4HaUCK-.description: The MT-LBu 1V14, known as the "Artillery Command and Reconnaissance Vehicle (ACRV) M1974," is a versatile military vehicle built on the MT-LB chassis. Operating as an observation post and a light Fire Support Team Vehicle (FISTV), it plays a crucial role as a forward observer. Its arsenal includes a long-range data-capable computer and three medium-range radios, initially featuring a radio teletype which was replaced by a computer. It boasts impressive observation capabilities with enhanced day and night vision, a laser rangefinder, and a laser designator, all housed in an expanded turret. Armed with a light machine gun, the vehicle can also perform secondary functions like surveying gun locations. A telescoping antenna ensures long-range communication, while GLONASS navigation with an inertial backup aids movement. Upgraded versions sport improved day and night vision, making the 1V14 an invaluable asset for relaying sensor data, target coordinates, and preliminary fire solutions to higher headquarters.
JLAcWGG3iMEIB4HaUCK-.name: 1V14

JTXmoUZSPyp4HAnWwqjn.description: The Ural-375D is a general purpose military truck, it replaced the ZIL-157 as the standard Soviet Army truck in 1979, it itself has been replaced by the Ural-4320, though not fully and still sees service with reserve units, it has multiple variants including the BM-21 grad, TCV (Troop Carrying Vehicle) and mechanical variants, it also sees popularity in the civilian market.
JTXmoUZSPyp4HAnWwqjn.name: Ural-375D

recognising_features.ural375d_xu0stn947v0x4jiznmlo.jpg: The Ural-375D has a typical T-shaped cab, the bonnet/hood is long and sloping with a flat front, the air intake grille is central at the front, with 2 mudguards on either side, underneath the mudguards are the headlight clusters, with a large bar underneath them, sometimes, like on this one there are extra lights underneath the bar. The cab has large windows in the front, split by a central pane. Behind the cab is usually a spare tyre which can be seen from the right side of the vehicle, on the left side is a stowage box and a set of ladders for access to the top of the cab. The fuel tank is behind the cab.

Ji-D3ixIRGJ5PUKmTE6a.description: The BMP-1Ksh is a Soviet/Russian command vehicle of the battalion level, commonly used by motor rifle regiments based on the BMP series of vehicles, the gun is removed and replaced with a ‘HAWK EYE’ mast, as well as other additions for comms equipment.
Ji-D3ixIRGJ5PUKmTE6a.name: BMP-1Ksh

recognising_features.bmp1ksh_dq542m6erecxay7dmtb2.jpg: On the right side, there is a box in the centre of the hull, above that is a stowage box for a mast. The turret has an IR searchlight above the hatch.
recognising_features.bmp1ksh_j1sg4isavakh420xk7yr.jpg: The BMP-1Ksh is easily remembered with an easy to remember pneumonic ‘Keep Sending Home’ due to it being a command vehicle, if taken out it can no longer send home. The turret  is the same as the BMP-1 except it has a large mast in place of the 73mm gun. There are boxes at the rear of the hull, as well as more mounts for antennae on the rear, you can see the antennae base sticking out at the rear right.
recognising_features.bmp1ksh_m4cbsc49e02gcm491338.jpg: You can see on this image that the turret is fixed in place, there is also a searchlight above the vehicle commanders hatch.

Jn3f-hNMvkm6-60odjb3.description: The GAZ-66 is a Soviet 4x4 military truck, it was one of the main cargo trucks for the Soviet Ground Forces, it has a large variety of variants including ambulances, decontamination vehicles, mobile workshops as well as standard TCV (Troop Carrying Vehicles). Nearly a million vehicles were produced for both military and civilian use, it has gained legendary status due to its unmatched reliability, off road capability and being simple to fix, it is nicknamed 'шишига' meaning 'trueman'.
Jn3f-hNMvkm6-60odjb3.name: GAZ-66

recognising_features.gaz66_cm33xpq916q574mp8gce.jpg: The GAZ-66 truck has a flat front, but still has some of the typical fittings to Soviet trucks of this era. These include a searchlight next to the drivers mirror, three orange lights on the roof and 2x large windows with a thin pane down the centre. In front of the doors is another thin oval mirror. The front of the cab has a grille which has 9 vertical cut outs for air feed to the radiator, the lights consist of a large circular headlight on both sides, as well as a small circular indicator above it.
recognising_features.gaz66_l38qwmarh172jsgen9p8.jpg: Below the grille is a large metal bumper, this provides space for the winch which can be seen at the front lower centre. The GAZ-66 has 4 roadwheels, usually it has a spare wheel behind the cab, unless it has a KUNG module fitted like the one here, in this case the spare tyre usually can be found on the rear of the KUNG module.

KFLIsUMhamyMhMagkUZq.description: The T-80UE-1 is an upgraded T-80U. It is a T-80UD turret on a T-80BV hull, upgrades include a Belorussian PLISSA thermal sight to replace the older night sight, this can be noted by the different shape of the sight and also the lack of an IR searchlight or PL-1 pulse beamer. A new fire control system, and the ability to fire the 9K119 Refleks GLATGM. Apparently production was expensive and only about a battalion of tanks were delivered, so around 30-40.
KFLIsUMhamyMhMagkUZq.name: T-80UE-1

recognising_features.t80ue1_fiqo3d8encyk1ta8fwz1.jpg: The main recognising feature of the T-80UE-1 is the PLISSA sight and the DVE-BS wind sensor, the wind sensor is the same seen on other Russian tanks with modernised fire control systems, it is at the rear of the turret and is the prominent mast. The PLISSA sight is much taller than the standard T-80U night sight, it has a hinge on the right side of the sight door. The Buran-PA night sight from the T-80U is much smaller, its housing is a small square.
recognising_features.t80ue1_xywisr5hc7ouzm7z7h6t.jpg: Another feature is the lack of IR searchlight which sets it apart from the T-80U, instead the area where it once was is filled with Kontakt-5.

KFmns_boDah4mHW3az3f.description: The BMD-4M is the latest design of the BMD series, it is extremely light to be air portable, although one of the most heavily armed in its class, it is equipped with the weapons module from the BMP-3. It is incorporated into the VDV companies for fire support and to also carry dismounts.
KFmns_boDah4mHW3az3f.name: BMD-4M

recognising_features.bmd4m_08j553zwbdxatvu9z8bo.jpg: The rear is different to other BMD’s as they slope down, whereas the BMD-4M is flat at the rear with a small slope in the centre. There are 2 water jets at the rear, very low both next to the tracks.
recognising_features.bmd4m_fy90w6cbc9jqjp4nr69q.jpg: The BMD-4M has a small turret, similar to the BMP-3. It has the commanders primary sight on the left side of the turret, with the gunners primary sight on the right. The front of the turret is sloped with 3 SGD’s either side of the MA.
recognising_features.bmd4m_zud7m4ymw25ooosiwrnf.jpg: The Hull looks similar to a downsized BMP-3, It is boat-shaped with a heavily sloped upper glacis plate. The driver has 3 periscopes and in typical BMD fashion 2 hatches either side of the driver for the dismounts with a single periscope each. The exhaust is a rectangular slit on the right hand side. The track is supported by 2 top rollers with 5 equally spaced road wheels.

KKyNVT3IUI8STp6jJpRi.description: The Rooikat (Afrikaans for Caracal) 1C is a South African armoured car, it was designed to replace the Eland-90. The first SADF Rooikat squadron was delivered to 1 SSB (Special Service Battalion) in August 1989. The Rooikat 1C at the present is mainly in storage, with the Rooikat 1D being the latest version in active service. The Rooikat is perfect for the biome it operates in, the Southern African battlespace is an unforgiving environment, and in terms of armoured warfare, mobility is the key there, hence why the Rooikat is focused on mobility. The vehicle can outmanoeuvre tanks and destroy them in these conditions, where armoured engagements are generally at close range. Credit to Dr Dewald Venter, his books and publications on the Rooikat and other SANDF vehicles have helped this entry massively.
KKyNVT3IUI8STp6jJpRi.name: Rooikat 1C

recognising_features.rooikat1c_ique6mtiuu0y3d9923ay.jpg: The Rooikat 1C differs from the Rooikat 1D by the lack of a commanders panoramic sight and also it's pintle mounted MG4 machine gun, for a full recognition guide on the Rooikat, see Rooikat 1D.

Kz4L5mw7ICyP8EJBZztF.description: The Mi-28N Havoc is an attack-helicopter designed and built by the Russian company Mil. It is primarily a tank killer, in contrast to the Mi-24 Hind that can also be used as troop transport. The original Mi-28 was produced in 1982, with the 28N variant being released in 2009. The Havoc saw service in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Kz4L5mw7ICyP8EJBZztF.name: Mi-28N

recognising_features.mi28n_oa6kxr5ccts7d6v9qvfw.jpg: The Mi-28N Havoc has a long and thin fuselage with a single rotor. The rudder is angled slightly rearwards and has a horizonal stabiliser at the top. The tail rotor consists of two double blades. There are two wheels beneath the fuselage and a single wheel under the rudder.
recognising_features.mi28n_s0ewbklobq64qv4dahnn.jpg: The double cockpit has angular windows, with one pilot sitting above the other. The air intakes are on the side of the fuselage, with the external engines behind them. It has short winglets, that have two pylons (hard points) each.
recognising_features.mi28n_xczt30ak21iycm30wmht.jpg: At the nose of the helicopter is a cluster of sensors, including an obvious round 'nose' on the front. There is a flat, clyindrical radar at the base of the cluster. Beneath the sensors sits the 2A42 30mm autocannon fixted to an external mount.

KzuPgTwGHqawkdNmTFZC.description: The T-72B3 Obr.2016 is the latest iteration of the T-72 family, it includes upgrades to the ERA (4S22 ERA), a new powerpack, new FCS to name a few. You may see photos of some T-72B3’s with a commanders independent sight fitted, this is incorrectly stated to be a T-72B3 Obr.2016, it is a T-72B3 Obr.2014 made for the Tank Biathlon.
KzuPgTwGHqawkdNmTFZC.name: T-72B3 Obr.2016

recognising_features.t72b3obr.2016_03ivi4aq0juc1zgnu7jl.jpg: Here is a standard T-72B3 Obr.2016, you will notice the lack of the UBH urban survival armour down the sides.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2016_j9j6gaxf9wvlez7gdeut.jpg: Thermal view of the T-72B3 Obr.2016, you can see the difference in visual heat displayed due to the new side skirts, in a hull down position it would be quite difficult to PID.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2016_ukfokeie1yygfqzrtak5.jpg: The T-72B3 Obr.2016 is the latest iteration of the T-72 family, it has many upgrades, mostly internal. The recognising upgrades is the new 4S22 armour package on the turret sides, you will see the ‘soft ERA’ packages fitted down the hull sides this is part of the 2S24 UBH urban survival package, which isn’t fitted to all variants. Also the addition of bar armour at the rear.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2016_xi4xtrrhpvhsgqnpejiw.jpg: There is also additional 4S22 ERA on the turret sides seen here, as well as the bar armour addition at the rear of the turret. The main differences between this and the original T-72B3 is the relikt armour package.

LjLC7VPVBa0rIT0P-Yj0.description: The T-62M is an extensive modification of the T-62, it has the new Volna FCS, BDD Appliqué armour system, KTD-2 LRF, new TShSM-41U gunners sight, 1K13 sight for the use of the 9K116-2 Sheksna GLATGM, BV-62 Ballistic Computer and a newer engine.
LjLC7VPVBa0rIT0P-Yj0.name: T-62M

recognising_features.t62m_j79ukiyjicwb1srdxrwu.jpg: Turret, new gunners sight, prominent box on LHS, KTD-2 LRF fitted above the gun, BDD Appliqué armour fitted to the turret cheeks. Hull, Appliqué armour on the front glacis plate along with more armour on the lower glacis plate

LknZkawZnVNaGT9mlvXa.description: The 9P149 Shturm-S NATO RN:AT-6 Spiral is a radio guided ATGM mounted on the MTLB hull, it is the same missile launched by the MI-24 Hind, it was originally developed to serve in Anti-Tank platoons that were based or would operate in boggy areas, due to the MTLB low ground pressure.
LknZkawZnVNaGT9mlvXa.name: 9P149 Shturm-S

recognising_features.9p149shturms_96u1d5vr4nzkdivv041h.jpg: The 9P149 Shturm-S barely changes the MTLB hull, the biggest recognising feature being the optical guidance tracker that replaces the 1 man MG turret. The launch tube is at the rear right, it folds down to load and also when its not in use, which can be very deceiving, so it is key to remember the optical guidance tracker, for more info on recog features see MTLB in APC section.
recognising_features.9p149shturms_c50pbx8qka67ftay0jlv.jpg: Here the photo shows the missile stowed away, another point to note is the lack of a second viewport for the commander.

M-tJ9bgsyZMa901xfJvH.description: The BREM-1 is a Soviet armoured recovery vehicle (ARV) based on the T-72, around 342 were produced, it was designed to supplement the T-64 and T-80 battalions as well, so an evident shortage of armoured recovery vehicles is a big problem in the Russian Ground Forces, solidified by the many tanks lost to being bogged in during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. There were also extremely low numbers seen in country. The vehicle is fitted with a 4.4m crane. It has a 19t capacity at 2m and 3t capacity at 4.4m. It is used to lift damaged or stuck vehicles. Also the crane can be used to lift vehicles for access and repair. It is worth noting that cranes of modern Western ARV’s can lift much more. The main winch has 25 t capacity, that can be increased to 100 t using snatch blocks. The cable is 200 m long. It can be also used for self-recovery. It can also tow armoured vehicles upto 50t.
M-tJ9bgsyZMa901xfJvH.name: BREM-1

recognising_features.brem1_03qbk6fhgd9aexrxmq1m.jpg: Upon closer inspection of the vehicle, you will notice the hull has much more of an upwards angle, you can see the 2 cupolas, the commanders being the one on the right, noted by the IR searchlight. You can also see the crane which almost looks like its cut into the side of the superstructure.
recognising_features.brem1_8o4k7zn76acgt4htte3b.jpg: The BREM-1 has a large box in the centre of the hull, this is for stowage of tools and equipment. The crane runs parallel to the hull alongside the left side when folded down, raising towards the rear. The commander and crane operator have 2 raised cupolas next to each other in the centre hull. The running gear remains the same as that of the T-72 that it is based on. Note that the BREM-1 is usually never fitted with side skirts.

MDv1r478HAjpxv9Qv45n.description: The ZIL-131 is a Soviet general-purpose military truck, this variant is the general 6x6 cargo truck, with other variants including tractor-trailers, fire engine, fuel truck, dump truck. The 6x6 version can have a variety of modules mounted to the rear, for example the TCV (troop carrying vehicle) module, the common Soviet KUNG modules and so on.
MDv1r478HAjpxv9Qv45n.name: ZiL-131

recognising_features.zil131_ptj0c4zv55v2g4oyz90t.jpg: ZIL-131 fire engines were the first on scene at the Chernobyl disaster, hence the large amount of them in the irradiated vehicle graveyard inside the exclusion zone, as of now most of them were buried due to being some of the most heavily contaminated vehicles of the whole disaster.
recognising_features.zil131_tiwdaixqzu0rbe7i7o7l.jpg: The ZIL-131 has a typical soviet style T-shape truck cab, there are 2 large front windows with a pane down the centre, there are 3 orange tinted lights on the cab roof. There is a searchlight next to the drivers side mirror, just forward of this are 4 vents to assist with engine cooling. The front of the cab has ЗИЛ(ZIL) written above the grille, the grille is made up of 5x vertical cut outs on either side with the radiator visible behind them, underneath are 2x horizontal cut outs. The headlights are mounted on the front of the mudguards and consist of a headlight and indicator cluster per side, with a protective cage in front. The fuel tank is just behind the cab, there are 6 roadwheels altogether with 2 at the front and 4 at the rear.

MMh_BVE4UWkB8Y0dbRCq.name: 9T234-2
MMh_BVE4UWkB8Y0dbRCq.description: The 9T234-2 Transporter loader is a part of the BM-30 Smerch family, its role is to transport and load missiles for the launchers, it is based on the same MAZ-543M or MAZ-79111 8x8 truck as the launcher, it has a capacity of 12 missiles, the same as the launcher, so it can load 1 launcher system.

recognising_features.9t2342_j2u6wzzsm7lxsx1bphmx.jpg: The front of the truck is easily recognisable with its distinctive layout, with 2 separate cabs and a flat part between them, whereas the BM-30 Smerch itself has a single cab on the left hand side. Behind the cab is a raised structure and the crane for loading the missiles, the rear is a long flatbed with a large overhang at the rear, there is no obvious launch unit.
recognising_features.9t2342_uyaiq3c5bm4pm5vtqvy8.jpg: When loading the sides are lowered and the crane is raised, as seen here.

Ng7eNUYX2ezAr4pKTOkC.description: The T-64B is an extensive modification of the T-64A, including redesigned armour, a new 1A33 FCS, the ability to fire the 9K112 Kobra(AT-8 Songster) GLATGM and Stabilisation upgrades to name a few, this upgrade brought it in line with the newer tanks in service like the T-72 and T-80, the T-64BV was fitted with Kontakt-1 ERA on the hull and turret, it is still in service today, mainly with the Ukrainian Land Forces. The T-64BV is still produced to this day in Ukraine.
Ng7eNUYX2ezAr4pKTOkC.name: T-64BV

recognising_features.t64bv_ow484gj8bylwgv9k8yca.jpg: For comparison this is a T-72AV, you can see that the ERA is fitted in the clamshell design I mentioned but in a one brick row style instead of 2 brick rows like on the T-64BV
recognising_features.t64bv_q5suz5u49zmbwyv072g8.jpg: Turret, Kontakt-1 fitted liberally around the turret. Fitted in a clamshell design with a double row of bricks, rather than a single row that you’ll see on other T-Series, the searchlight remains on the left side of the gun, with 2 SGD banks of 4 on the rear left of the turret.
recognising_features.t64bv_v0ij68aoyejjm5mkacbo.jpg: Along the hull there is again Kontakt-1 placed liberally across the front glacis plate, with a 1 brick row along the upper lower glacis, the hull also contain ERA bricks along the sides approximately 3/4 the way down.

NqMwspM2gLjZEPOGeckd.description: The T-90A is an extensive modification and modernisation of the T-72B, including a brand new welded turret, new engine, new FCS, new armour layout and so on. It shares features with the T-80U, it also has the Shtora ECM to disrupt ATGM guidance. It was until the T-14, Russia’s most modern tank series.
NqMwspM2gLjZEPOGeckd.name: T-90A

recognising_features.t90a_592cckpd00a7hmvcmzzw.jpg: When the Shtora-1 is switched on, it gives a prominent red glow from each box. Due to these being IR these are easily sighted through standard issue NVG’s or any IR night sight.
recognising_features.t90a_5rwuourduth5k4sg0w0c.jpg: Here is a rare photo of a turret of a T-90A with no ERA, you can see the sharpness of the design, the turret is now welded giving it a much more western look, some early production T-90’s have older cast turrets. This shows the quality of Russian tank storage, when the high numbers of Russian tanks are pushed as a means of scaremongering, this is actually the tanks that make up those numbers.
recognising_features.t90a_7im4cxcx4jz4tiwj8pko.jpg: The T-90A is basically a hybrid between the T-72B(Hull) and T-80U (Turret), recognising features for the turret is the new layout of Kontakt-5 which has no gaps in between the ERA mounts, the Shtora-1 APS fitted to the turret front, commonly known as the ‘eyes’. The hull remains visually similar to a T-72BA with the Kontakt-5 blocks on the front glacis plate, along with the 3 armour plates on the front of the hull sides.
recognising_features.t90a_crj0jw1ndgbfhe0lwwy3.jpg: This photo shows a T-90A in production before the composite armour is added to the turret front.
recognising_features.t90a_h8shwfg68l7ps5p40krs.jpg: This closeup shows the layout, you can see the laser warning sensors above the gun, the new gunners night sight and the meteorological sensor indicating this is a tank with a modern FCS. You can see that it has SGD’s in 2 banks on either side of the turret
recognising_features.t90a_xd71h6jy7rnmsgt3b68c.jpg: You will see here what it looks like when the shtora-1 APS system is switched on, it’s a very distinctive red glow.

O90YBx_U1VoUgOEgE6ZQ.description: The 2S4 Tyulpan is a self-propelled 240mm mortar system. It is the largest calibre mortar in use worldwide. Mounted on a GM-123 chassis, the mortar barrel is loaded and then elevated into position. Due to the complex firing sequence it has a slow rate of fire, one round per minute. It has a range of 10km for standard ammunition and 20km for rocket assisted mortars.
O90YBx_U1VoUgOEgE6ZQ.name: 2S4 Tyulpan

recognising_features.2s4tyulpan_hqzy61eksar4qpq88eah.jpg: The GM-123 chassis the mortar is mounted on has 6 road whees in a 1-2-3-4-56 configuration. The final drive is at the front. The mortar is easily distinguishable, as well as the large, square base-plate at the rear of the vehicle.
recognising_features.2s4tyulpan_xc8r1o82o3sdvsc20nag.jpg: 2S4 in Ukraine (2022), note the bar armour cages on top of the turrets to defend occupants from RPG attack.
recognising_features.2s4tyulpan_zkw3on9f2lcj1ucokgk6.jpg: This image shows the M240 mortar in the deployed position.

OJfLsuRBpTFy-VISHzC4.name: MT-LB SPAAG
OJfLsuRBpTFy-VISHzC4.description: With the collapse of the USSR, the breakaway region in Moldova known as Transnistria was left with large stocks from the 14th Guards Army who were based there as well as in Ukraine and Moldova, this left Transnistria with many unusual, specialised and rare vehicles, whilst leaving them with no IFV's,SPG's or SPAAG's of their own, they ended up with specialised engineering vehicles found in few countries arsenals across the world, this has led to some interesting modifications to fill the lack of APC's and SPAAG's. This modification is both of Russian and Transnistrian design, the Operational Group of Russian Forces (OGRF) is the Russian peacekeeping unit based in Cobasna, unrecognised Transnistria, since the Ukrainian banning of Russian arms movements through its country in 2014, the OGRF is left with an old mix of out of service equipment unlike the rest of the Russian Armed Forces for example BTR-60's, BRDM-2's, so modifications like these are commonplace nowadays. The modification itself is an MTLB with a modified BTR-70 turret on a tower, it was confirmed in an interview with an OGRF officer that it is for air defence. It is likely that due to the block on weapons, Transnistria and the OGRF will continue to display interesting modifications unlike any other country in Europe.

recognising_features.mtlbspaag_9zb5brh9lic0dwbavn1h.jpg: What's interesting is that the commanders PKTturret remains, it seems the vehicle would be much more suited for fire support against ground vehicles.
recognising_features.mtlbspaag_my7g3cp9s49gz5g5jm32.jpg: The main feature of this vehicle is the large tower for the BTR-70 turret, the turret has been modified and has twin 12.7mm NSVT's. Although the vehicle has no obvious anti-air or night sight, so it could only be used for low, close range helicopter engagements.
recognising_features.mtlbspaag_t22xcfscc4ulsth394my.jpg: This angle shows the tall height of the turret fitted atop the tower, the hydraulic dozer blade at the rear of the vehicle was retained, meaning that the vehicle can still be used for the multi-purpose roles it was originally designed for.
recognising_features.mtlbspaag_tofi16wpp60zg3s52n0h.jpg: Seen here is the turret in a workshop, it shows the similarities between this and a BTR-70 turret.

OMDh5g-bFGMvyVANCDJG.description: The 2S25 Sprut-SD(Kraken/Squid) is a fire support/tank destroyer made for the VDV, it gives the lightly armoured/armed VDV air assault divisions a potent, mobile tank destroyer, whilst still being air-portable and droppable as well as being amphibious. Only around 24 of these vehicles were produced, supplying 3 Squadrons of 8 vehicles.
OMDh5g-bFGMvyVANCDJG.name: 2S25 Sprut-SD

recognising_features.2s25sprutsd_5grm4nno8s0svgf4pcza.jpg: For an in-depth analysis on the Hull, see BMD-3/4. The hull is very similar aside from 2 extra roadwheels and the length addition. The rear of the turret has 2 banks of 3 SGD’s, the centre turret rear has the ejection port for the 125mm spent ammunition.
recognising_features.2s25sprutsd_cocj6gsb17jtepwh82ib.jpg: The turret is large and placed on the forward centre of the hull. The turret has large sloping cheeks with a mantle less gun. The gunners sighting systems are on the left side of the turret, the commander's primary sight is on the right, there is a small IR searchlight on the right side of the gun, the 2S25 does not have a TI capability.

OMmBw-gV0_VuhNg--3Mu.description: The BREM-L is a light armoured recovery vehicle based on the BMP-3, it is intended to replace the BMP-1 based BREM-2, although this process is slow. It is comparable in the west to the FV513 Warrior AR&RV, the recovery equipment is a hydraulic crane with 11t lift capability, as well as winches which can straight pull a weight of 40t.
OMmBw-gV0_VuhNg--3Mu.name: BREM-L

recognising_features.breml_0j8ea4f630d85p3k06z1.jpg: The BREM-L is quite distinctive, the commander has a large cylindrical raised cupola in the centre, offset to the right, the driver remains in the same place as on the BMP-3. To the left off the drivers position is a large cylinder which is the base mount for the crane, the crane runs down the right side of the vehicle when stowed. The front of the vehicle is fitted with a dozer blade.
recognising_features.breml_2jtl65449mf9w0zjt6s2.jpg: The BREM-L from the side has some noticeable features; it has a tray behind the commander for stowage of spare parts and tools. You can see how the crane runs across the vehicle at an angle, from front left to rear right. The hull remains the same as the BMP-3, with the exhaust at the rear right, the rectangular slit. The roadwheels are also in the same format with prominent gaps between the 1st,2nd,3rd and also 5th and 6th.

OUQgnQeN6lzXSDjiw2iJ.description: The RKhM-4-01 is a Russian radiation and chemical reconnaissance platform based on the BTR-80, it has a variety of sensors for both testing, detecting and finding chemical and nuclear agents. These are mainly internal, although there are some features outside to help identify it. As well as chemical and nuclear recce, it can also conduct weather sampling, a motor rifle brigade will usually have a company equipped with this kind of platform, usually RKhM-4 or RKhM-6, although there are separate NBC/CBRN protection brigades.
OUQgnQeN6lzXSDjiw2iJ.name: RKhM-4-01

recognising_features.rkhm401_9kirl3eqiugg5pgwo63h.jpg: The RKhM-4-01 is easily confused as a standard BTR-80, the key differences are the sensors, the first one being behind the headlight, it is a fixed mount going upwards, the second sensor on the rear right of the turret, next to the smoke grenade dischargers, the final prominent feature is at the rear, behind the engine decks, below this are yellow markers.
recognising_features.rkhm401_i0t9ie79fv2tgvvfga60.jpg: Seen here are the yellow markers, they are to place in positions that a chemical has been detected in.

OxKvqTA0xeQOi1Qn7rxw.description: The BTR-3U is a Ukrainian self-produced IFV, built for the export market but also in Ukrainian service. It is based on the BTR-80 but built from scratch, rather than being an upgraded hull of an older BTR. The turret system is modular and can be switched.
OxKvqTA0xeQOi1Qn7rxw.name: BTR-3U

recognising_features.btr3u_1hk7hkeqxew8631n4u29.jpg: The BTR-3U is different to the Russian BTR series, although some similarities remain. The Shkval turret turret package is distinctive, the 30mm has a rail system on the outside, either side of the main gun are 2 banks of 3 SGD’s. On the left of the turret is a large box for the sighting system.
recognising_features.btr3u_7ga5pn5wiob5qt1uhx8j.jpg: The right side of the turret has 2 mounts for ATGM’s, these are usually Ukrainian self-produced ‘Barrier’ ATGM’s. The hull changes are plentiful with a completely new superstructure, you can see it is raised and is taller than a standard Russian BTR, with a prominent circular base for the turret.
recognising_features.btr3u_8k0pnhqjshgelm90kgml.jpg: The BTR-3U rear is different to that of a Russian BTR, the exhaust is the black rectangular slit between the 2 tail lights, the water jet cover is at the bottom centre of the rear.
recognising_features.btr3u_at3u6advxu3hctszgme5.jpg: The frontal hull remains similar to a BTR-80 with the armoured windows, boat shaped frontal hull. The sides change with a lack of firing ports covering the whole side like on BTR-80, addition of grab handles, there are also 2 triangle footholds with squared off ends to aid mounting the vehicle.

PAMSUQ-6PiIGjrA_Nf_B.description: The T-72BM2 'Sling' is a Belorussian modification of the T-72B, designed and trialled by the Belorussian 140th Repair Plant. It's upgrades include a Sosna-U sight, a UBH sideskirt and bar armour kit and an ERA package, the ERA looks exactly like Relikt, although this is not confirmed so it could be an indigenous Belarussian design. The engine and transmission remains the same as the T-72B which is the V-12 V-84MS engine, so it is lacking in power compared to a T-72B3 or T90A. The T-72BM2 has been accepted for service, but it is currently unknown if the armed forces have received it yet (as of October 2022), so I hope you understand there aren't many images around yet, any new images will be added when they're available.
PAMSUQ-6PiIGjrA_Nf_B.name: T-72BM2

recognising_features.t72bm2_b8trsm44fn2ro5qri4cn.jpg: Rather than a single cluster of SGD's, the T-72BM2, just like the T-80BVM has 2 banks of 4 SGD's, as well as a small panel of 4 ERA blocks covering them. The large box cover for the Sosna-U sight is prominent on the left side of the turret, with the TPD-K1 sight in front of it, this is a big giveaway that it is a T-72, not a T-80. The TPD-K1 sight mentioned is commonly nicknamed 'doghouse' given its appearance.
recognising_features.t72bm2_e6tw6cbzovw59vxj60v9.jpg: The Relikt ERA gives the turret that prominent 'flying saucer' look, it is worth noting that Relikt reduces APFSDS penetration by up to 50%, as well as defeating tandem warheads; although it has been observed that tanks equipped with Relikt have succumbed to NLAW and FGM-148 Javelin ATGM's
recognising_features.t72bm2_qb687p5re8l9g43edy5c.jpg: The T-72BM2, given the Relikt and UBH package, can look extremely similar to the T-80BVM. The main recognising features to distinguish between the two are as follows. The tracks on the T-72BM2 are the old single pin design from the T-72B, whereas the T-80BVM has a modern dual pin track with track pads. The Relikt on the frontal glacis plate has 2 gaps for the towing eyes, on the T-80BVM there are no gaps and the Relikt spreads right across the frontal glacis plate. The singular drivers periscope, compared to the 3 drivers periscopes on the T-80 series is always a good giveaway. The exhaust is mounted on the left side, which is where you will receive a thermal signature through thermal sights.

PRq3PMpCm8P1egXcRyvc.description: The T-84 Oplot-M or T-84 BM  is a heavy modification of the T-80UD, with a completely new welded turret, the new turret is a completely new design with the autoloader at the rear of the turret, this mitigates the risk of a side hit detonating the ammunition. The new autoloader has blow-off panels to protect the crew from the blast. The armour package is highly enhanced with Nozh ERA and new composite armour on the welded turret, it also has a new 6TD opposed piston engine, making it one of the fastest tanks in the world.
PRq3PMpCm8P1egXcRyvc.name: T-84BM

recognising_features.t84bm_j32kwymc8n62knm6uv19.jpg: The rear of the vehicle remains very similar to the T-80UD, with the exhaust in the same place; a  noticeable feature is the addition of steps to mount the vehicle on the rear left. On the rear of the turret you can see the stowage boxes.
recognising_features.t84bm_kjnup8wx7vy782e5z0qr.jpg: The front hull has a much more flat appearance, this is due to the new ERA fitted, the lower glacis plate has rubber flaps. The sideskirts are shown on this photo showing the extra ERA that can be added to the sides of the vehicle.
recognising_features.t84bm_wu2he1qnyqzzcndte3kq.jpg: The T-84 Oplot-M has a completely new turret, it is welded giving it a more western look. It has Nozh ERA covering the frontal arc, on both sides it has Shtora-1 IRCM dazzlers, also known as eyes. Above the gun are the laser warning sensors, the gunners sights are in the same location as other T-Series versions. The commander now has a large panoramic sight, it looks like a large bucket on top, there is also a meteorological sensor at the rear centre of the turret.
recognising_features.t84bm_xg50vz427foml2smxjku.jpg: This side view shows the length of the new turret, you can see the cutout for the SGD’s, towards the rear are stowage bins. The roadwheel layout remains the same as the T-80U which the tank is based on.

Qzdb4FQ3jbALZ-6c_Kpi.description: T-62MV is a further T-62 upgrade, it has all the upgrades of the T-62M minus the BDD appliqué kit, that is now replaced with Kontakt-1 ERA. Kontakt-1 is fitted down the sides of the hull, the front glacis plate and on the turret front, this gives it much better performance against chemical energy munitions. V standing for "Vzryvnoi"-Explosive.
Qzdb4FQ3jbALZ-6c_Kpi.name: T-62MV

recognising_features.t62mv_955cklqbr9ltdjbw9x6d.jpg: Turret, new gunners sight, prominent box on LHS, KTD-2 LRF fitted above the gun, BDD Appliqué armour fitted to the turret cheeks. Hull, Appliqué armour on the front glacis plate along with more armour on the lower glacis plate
recognising_features.t62mv_c6rdfvnnfqtf13wd2fjt.jpg: The Turret fitting has the typical ‘clamshell’ layout, along the front of the vehicle it covers the front glacis apart from the headlight fitting, it also has bricks down the sides
recognising_features.t62mv_x52apgz4eblg28xsajr8.jpg: The fittings for the ERA, that give them that distinctive clamshell appearance

RUBq-kF0ilNSeXCMBvZL.description: The Leopard 2PL is a modernised Leopard 2A4 in partnership with Rheinmetall and the Polska Grupa Zbrojeniowa (Polish Armaments Group), upgrades include. Commanders and Gunners sights, Additional turret armour, new turret stowage, and new gun stabilisation to name a few. Anti-splinter liners have been installed inside the tank to protect the crew inside the vehicle against shrapnel in the event of a puncture or hit.
RUBq-kF0ilNSeXCMBvZL.name: Leopard 2PL

recognising_features.leopard2pl_1hwgcbg5zodcnrphhlkp.jpg: The biggest differences with the Leopard 2PL are with the turret, you will see the turret appears much wider and much more armoured due to the armour package fitted; it could be easily confused with the Leclerc due to the placement of the gunners sight and armour layout.
recognising_features.leopard2pl_b0jnjn6dr2gcee4lrait.jpg: The gunners sight has a prominent cutout in the armour, behind that as with all leopards is the commanders panoramic sight, the gun mantlet and length of the turret give the appearance that the MA is much shorter than it actually is.
recognising_features.leopard2pl_kpybfgkmoy22hr5koegh.jpg: The SGD’s are placed at the rear of the turret in a gap, you will find it hard to see these when the turret is traversed forward, this will be pertinent when looking at the side of the vehicle.

RUJNywhYQo1NkCR2mLn9.description: The ZSL-10 is the APC variant of the Type-08 family of AFV's, it can carry more dismounts but possesses less firepower than its ZBL-08 IFV relative. This vehicle family forms the backbone of the Chinese medium manoeuvre brigade vehicles, the vehicle is fully amphibious and is in service with both the PLA Ground Forces and PLA Naval Marine Corps. Not many images are available of the ZSL-10.
RUJNywhYQo1NkCR2mLn9.name: ZSL-10

recognising_features.zsl10_oonjmwftcpa55mwxtzul.jpg: The ZSL-10 has the typical characteristics of the Type-08 family, though due to it being an APC it lacks the larger turret of the IFV variant and has a raised superstructure to accomodate more troops and equipment, it has a small single man open top 12.7mm QJC-88 turret in the centre of the raised superstructure. The small turret has plastic view points around it, there are now 2 periscopes on the side of the hull, one just below where the superstructure begins to slope upwards and one at the rear below the 2 rows of 3x SGD's, which are on either side.

R_Ynw6TZY_erze-UvKY2.description:
The T-14 Armata (Object 148) is a Russian MBT designed in 2014, it comes after the cancellation of the Object 195 and Object 187. The tank was first seen publicly in March 2015, under wraps on a train. The tank is unusual in its crew layout, with the crew in an armoured capsule in the hull, resulting in an unmanned turret. The tank is still in trials and not yet accepted in to service for the Russian Ground Forces, feedback from the SMO in August 2022 resulted in some requests for the T-14
-Increased range for active protection system detection of threat, also increased range for hard kill.
-Improved protection against RPG’s.
-Enhanced electronic protection against electromagnetic interference.
-New system for remote detonation of land mines.
A system like the latter is fitted to the BMR-3M, so it is likely this will be used instead of procuring a new system, it is unknown if these upgrades have been fitted yet.
R_Ynw6TZY_erze-UvKY2.name: T-14

recognising_features.t14_4tk5poq0xullnd36vwkn.jpg: As you can see on this one, the ERA is more rectangular rather than square, as well as having new roadwheels with indentations. It is likely we’ll see more modifications as the tank gets closer to serial production.
recognising_features.t14_kvlxb7b981howj3t3czm.jpg: The gun has no obvious fume extractor, due to of course not needing one as there is no turret crew, it has thermal sleeves throughout and a muzzle reference system sensor at the tip, therefore indicating a modern FCS.
recognising_features.t14_nagphmlg28upljwyg293.jpg: The T-14 is unlike other Russian serial production tanks, so it’s relatively easy to recognise compared to those. It is distinctive with its large hull, which is covered in ERA across the front, you can make out the lines between the blocks if you zoom in. The 2 headlights are LED, and the driver has a camera on the centre of the upper frontal plate. The 3 crew are situated just in front of the turret, hence the abundance of periscopes and the 3 hatches.
recognising_features.t14_rnkd67xjjrnltogv79lz.jpg: The tracks are of a modern, dual pin design nature. There are tiles of Malachit ERA down the hull sides, with rubber flaps underneath them, the ERA ends at the rear quarter for bar armour, the exhausts are on both sides (indicating twin-turbo) and are similar to the T-72B3 Obr.2016 with the slanted down exhaust. There are 7 equally spaced roadwheels.
recognising_features.t14_u8r3xenwai9zbwaq8f0k.jpg: Moving onto the turret, the T-14 has a large recess for the gunners sight, to the lower right of that are launchers for the Afganit hard kill APS, just above those are sensors for the system, and behind those in the circular pods are the NII Stali upper hemisphere protection complex, which are 2x traversable mounts with 12x cartridges for the APS. The mast on the turret is the FCS meteorological sensor, behind that towards the rear of the turret is the commanders panoramic sight and remote KORD machine gun.
recognising_features.t14_y85aog5h0b8iaou7r1ex.jpg: So far there are 2 versions of the T-14, the one shown here is the earlier model with the older generation Malachit ERA on the hull sides, the next image shows the latest model (2022).

S3YjS2-udc1YyNu43wZq.description: In line with most Chinese AFV platforms, there is typically a dedicated fire support version posessing a 105mm gun, the gun is a modified copy of the 105mm Royal Ordnance L7. The vehicle is designed to provide fire support for infantry against heavier armoured targets, although it does not possess an anti-armour capability to counter NATO MBT's frontally. The ZTL-11 is contained in medium CA brigades, the medium battalions are usually three infantry companies equipped with ZBL-08/ZSL-10 IFV/APC's and 1 Assault Gun Company with 14 ZTL-11's as well as other typical fire support weapons.
S3YjS2-udc1YyNu43wZq.name: ZTL-11

recognising_features.ztl11_h650y5xjlkkl977t3o9m.jpg: Looking at the rear of the turret, there is a bustle rack for crew stowage, as well as a small pole with a wider cylinder at the top,I believe this to be the meteorological sensor for the fire control system. At the rear of the hull there is no door on this version, instead it is used to stow CES items like tools, tow ropes and so on, the 2x propellors remain giving the vehicle an amphibious capability.
recognising_features.ztl11_wi94830rjzymza787tu4.jpg: The previously mentioned engine movement shows that the engine is rear mounted, due to a lack of neccessity for a dismount compartment. The small exhaust is now on the left hand side above a prominent grille. The turret roof has a prominent cut out portion to accomodate the gunners sight, which is a low profile rectangle with a small searchlight by its side. There is a single antennae just behind the gunners hatch.
recognising_features.ztl11_ygn8cm0lwxkkdu27hpjv.jpg: The ZTL-11 is part of the Type-08 family of AFV's, therefore the hull remains generally the same as the ZBL-08, so for full recognising features on the hull, please see the ZBL-08 entry, this entry will specifically be for the ZTL-11 modifications. So to begin, the turret is the most obvious change, it is much larger to accomodate the 105mm MA, it is also centrally mounted. The front turret cheeks have 2 banks of 6x SGD's, mounted with a row of 4 and then 2 on top, the main gun has a fume extractor approximately a quarter of the way down the barrel. You may notice that the engine is now mounted at the rear.

S565z4Gh84td3rAMNMbS.description: The Merkava 3D Baz Dor Dalet is the latest generation upgrade of the Merkava 3, it provides composite armour on the turret sides, an upgraded FCS (Fire Control System) called Baz (Falcon), the Baz FCS provides the commander with a panoramic sight, allowing for hunter killer capability. It also gives an auto track feature for the gunner, both commander and gunner have thermal imaging with this upgrade. The Merkava 3D Dor Dalet is commonly incorrectly called the 'Merkava 3 Baz', this is wrong. The term Baz is simply referring to the FCS, not the whole upgrade package. The Baz is being fitted to the earlier gen Merkava 3's. The Merkava series is well known for being able to transport infantry in it's rear compartment, though this is rarely used and instead the space is used for more ammo, as well as sometimes for casualty evacuation of infantry/other tank crews.
S565z4Gh84td3rAMNMbS.name: Merkava 3D Baz

recognising_features.merkava3dbaz_2r9utnbcjuef60k0maso.jpg: The Merkava's hull has the engine at the front, so the exhaust is on the front right, it's a large black rectangle. The sideskirts are wavy across the bottom, with a footstep on the front sideskirt. The front 4 roadwheels are equally spaced, with the 5 and 6th having prominent gaps between them. The final drive is of course at the front of the vehicle, with the idler at the rear.
recognising_features.merkava3dbaz_2tdhvd6d0p1gbxk4zkae.jpg: A good recognising feature for the 3D Baz Dor Dalet is the amount of machine guns on top of the turret, at the front is an M2 .50 which is mounted above the main gun and is slaved to the main gun, the commander and loader have an FN-MAG 7.62mm MG each. The main gun is an Israeli produced Rh120 L/44 cannon, similar to that of the Leopard 2 and M1A1/2 Abrams, the recognising feature for that is the large bulbous fume extractor.
recognising_features.merkava3dbaz_d2algjqja2qdc83v5cln.jpg: The rear of the turret has a large bustle for stowage of equipment, usually callsigns/affiliation to tank company are placed on them like you can see here, below the rack are chains to aid in pre-detonation of RPG's.
recognising_features.merkava3dbaz_mph5wmzzw6ts1ic609ug.jpg: The frontal hull is heavily sloped, with the driver sitting off to the left of the vehicle just in front of the turret, he has 3 periscopes. Moving on to the turret, the 3D Baz Dor Dalet has the extra side turret armour when compared to prior Mark 3's, this can be seen by the sheer width of the already large turret. The gunner has a prominent cut-out for his sight, in front of that is one of the banks for the SGD's, they are rectangular in shape and on either side of the turret, with the bank on the left side of the turret being positioned higher.

S5R2oHqbnt-NOH3hUMi4.description: The PLL-09 is the SPG of the Type-08 family, primarily used in artillery units that support the PLAGF's Medium Combined Arms Manoeuvre Brigades, it contains a modified 122mm gun based on the Soviet D-30. The gun is fully stabilised and can fire laser guided munitions, the fire control system is computerised and can provide both indirect and direct fire to support the infantry.
S5R2oHqbnt-NOH3hUMi4.name: PLL-09

recognising_features.pll09_6iez2zix0dqcox1ixkgf.jpg: As always with the Type-08 family, the hull remains the same throughout apart from slight structural differences between models. This variant has a large turret at the rear of the hull, the turret has a slope upwards with the main gun in the centre, the gun has a recoil system enclosed above it, as well as a large box above the recoil system. The turret features 2 banks of 6 SGD's on either side of the turret, the hull sides just below the turret contain stowage points for CES, mainly tow ropes  etc.
recognising_features.pll09_7mbb7hwkby089bq7h0i9.jpg: The turret sides and rear have raised crosses on them, easily remembered for recognition as a black noughts and crosses board. The rear contains a single door for ammunition loading and has a foot step, the vehicle retains the propellors for its amphibious operations capability.
recognising_features.pll09_tnmwqcjvngmn6wwz7p9c.jpg: There is a large cutout on the right side of the vehicle for the exhaust, which is completely different to the other variants in the family, this exhaust is like a car one, basically a large backbox with an exit pipe facing upwards, the hull sides are smooth and contain no periscopes like other models.

SBSKJWb4LcNqST9Wd542.description: The 9K317 Buk-M2, NATO designation SA-17 'Grizzly', is an upgraded system to the Buk M1. The major improvements are the integral 9S36 fire control radar and the ability to engage with the more modern 9M317 surface to air missiles. The TELAR is upgraded to the 9A317 and the TEL is now the 9A310, the pair can carry a total of 12 missiles (4 on TELAR, 8 on TEL). The system now uses the 9S18M1 'Snow Drift' radar for target acquisition.
SBSKJWb4LcNqST9Wd542.name: 9K317 Buk-M2

recognising_features.9k317bukm2_2gluxb4vu73691hp8ipk.jpg: The key recognising feature is the new 9S36 radar, it is flatter than its predessesor (Fire Dome).
recognising_features.9k317bukm2_bai95ygfl8204glfpksn.jpg: The 9A310 TEL (identified by the crane) can be identified by the solid wheels and the 'arrow' framework on the launcher's sides point downwards.
recognising_features.9k317bukm2_c9hhyli2vezwvt79f6kw.jpg: The Buk-M2 is mounted on the same chassis as the M1, however the roadwheels are now solid steel (as opposed to the light weight spaced wheels on the M1).

SNuXMw1jPd49Iiqn5KlH.description: The R-330BMV Borisoglebsk-2 is a Russian electronic warfare system, it is used for deception and jamming, it can track and jam most radio systems (HF,VHF,UHF) both air and ground comms, with its wide frequency bandwidth, as well as a high probability of identifying radar emissions, it was used in Eastern Ukraine in 2015, in what could be assessed to be a field test. It was also used in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, 1 was destroyed and 2 captured.
SNuXMw1jPd49Iiqn5KlH.name: R-330BMV

recognising_features.r330bmv_57i9xus3jqmkst97etay.jpg:
On the right side, there are 2 long stowage boxes, there are some hatches towards the rear, the rest of this side remains the same. This one was captured by the Ukrainian 10th Mountain Assault Brigade; the current fate of the vehicle is unknown. 






(Almost definitely the CIA does not have this).
recognising_features.r330bmv_716q0ldrnrvbmg2un3eh.jpg: The R-330BMV is based on the MTLBu hull, the hull is tall with sloping on the sides, it has 2 visors for the driver and vehicle commander. It also has a boat-shaped hull, this is due to the amphibious capability. There is a large mast at the rear left, it has a very obscure mast, it has 6 vertically placed antennae coming off of the main mast, with a circular dish at the top. The large cage at the front is a protective and retaining cage for the mast.
recognising_features.r330bmv_8w59jh4ixdwa6932hiu6.jpg: Upon a closer look at the side, this time with the mast folded you can see what the vehicle looks like when not in use. There is a stowage box on the left side towards the front. There is a part of the hull at the front which is angled downwards, with what looks like an air grille above the final drive, although this is just a cover. There is a large gap between the tracks and hull, with no side skirts. The vehicle has 7 road wheels, all of which are equally spaced throughout.

SO5X0-jm9lrS-pzp8rhV.description: The T-62MV Obr.2022 is an upgrade of the T-62MV with the 1PN96MT-02 thermal imaging sight, which greatly enhances the capability of the tank other than this the tank remains generally the same.
SO5X0-jm9lrS-pzp8rhV.name: T-62MV Obr.2022

recognising_features.t62mvobr.2022_l6hoijbh2temc58akt0y.jpg: Similar to the T-62M Obr.2022 the large IR searchlight and KTD-02 laser rangefinder is omitted as the 1PN96MT-02 sight has its own LRF, the other recognising feature is the bar armour around the rear of the turret, other than this the tank remains the same as the T-62MV.

T2DAlRMHVjyZNleuu9PX.description: The Ural-VV is an up-armoured variant of the popular Ural-4320 truck, mainly used by Rosgvardia (Internal Troops).
T2DAlRMHVjyZNleuu9PX.name: Ural-VV

recognising_features.uralvv_0wfghwb4yyb41wa1ovvk.jpg: This Ural-VV belongs to Rosgvardia, as you can see from the paint scheme. The right side of the vehicle has a door leading to the dismount compartment, the door opens towards the rear of the vehicle. You can see hatches on top of the vehicle for small arms use.
recognising_features.uralvv_ij0aifney4urhps40t24.jpg: The Ural-VV is a large truck with a single superstructure, there's no gap between the cab and rear compartment. The front window is large and has no split in the centre, the bonnet is sloping with the wheel arches being on other side. There is a small grille in the centre, there are headlights mounted on the front of the mudguards. The side door is small and has a spare tyre just behind it. Towards the rear of the superstructure are 3x small square windows.
recognising_features.uralvv_zak5tu6s86i9pgvy97lx.jpg: Rear of the Ural-VV, there are steps folded away on the rear doors.

T3kWc4XPIx0qV1-eRwC6.description: The BTR-ZD is an air defence variant of the BTR-D, with a ZU-23-2 cannon and extra stowage for MANPADS, it typically carries troops specialised in air defence, the main gun can engage ground targets and is more commonly seen to be used in this role rather than it's main purpose of air defence.
T3kWc4XPIx0qV1-eRwC6.name: BTR-ZD Skrezhet

recognising_features.btrzdskrezhet_20038ktf44vosquauzx1.jpg: The BTR-ZD is a ZU-23-2 cannon mounted on top of a BTR-D, for BTR-D recognising features please visit that entry. The ZU-23-2 is mounted on top of the hull, it can either be mounted at the front or rear, the one shown here is on the front. The gun can be dismounted and placed on the ground for static use.
recognising_features.btrzdskrezhet_7h5uvxspzc76v3ejdm6e.jpg: As previously mentioned with gun placement, this one has the gun mounted at the rear of the hull.

T600bClVf5BsCka0cnQG.description: The Zoopark-1, developed by the former Soviet Union in the 1980s, is a counter-battery radar system that replaced the APK-1 Ris system. Mounted on an MTLB tracked chassis, it identifies enemy artillery positions, including mortars, howitzers, and rocket launchers. Deployed to Syria in 2016, this autonomous radar takes five minutes for setup. Capable of monitoring 12 targets concurrently, it detects 70 firing positions per minute.
T600bClVf5BsCka0cnQG.name: 1L259

recognising_features.1l259_930jg9z6tnuyt6oje8dl.jpg: The Zoopark-1 is easily recognisable by the large rectangular radar, it has cut outs in each corner giving it a rough octagonal shape. There is a beam return array forward of the radar. Radar aside, the Zoopark-1 is mounted on a standard MTLBu.
recognising_features.1l259_eiuj31rxtxwh18lm2eaz.jpg: In the radar down position the vehicle can be difficult to identify from the side, the radar sits to the rear.

TBYHED9Jm9PyHsV0fvcl.description:
The T-64B1M is a Ukrainian upgrade of the T-64B1, the main upgrade being the addition of Nozh ERA and a rear turret extension for stowage. There aren't many in service with the Ukrainian army but they have
seen action since 2014 and currently.
TBYHED9Jm9PyHsV0fvcl.name: T-64B1M

recognising_features.t64b1m_0gnq56nyje9uf8rrv78s.jpg: Here is a T-64B1M that shows the Nozh ERA has clearly resisted a hit from an ATGM.
recognising_features.t64b1m_ste18l9oy2njivd6rmjk.jpg: Here is a T-64B1M damaged and abandoned near Mariupol during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.t64b1m_tfc067ovudan4cyefclr.jpg:
You can also see in this photo the turret bustle rack
and stowage extension on the rear of the turret.
recognising_features.t64b1m_vl21tk5qu1j18vcuqr8r.jpg: The key differences here is the ERA on the turret, giving it a look similar to a turtle shell, the ERA has no gaps in between the blocks. The sideskirts now have ERA panels covering them.

TdiU7FLrS09WAaXlpzVn.name: ZBD-05
TdiU7FLrS09WAaXlpzVn.description: The Type 05/ZBD-05 is a Chinese IFV, predominantly for use by the PLANMC (People’s Liberation Army Navy Marine Corps). It has a heavy focus on ship-borne amphibious operations; it is statistically improved in every way when compared to the contemporary USMC AAV-7A1. It would appear that the creators of the Type-05 took a large amount of inspiration from the USMC’s EFV (Expeditionary Fighting Vehicle), which would have fulfilled the same capability role as the Type-05 does. It has 2 variants, the ZBD-05 which is this one, the IFV, then the Type-05 Assault Vehicle, which is also covered here. The key difference between the 2 vehicles are the turrets, the ZBD-05 having the Ukrainian 30mm Shkval module, with the ZTD-05 AV having an upgraded L7 105mm gun. An interesting feature of the ZBD-05 platform is that when in the water, the engine is able to generate 1475 horsepower as well as switching to land mode with only 550 horsepower.

recognising_features.zbd05_bhtr4ux8nasx1jglyczu.jpg: The view from the side really puts into perspective the length of this vehicle, the sides are flat, sometimes having a tow rope stowed along the side. At the rear is a stabilising plate mounted on hydraulic arms, although we cannot find a solid answer for what it is, we believe it is to do with the amphibious capability. The running gear consists of a final drive at the front, 3 top rollers, 6 road wheels with a very prominent gap between the 5th and 6th and the idler at the rear.
recognising_features.zbd05_m6tp9qug0yr6in2v0ext.jpg: The Type 05 IFV begins the step away of blatant unlicensed copies from China, although heavily inspired by the USMC EFV, it marks a step in the direction of ingenuity for the Chinese military industry. The hull is very long, almost looking completely like a boat with a turret on, especially when you can see the tracks like in this photo. The turret is a small 2 man turret towards the rear, with a slightly sloped front, with flat sides. The driver is seated on the front left, with a raised cupola. A great recognising feature with the Type 05 IFV is that PLANMC are vehicles are typically painted in a camouflage design with a heavy blue/light blue colouration, this will be a good recognising feature.
recognising_features.zbd05_zqywhtio4zv1v32ctduq.jpg: The front cheek welds slope off to the sides, with 2 banks of 4 SGD’s either side of the MA. The gunner has a large box sight in front of his hatch, with a searchlight on the left of it, the commander has a sighting system attached to his hatch. On the left side of the turret is a HJ-73C ATGM, which is a copy of the 9M14 Malyutka (AT-3 Sagger).

U0y7iVfR1rqlij7zFdbM.description: The T-72B1 Obr.1989 is a T-72B1 with Kontakt-5 fitted as part of the Obr.1989 package, it enhances protection. The difference with the standard T-72B is that the B1 retains the older TPN-3-49 sight from the T-72A, this is easily remembered by 'B has a sight door, B1 doesn't' as the B1 has 4 mounting screws, requiring the gunner to manually remove the sight cover from outside of the vehicle, it also means that the tank is unable to fire GLATGM. The T-72B1 Obr.1989 is overall a very rare tank, although learning the minute differences improves your skill and knowledge level on a wider scale.
U0y7iVfR1rqlij7zFdbM.name: T-72B1 Obr.1989

recognising_features.t72b1obr.1989_2s0kjgo2czkujujqlr6a.jpg: A destroyed T-72B1 Obr.1989 in Ukraine, it should be noted that this tank has had Kontakt-1 fitted on top of the Kontakt-5.
recognising_features.t72b1obr.1989_awx2l5n9j0h5l9r7rdod.jpg: As mentioned in the description, the biggest giveaway is the sight difference. On the left side of the turret, the box with the 4 screws is the TPN-3-49 sight, whereas the normal T-72B Obr.1989 has the 1K13 sight, with a sight door on a spring mount. The Luna IR searchlight is also a good recognising feature that this tank does not have modern TI sights, instead it has IR sights, giving it a much lower engagement and detection range in low light conditions.
recognising_features.t72b1obr.1989_slc3jqiwt061gicm8qhh.jpg: An Armenian T-72B1 Obr.1989, Armenia is the only known country outside of Russia to use this variant.

UOB9L6KXaFdS6RcsP17N.description: The BMP-2 is an upgrade of the BMP-1, it brings a new, larger 2 man turret with a new 30mm 2A42 Auto-cannon, newer 9M133 Kornet/9M113 ATGM, it removes 2 of the 4 hatches from the BMP-1. The BMP-2 forms the backbone of most Ex Soviet countries IFV capability, as well as a lot of other countries around the world.
UOB9L6KXaFdS6RcsP17N.name: BMP-2

recognising_features.bmp2_9iyacfh2z7x0ymekr7us.jpg: The main recognising features of the BMP-2 is the newer 2 man turret, it is much wider and larger than the BMP-1. The turret has a new 30mm 2A42 cannon, it is much longer and thinner than that of the 73mm, it has a rectangular muzzle brake.
recognising_features.bmp2_yyrt20nh7dv2u7pm42jx.jpg: The 9M113 launch tube is now fitted centrally on top of the turret, there are also SGD’s on either side of the turret in banks of 3. The hull remains the same aside from the 2 omitted dismount hatches, it now just has 2.

Vki2zE8s6USYoeGv4qBS.description: The Polonez is an indigenous Belarussian MLRS system, it has 8 launch tubes for 300mm rockets, it is claimed that each rocket can be targeted individually. The requisiton of these vehicles come as the Belarussian BM-21 (Grad) and BM-27 (Uragan) fleet is significantly ageing and is becoming harder to maintain, as mentioned in other Belarussian vehicle cards, this is a big shift for a state once fully dependant on Russia in terms of AFV's and arms. The system has been sold to Azerbaijan and saw service in the 2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war. The full missile salvo can be launched in 50 seconds and reloaded in 8 minutes. The vehicle platform is the MZKT-7930 heavy high mobility truck.
Vki2zE8s6USYoeGv4qBS.name: Polonez

recognising_features.polonez_2al9h5bv5gu24f6zxnas.jpg: The vehicles pushed into service with Belarus appear to be painted in this commonly seen with a dark green base camouflage pattern, with black and white overlay patterns.
recognising_features.polonez_5tgmwielqhroqey09zz9.jpg: The truck cab itself has 3 large front windows, each with a wiper. There is a small grille in the centre, there are light clusters either side at the front, typical with Russian and Former Soviet trucks, the truck has a large overhang, with the roadwheels set further back. There are 8 roadwheels, in between the 1st and 2nd roadwheel there is a ladder for mounting/dismounting. The missile rails are 7m long in 2 banks of 4, mounted side by side.

VuYsjm3coPL882y8zuac.description: The 9P157-2 Khrizantema NATO:AT-15 Springer is a Russian ATGM vehicle, based on the BMP-3 hull. It is both ACLOS/SACLOS guidance, ACLOS meaning that the system will track the missile to the target itself without the need for operator input. There is also a SACLOS system where the gunner can track the missile and provide input. It can supposedly engage 2 targets at once thanks to its detection radar.
VuYsjm3coPL882y8zuac.name: 9P157-2

recognising_features.9p1572_4dhszmqq7xsa1agt6jbh.jpg: The sight has doors to cover it, but the barrel shaped sight remains in place, so this is key for recognition of such a potent vehicle.
recognising_features.9p1572_v296uxhg01ru6w01dbsi.jpg: The 9M157-2 is mounted on the BMP-3 hull, the turret is removed in place for the ATGM mount, radar and sighting/guidance sight. The sighting system is on the front right. The rest of the hull remains the same, see BMP-3 in IFV section for and in depth hull recognition guide.
recognising_features.9p1572_wjo57tbxk299cgme7cwg.jpg: The 9P157-2 is notable for its ability for the radar and launcher to be stowed away, giving the appearance as shown here that it is just an APC, there is one way to note the differences, the sighting system remains in place.

W4OFC0_d4dTsP-1lA5l1.description: The 2A65, a late Cold War Soviet howitzer, began its development in 1976, aiming to replace the 152mm D-20, D-1, and ML-20. NATO initially dubbed it the M1987 before its true name, Msta-B, was identified. This towed howitzer variant is from the ordnance of the 2S19 Msta-S self-propelled model. It features a two-wheel split trail carriage, and its 152mm 47-caliber armament includes a double baffle muzzle brake and sliding breech block. Operated by an eight-member crew with a gun shield for protection, the 2A65 can fire up to 28.5 km with specialised ammunition at 7 rounds per minute. Its mobility requires a 6x6 5-ton truck, like the Ural-4320 or KamAZ-6530. Despite large-scale production, most 2A65s remained in storage post the Soviet Union's fall, with successor states as primary users.
W4OFC0_d4dTsP-1lA5l1.name: 2A65 Msta-B

recognising_features.2a65mstab_ofnw42xdy9bb089tdxgb.jpg: The Msta-B model features two wheels and bears a protective shield similar to other Soviet towed artillery equipment. It can be distinguished by its two wheels, which remain on the ground when deployed, unlike the four wheels on the Giatsint-B and the lifting mechanism of the D-30. Its recoil system includes two barrels positioned above the main gun, and its muzzle brake features three baffles. Additionally, its barrel length exceeds that of the D-20 and D-30, being identical to the gun used in the 2S19 and 2S33.
recognising_features.2a65mstab_yonb1ul1n6uvytitdixi.jpg: Msta-B in its towed position, note the split trails forming one to be hitched to this Ural 375D.

WL2LEJ6AGr9G6zDUilIX.description: The 9K37M1 Buk-M1 is a medium to long range surface to air missile, NATO designation SA-11 'Gadfly'. The system is upgraded from the 2K12 Kub family of SAMs. Unlike self-contained SAMs, the Buk-M1 requires an external 9S18 'Tube Arm' target acquisition radar before it can use its integral 9S35 'Fire Dome' tracking and engagement radar. The system consists of the 9A310 TELAR and 9A39 TEL. The TELAR carries 4 missiles ready to fire, the TEL carries 4 missiles ready to engage and 4 in storage - in place of the radar it has a crane to load itself or the TELAR. The TEL must connect to the TELARs 'Fire Dome' to engage.
WL2LEJ6AGr9G6zDUilIX.name: 9K37 Buk-M1

recognising_features.9k37bukm1_6uesa9oth0murd00gu58.jpg: The Buk M1's TEL (9A39) can be identified by the crane in place of the radar and by the fact that the 'arrows' on the sides of the launcher point upwards. The wheels on some older M1 variants have spaces in them to reduce weight.
recognising_features.9k37bukm1_9hbvowe1hmy1hwaeqgm2.jpg: The 9S35 'Fire Dome' radar is a unique looking radar which extends well over the chassis when traversed. Unlike most radars it is elongated, with a curved top and flat bottom. This radar is unique to the Buk M1 and is its key recognising feature.
recognising_features.9k37bukm1_ofbq1u6ors1y75p4frsg.jpg: The Buk M1 is mounted on the GM-569 chassis. It has 6 evenly spaced road wheels. The launcher has a flat profile and is as long as the chassis. The TELAR can carry up to 4 9M38 surface to air missiles. The 9S35 'Fire Dome' radar can be seen on the front of the launcher platform.
