WSFu16D4t2seUs0XVPcd.description: The Rooikat (Afrikaans for Caracal) 1D is the latest upgrade of the South African armoured recce car used by the SANDF. The 1D upgrades include upgrades to the powerpack for reliability, addition of a commanders panoramic sight and removal of the commanders machine gun. The Rooikat was designed with mobility at the forefront of its design philosophy. Credit to Dr Dewald Venter, his books and publications on the Rooikat and other SANDF vehicles have helped this entry massively.
WSFu16D4t2seUs0XVPcd.name: Rooikat 1D

recognising_features.rooikat1d_b51zqa587yep1y4x0kwq.jpg: The roadwheels are large, with an upside down triangle shape between the 1st and 2nd, 3rd and 4th roadwheels. The hull raises towards the rear to accommodate the power pack.
recognising_features.rooikat1d_fts0uy1q1acytyb95knd.jpg: There is a large stowage box at the rear of the turret. On the rear of the vehicle the exhaust is on the left hand side, this is where thermal signature will be visible.
recognising_features.rooikat1d_ia8i7wpz6vqer3abgukz.jpg: The turret has the smoke grenades mounted off to the rear sides of the turret.
recognising_features.rooikat1d_kakfnop4p5643bq7izw9.jpg: The turret is low profile and long, there is a rail on the commanders side next to the commander, on the turret sides are small brackets, I assume its for attaching equipment. The gunners sight is a rectangular shape in front of the commanders primary sight, it has a cover over it in this image. The commanders cupola has 360 vision via periscopes all around, it juts out slightly over the side of the turret.
recognising_features.rooikat1d_szlidc3yzrnod9mtc6uq.jpg: The Rooikat has a low profile hull, it is sloped on the upper glacis plate with the driver sitting off to the right (left as you look at) with 3 periscopes, there is a splash plate that runs either side of the drivers periscopes. In front of the drivers hatch there is an inspection panel, the lower plate is relatively flat and has 2 headlights either side.

WpqUC19dqh7MwV--cNrO.name: ZBD-04
WpqUC19dqh7MwV--cNrO.description: The Type 04/ZBD-04 is a Chinese IFV, sometimes incorrectly called the Type 97, due to the early prototypes receiving the name ZBD-97. Produced indigenously, although with some copied parts. The copied parts mainly consist of the turret, which is heavily influenced by the BMP-3, however the hull is of an indigenous design, it was designed as the successor to the Type 86, which is essentially a Chinese produced BMP-1. As with most Chinese vehicles, definitive information can be scarce, although some things can be confirmed by what can be seen on the vehicles.

recognising_features.zbd04_5jgu5sywop1edth6hiaq.jpg: A close up of the turret, you can see the angling of the turret front. The gunner has a large sight with an oval shaped sight door on the left side of the turret.
recognising_features.zbd04_jnie3n9i9ag5wxpk7qsg.jpg: The hull of the ZBD-04 is of a typical Chinese design, with a heavy focus on amphibious operations. The driver is seated on the left side with a left side opening hatch, he has 3 periscopes, he is equipped with periscopes, although that is not shown in this picture (see next), the engine decks and exhaust are on the right, the black square being the exhaust, a worthy note for thermal view. The final drive is at the front, The road wheels are equally spaced, with prominent gaps between the 4th-5th-6th. There are 3 top rollers.
recognising_features.zbd04_owf2g5wv39v8n0yz44ak.jpg: Here you have a better view of the drivers position, as well as the front from a direct view. Note that the side slopes slightly towards the top, the sides are flat also with nothing fitted to the sides.
recognising_features.zbd04_xujaow6nwka4y2gwgym7.jpg: The ZBD-04 has a turret very reminiscent of the BMP-3, a good differentiating note is that the BMP-3 has a forward mounted turret with the engine at the rear, the ZBD-04 has the turret centrally placed with the engine mounted in the front of the hull. The turret slopes more than it does on the BMP-3, being more angular too, the BMP’s turret is more circular. It has 3x SGD’s on either side of the turret cheeks; the 100mm main gun has a 30mm coax beside it.

XZZssPyrIY4SpexiuPm0.description: The KamAZ-53949 Typhoon-L is a Russian 4x4 mine resistant ambush protected infantry mobility vehicle, the vehicle is part of the Russian Typhoon programme, the main goal of the program is to design a unified platform for all Russian armored wheeled vehicles. The vehicle can be fitted with either a pintle mount or RWS.
XZZssPyrIY4SpexiuPm0.name: KamAZ Typhoon-L

recognising_features.kamaztyphoonl_1yms68vdq0nnqqwnxd3c.jpg: The KamAZ-53949 Typhoon-K is a big change for Russian vehicle production, it looks very western compared to previous vehicles. The best way to recognise it from western counterparts is the front end, there are 7 rectangular grilles for the intercooler and radiator, as well as two circular LED lights, these are a big recognising feature for me personally. In the centre of the front is a winch system for self recovery and recovery from another vehicle, as well as two more lights further down, likely fog lights. The front windows are large with a small line down the centre, the air intake snorkel is on the left side as you look at it, there is also a small camera at the top centre above the windows. Weapons fitted are either a 12.7mm KORD or 7.62mm PKT, either a pintle mount or RWS.
recognising_features.kamaztyphoonl_d8vgiusax479fepyvyo2.jpg: The side of vehicle shows 2x foot steps and 2x platforms for stepping up onto the vehicle, above the rear wheel is a large wheel arch with stowage bins in it, there are 2 doors for the crew and dismounts to use on either side. The vehicles rear shows a dismount door with steps that are folded upwards for transport and fold down when the troops exit.

XaqfwsCb659sb91p0VBr.description: The 5P85D is the "slave" TEL used in the S-300PS system. It is identical in all aspects to the primary 5P85S TELs apart from the lack of a command module and therefore inability to fire its own missiles. There are usually 6 x 5P85S TELs to 1 x 5P85D TEL in the system organisation. They are mounted on the same MAZ-534 8-wheeler.
XaqfwsCb659sb91p0VBr.name: 5P85D TEL

recognising_features.5p85d_j2q4okzblbrcclso8f95.jpg: 5P85D on a victory parade in Moscow, note the lack of a command console behind the cab.
recognising_features.5p85d_ucdqswipwzjdl3911w2x.jpg: A pair of S-300PS TELs in the raised position ready to engage. Note the camouflage news on the cabs of the vehicles, this tactic has been seen on many occasions and is possibly done to disguise which is a 'master' TEL and a 'slave' TEL from airborne or satellite imagery.

XzqmmjgRrDDqNKvdwB3B.description: The Merkava 4M Windbreaker is an upgraded Merkava 4, it is equipped with the Trophy active protection system from Rafael, the tank saw it's first contact during Operation Protective Edge in 2014, where the APS successfully intercepted RPG's and ATGM's such as the 9M133 Kornet (NATO:AT-14 Spriggan) the system, by identifying the source of fire, on occasion also allowed tanks to kill the Hamas fighters, the Trophy system gives the tank a huge increase of survivability.
XzqmmjgRrDDqNKvdwB3B.name: Merkava 4M

recognising_features.merkava4mwindbreaker_dzncwvdzso2udag6k90: A close up of the turret, on the left you can see the APS radar, it is smooth and rectangle shaped with cut corners.
recognising_features.merkava4mwindbreaker_fr4qyota7wxfg9m9xdd: From this angle you can see the rear left radar fitted to the rear stowage bin, the APS radars look like rectangles with cut corners, they are always smooth when compared to the rough paint on the tank itself, the rough look is due to the non-slip coating.
recognising_features.merkava4mwindbreaker_oo6d2ishvr8iuqyeqdb: The Merkava 4M Windbreaker has the Trophy APS system fitted, the system is easily recognisable on the turret sides towards the rear, when facing the tank head on, they look like ears. The 4M also has the M2 .50 fitted above the gun, like on the 3D, it is, like on the 3D slaved to the main gun. The commander also has an FN-MAG.

YAOg0uI5YCVOCCjsyXVB.description: The Kaiman is a Belorussian indigenously designed vehicle, based on the chassis of a BRDM-2, it resembles and clearly taken inspiration from the German/Dutch Fennek recce vehicle. It has protection levels that will resist 7.62mm, as well as a V-shaped hull to divert the blast of landmines. It is claimed that the vehicle has space for 4 extra passengers in case of an emergency, although given the size of the vehicle this seems like an interesting claim, I assess its more likely to be able to carry 2 extra passengers, its main roles are recce patrols, escorts, internal security and some variants include command and signal versions.
YAOg0uI5YCVOCCjsyXVB.name: Kaiman

recognising_features.kaiman_kvisqr1jy86ksrknq156.jpg: There is a cupola in the centre which can have an armoured cover, at the rear there are 2 exhausts, one either side with covers over them, this is likely to mitigate thermal signature. A spare tyre is typically carried on the rear.
recognising_features.kaiman_p9m35m6upe43tae4yeeg.jpg: The Kaiman is extremely similar looking to the German/Dutch Fennek recce vehicle. It has a boat shaped hull indicating an amphibious capability, there are 2 LED lights in cages on the upper plate. The driver has 3 windows, one large central window and 2 smaller angled windows either side of the central one. The are 2 doors on either side, they both have windows and are quite small, there are handrails above them on either side and a footstep. Behind the doors are stowage compartments, above those are 3 SGD's, the vehicle has 4 runflat tyres.
recognising_features.kaiman_v4afmvv6lodvbdo2hypu.jpg: The other side is the same, you can see in between both exhaust mounts are the engine decks. On both sides there is a square door behind the last roadwheel, likely for stowage of equipment.

YJYnL7CNkKF84W_iibCk.description: The Leopard 2A6 was one of the biggest jumps in modernisation of the Leopard 2 series, it has new composite armour around the turret including the ability of adding ERA the tank now has the newer, larger 120mm L/55 gun, this gives it the most powerful gun out of NATO tanks, with high accuracy and power it outguns all contemporary tanks, until the Challenger 3 is put in service. Again with the Leopard 2 series, there are variations between models due to export country requirements and needs.
YJYnL7CNkKF84W_iibCk.name: Leopard 2A6

recognising_features.leopard2a6_5myi3s75pkjraoquydv7.jpg: With the new turret come new recognising features for you too learn, this includes the new larger L/55 gun, the new wedge shaped turret, on the turret you’ll see the new gunners sight, a big difference here is the commanders sight is now behind the commanders hatch. The SGD’s are fitted in double rows at the rear of the turret side.
recognising_features.leopard2a6_hyztaal0za59a6wqovs4.jpg: Leopard 2A6 CAN in Afghanistan, these are equipped with bar armour due to the low AT threat, this is to mitigate RPG damage.
recognising_features.leopard2a6_rokhxbimpl70epys19hu.jpg: On the hull you will notice the side skirts are of a different design, they feature 2 foot steps in the centre of the vehicle side. You will see the rear turret stowage which has 2 triangular shaped stowage bins at both sides on the rear.

YM6wdyUfHmJZMAbhghdE.description: The BTR-RD Robot is a BTR-D for use with anti-tank platoons within the VDV, the interior has been redesigned for stowage of ATGM.s. The ATGM’s can either be used in the dismounted role or mounted on the pintle on the vehicle; there are usually 6 vehicles per VDV regiment.
YM6wdyUfHmJZMAbhghdE.name: BTR-RD Robot

recognising_features.btrrdrobot_kggwjbwp8seun4k8u59f.jpg: The BTR-RD is visually identical to the BTR-D aside from the 9P135M-1  ATGM launcher on the commander's cupola.

YuXFT8Fe01H5aaVjwB4i.description: The Merkava 4 is the first fully digitised tank, all of the vehicle comms systems, electronics and sensors are integrated into a sophisticated battlefield management system, this provides the commander with up to date locations of themselves, friendly forces and marked enemy forces, all displayed on flat panel screens. The tank has an upgraded turret with even more composite armour, the effort to improve protection has led to a distinctive stepped silhouette, instead of the previous wedge shaped turret on the older Merkava models.
YuXFT8Fe01H5aaVjwB4i.name: Merkava 4

recognising_features.merkava4_11pn99p0nz7w1g2ascp5.jpg: The hull on the Merkava 4 is generally the same as the 3, the sideskirts change and the last couple of sideskirts are replaced by bar armour. Clearly the turret is the distinctive upgrade here, with a huge size and a shape that reminds me of the Tripods from the War of the Worlds film. The composite armour on the sides give a stepped effect, the turret flows towards the gun creating a point as the gun meets the turret front. The gunners sight is on the right side of the turret, as it is on the 3, though the commanders independent sight is now on the loaders side. The rear of the turret has a stowage rack.
recognising_features.merkava4_7lhz163fvalp6qch6jsk.jpg: The commanders sight is shown here on the left side of the turret, previously on the 3 it was behind the gunners sight.
recognising_features.merkava4_vufmzjnnjs6gtbn6aecv.jpg: This image clearly displays the sheer size of the turret, you can see the stepped effect on the sides due to the composite armour fitting. You can see the SGD banks on either side of the turret, they have black caps on them. Below the SGD's are the frontal laser warning sensors.

ZWGS5xogYUAoBf2E1MBy.description: The BMO-T is a heavy APC used to transport the rocket flamethrower troops of the NBC Protection Troops, it is based on the T-72 and is therefore extremely heavily armoured for an APC, with composite armour and Kontakt-5 ERA Tiles it is well protected.
ZWGS5xogYUAoBf2E1MBy.name: BMO-T

recognising_features.bmot_jkxwe9gtgfone5250e0j.jpg: The BMO-T has the same hull as the T-72, instead of a turret it has a raised superstructure. The superstructure is heavily sloped at the front with Kontakt-5 tiles covering the entirety; the commander’s hatch is at the central top of the vehicle with a KORD MG fitted on a pintle mount. There are 2 banks of SGD’s above each front mudguard, the sides are flat, also there are also 6 ERA panel tiles covering the lower side.
recognising_features.bmot_wr9tv3hb4ukr759sucq4.jpg: The rear of the BMO-T, it has 2 stowage boxes that extend all the way to the rear, with a large gap in between for access to the engine decks, the exhaust is at the rear left like on T-72.

a5EQg3pA348McsjKGNEq.description: The ATZ-4-131 is a fuel tanker variant of the ZIL-131, it has a tank capacity of 4148 litres and is used by logistical units for refuelling.
a5EQg3pA348McsjKGNEq.name: ATZ-4-131

recognising_features.atz4131_2dfdnd8pqsnrt7hywjon.jpg: The cab remains the same as the ZIL-131, the biggest difference is the obviously fuel tank at the rear in place of a troop carrying module. The fuel tank has 2x pipes on the side, this applies for both sides. There is also a large circular mount on top, for filling the tanker.

aT9uLYAPWftVAe5pZfl0.description: The ZSU 23-4 was the primary SPAAG throughout most of the Cold War. It is a capable platform that is still in use by both Russia and multiple countries today. It uses 4 x 2A7 (23mm) autocannons, which is where it gets it designation of 23-4. The system uses the 1RL33M1 'Tobol' radar, which align the turret towards targets. The radar has a detection range of 20km and an engagement range of 3000 metres. It is primarily designed to engage low flying targets, and has been used successfully in multiple conflicts - plugging the gaps beneath the divisional SAMS (such as Kub or Buk). There were modifications made to the ZSU for certain conflicts, since it was so effective at engaging ground targets.
aT9uLYAPWftVAe5pZfl0.name: ZSU 23-4

recognising_features.zsu234_cz3umrv4pa85swtbz8xw.jpg: The Gun Dish radar sits at the rear of the turret, behind the commanders hatch. The radar is circular and capable of traversing 360 degrees. In front of the radar, sitting under conical covers are two back-up optical sights for manual engagement.
recognising_features.zsu234_oj5kcde8cxsk0hecxgvu.jpg: Based on the chassis of the GM-575, the Shilka has 6 road-wheels in a 1-5 configuration. The final drive is at the rear. The drivers hatch sits in the front glacis plate on the left hand side. The turret contains the 4 x 2A7 autocannons and the radar system.
recognising_features.zsu234_pod89ago0vf6mhzfy2r0.jpg: A close up of the optical sights used for manual engagement, if the radar and these sights are destroyed - the Shilka cannot fire. This makes it highly vunerable to airburst weapon systems.

aY2IvdzWATWwOP_NyH9_.name: MT-LBu
aY2IvdzWATWwOP_NyH9_.description: The MTLBu is a larger, more powerful variant of the MTLB, it was designed to be the basis for command and specialist vehicles, most commonly the 1V12 through 1V16 series of artillery command, recce and forward observations vehicles.

recognising_features.mtlbu_aim8l08ztg4l6efehb18.jpg: At the rear is a singular door, it is small and square and sits in the centre. This particular variant is the 1V12 ACRV, captured in Iraq.
recognising_features.mtlbu_rqhrphk4ie19dgxdyslp.jpg: The MTLBu essentially looks like an overgrown MTLB, it is much higher, though still retains the look of an MTLB. The hull is boat shaped with a slack track, with 7 equally spaced roadwheels and the final drive at the front. Above the tracks is a large gap between the top of the track and the hull superstructure, it is flat lower down then slopes upwards before coming to a point on the side, giving it that boat shape. There is a large mudguard at the front, with 2 towing eyes on the lower glacis plate, there are 2 glass vision optics at the front with armoured shutters, there is typically a light in between these, as seen here.

aq6kxWAID4M_NbtVSr3F.description: The 2S33 Msta-SM2 is an upgraded variant of the 2S19 Msta. It is fitted with the 2A79 cannon, which is significantly longer and has improved ballistics. It can fire ammunition with more propellant charges and with a higher breech pressure, which improves the range of fire. The maximum range for standard ammunition is 30km and rocket propelled up to 40km.
aq6kxWAID4M_NbtVSr3F.name: 2S33 Msta-SM2

recognising_features.2s33mstasm2_16zb5y32da3kyahf8nsz.jpg: Another example of how long the barrel is on the 2S33 Msta-SM2.
recognising_features.2s33mstasm2_aw64vf5kdd4whbv6kwyz.jpg: The key identifible feature on the 2S33 is the longer side skirts, that cover 50% of the T-80 chassis road wheels. The road wheel configuration is still 1-2-3-456.
recognising_features.2s33mstasm2_prnv43ervza0349vfqfg.jpg: The 2S33 barrel is longer than the 2S19 barrel. Seen here in Ukraine (2022), the barrel is double the length of the turret. The fume extractor is also situated nearer to the muzzle break, whereas the 2S19 fume extractor was in the centre of the barrel.

b4VamHbYiOKl8tv_esM-.description: The BTR-80A is an upgraded BTR-80 fitted with a BPPU turret, up-armed with a 30mm cannon, it enhances the lethality of the standard BTR-80.
b4VamHbYiOKl8tv_esM-.name: BTR-80A

recognising_features.btr80a_82syarzu36sejx9katg5.jpg: The BTR-80A is characterised by the new turret, the turret is slanted rearwards, it has 3 SGD’s either side of the gun, the gun is prominent with its single cylindrical bulge towards the end. On the far right of the turret(not in shot) there is a seperate mount for the 7.62mm PKT, above the gun is the IR Searchlight.
recognising_features.btr80a_p6gqd4y9dozudj6nlb6o.jpg: On this shot you can see the PKT mount, the hull remains the same as the standard BTR-80, for a guide on the BTR-80 find it under APC’s.

b7Ml5kJtuHgBj9wjiQIj.description:
The BMR-1 is a mine clearing vehicle developed in the USSR in 1975, converting them from MTP-3 engineering vehicles, this was due to a need of a purpose built de-miner for use in the Soviet Ground Forces, it saw a lot of use in the Soviet-Afghan War, as well as the Ukrainian UNFIL unit in Lebanon and the Russo-Ukraine war. It has a KMT-5M mine clearing system, but this isn’t always the case, some are seen with the KMT-7 and KMT-9 mine rollers, it also has a modified machine gun turret from a BTR-60.
The vehicle itself is extremely rare, most of the pictures I could find where of a singular Ukrainian vehicle from 2014 which is in a poor condition, likely stored since 1991.
b7Ml5kJtuHgBj9wjiQIj.name: BMR-1

recognising_features.bmr1_7pqrl69v1q2abpt3nng9.jpg: The superstructure sides are sloped upwards too, with the modified BTR-60 turret on top, the turret is not in the frying pan style but completely cylindrical, as mentioned previously track links are on the vehicle side, with the exhaust at the rear left of the vehicle.
recognising_features.bmr1_c8s65f6mw1e2xbgjshmi.jpg: The lower hull is instantly recognisable as that of a T-54/55, with 5 roadwheels with a prominent gap between the 3rd and 4th and rubber flaps on the side, it has the late style rubber flaps which extend upwards above the hull. The upper hull contains a large superstructure with heavy sloping upwards, there are two headlights on the right side (left as you look at it) and various points for bolting equipment on, usually track links.
recognising_features.bmr1_lt7pi2ia9k9i6pmt3y8f.jpg: The rear of the vehicle shows a large tool box at the rear left, and a low profile one on the right. On the rear of the superstructure is a crew hatch and a large dome next to it.

bQ1DwUcmZ52giNtYR1Wa.description: The 5P85S is the primary TEL for the S-300PS (NATO: SA-10B "Grumble") system. It is the third generation upgrade for the S-300 system and the oldest still in service. It carries four 5V55R missiles and is one of three TELs that form the S-300 battery, the other two are the 5P85D "slave" TEL and the 5P85T "trailer" TEL which are unable to fire on their own and require the guidance systems from a 5P85S, which in turn requires input from a host of external radars to accurately engage air and ground targets up to 90km away. The TEL is based on the MAZ-543 8 wheeled truck.
bQ1DwUcmZ52giNtYR1Wa.name: 5P85S TEL

recognising_features.5p85s_be7qgx8ysk7mhcxy12p2.jpg: The MAZ-543 is an 8 wheeler with a distinctive cut out on the front right of the cab. The 5P85S can be identified as the 'master' TEL by the presence of the angular command module sitting behind the cab. On the 5P85D variant of TEL this space is used for equipment storage and is usually open, although can sometimes have a weather cover over it.
recognising_features.5p85s_mprty3ikrmn5lof69fcg.jpg: Unlike the S-300V TELARs and LLVs, the S-300PS (and all other variants) have the four missiles in banks of two rather than in one row. Be aware that S-400 and S-500 also use this configuration so it isn't reliable way to identify an S-300 from other systems.

bh9nDbknBYVzIb4c0PaA.description: The BMD-1P is a BMD-1 upgraded with the newer more effective 9M113/9P135M-1 (Konkurs) ATGM replacing the older 9M14/9M14 Malyutka.
bh9nDbknBYVzIb4c0PaA.name: BMD-1P

recognising_features.bmd1p_5cqxaz0fo0pfjb5xb8q2.jpg: Similar to the BMP-1P, the only change with the BMD-1P is with the ATGM change, the main visible difference is the ATGM now being a large elevated launch tube on the turret, whereas the BMD-1 has the bare missile fitted above the armament. Although thismay seem intricate and unnecessary to learn, the change in ATGM hugely changes the potency of these IFV’s for example the effective range of the 9M14 compared to the 9M113 is as follows 9M14-3km, 9M113-4km. This significantly enhances the lethality of these vehicles, therefore showing the need to recognise the differences with these vehicles.

bmjkr2txuNkJHTAv-hYi.description: The 9P163M-1 Kornet-T NATO:AT-14 Spriggan is an ATGM vehicle, based on the BMP-3 hull. It is very similar to the 9P157 in some aspects.
bmjkr2txuNkJHTAv-hYi.name: 9P163M Kornet-T

recognising_features.9p163mkornett_1c2r3g5lmmdo41p2pzot.jpg: The hull remains the same as the BMP-3, the main differences are the periscopes and searchlight on the right hand side. The left side has the sighting system. On the top centre is the 2 missile launch tubes for the 9M113 missiles, they can be folded down inside in a stowed position like the 9P157-2.
recognising_features.9p163mkornett_toocgrhfu25xafxawa2t.jpg: On this side view you can see the triangular shaped sight on the left hand side, the 2 launch tubes are mounted on the rectangular vertical mounting arm.

bv5Ngi-yFMGYOWTfUMZh.description: The BTR-82A is the latest production model of the BTR series, it has improved protection, GLONASS navi system, more powerful engine and newer sighting systems.
bv5Ngi-yFMGYOWTfUMZh.name: BTR-82A

recognising_features.btr82a_b9tlvz5mvumv4l5irmi4.jpg: As you can see here there is a prominent cylinder above the exhaust, this is on both sides and a good indicating feature for this model, this isn't fitted to other BTR models. For an in-depth guide on BTR-80, see BTR-80.
recognising_features.btr82a_oocqr7be73gv9d511d3u.jpg: The BTR-82A is visually very similar to the BTR-80A, The main differences are on the turret and the rear. The sighting system below the gun isn’t there on BTR-80A, the searchlight above the gun is replaced with a square box.

c3h39axBFlh0aU7Bea4H.description: The 9A84 is the Loader Launcher Vehicle (LLV) for the 9M82 "Giant" surface-to-air missile. Unlike the 9A82/9A83 TELARs, it has no way of guiding its own missiles and must work in conjunction with an S-300V TELAR, which it can also reload with its crane.
c3h39axBFlh0aU7Bea4H.name: 9A84 LLV

recognising_features.9a84_abml8g8dccmr0p9znavj.jpg: This 9A84 LLV is using its crane to reload a 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR.
recognising_features.9a84_j80pk6j5nt8hl2jarlbc.jpg: The 9A84 LLV has two "Giant" missiles, seen here with a 9A83 "Gladiator" TELAR (notice the missile size difference).

c4lzB4DvxgqY4SwCUROQ.description: The Vityaz DT-30 is an articulated tracked carrier, designed to operate in extreme weather conditions. It was designed to operate in extreme climatic biomes like northern Russia, Siberia and the Far East. They can also be used as recovery vehicles due to the high pull ratio, they also have a very low ground pressure, which is useful for preventing the detonation of mines. The vehicles are used by Russian Army units in extreme climates, as well as civilian companies who use them for logging in the Far East and also scientific companies who conduct scientific research in extreme climates like the Arctic as well as remote and isolated regions like the Northern Islands of Russia. Some vehicles were used in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mostly by the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade. This and the DT-10 series are commonly confused, it is key to remember that the DT-30 is larger and longer than the DT-10. More than a hundred Vityaz vehicles are used in Russia for the transportation of cargo, such as: blocks, cranes and even towers for power lines in hard to reach regions. They serve rescue teams in extreme conditions. When a natural disaster occurs, there are no roads, the Vityaz all-terrain vehicle is a great help.
c4lzB4DvxgqY4SwCUROQ.name: DT-30

recognising_features.dt30_gcd7mhioh8ylpnh7sbdr.jpg: The DT-30 is an extremely recognisable vehicle, at a glance you can tell it is a purpose built all-terrain vehicle, this is an ATV much larger than any of the similar vehicles in the west. The vehicle has 2 parts, the front section is the cab and stowage, the trailer is purely for logistics or troop transport. The cab has 3 front windows, and a flat front with sloping towards the bottom. There are 2x headlights on the roof as well as 1x large searchlight, there are also 2x headlights and indicators on the front below the windows, there are 2 towing eyes on the lower front centre.
recognising_features.dt30_s7fze9ucve4yc16al9v4.jpg: The DT-30 has 6 roadwheels inside of wide tracks, the wide tracks provide a low ground pressure, which is necessary for the terrain the vehicle crosses. The side doors are small and rounded off at the edges, with a small set of ladders next to them. The engine is mounted in the centre of the first module, behind that is a logistics compartment, which can be denoted by the tarpaulin.

c7fW-jh9x_o-55qZ1Kn2.description: The BREM-K is a Russian light armoured recovery vehicle, based on the BTR-80. It has an unusual design, rather than a crane it has an A frame hoist boom, winch with 2 spools of cable attached to the turret. It is designed to work in BTR BTG’S its primary role being to recover bogged in vehicles. It has space for extra mechanics or the crew of the recovered vehicle.
c7fW-jh9x_o-55qZ1Kn2.name: BREM-K

recognising_features.bremk_jo3ncz89b5s1m6io4gny.jpg: The turret is similar to the standard BTR-80, except it now has the 14.5mm KPVT removed, although it retains the PKTmount for local defence. Fitted to the rear of the turret are 2 large spools for the A frame, they give a distinct recognition feature.
recognising_features.bremk_rqgiabtszsx8wkph1fz1.jpg: On the side of the vehicle you will see extra equipment for tools, not usually seen on a standard BTR-80. Behind the turret is a crate for stowage of tools and equipment, the rest of the hull remains the same.

ciRvI5WNpfdf6JDFj_EB.description: The T-90S is an export model of the T-90 series MBT, you may it see it written as 'T-90C' when written in Cyrillic. The T-90S was originally offered with an export version of Shtora-1 which did not have the OTShU-1-7 electro optical dazzlers, this area without the dazzlers was filled with more Kontakt-1. It appears that from the 2010's onwards T-90S tanks are now offered with the full Shtora-1 system, which is strange as the dazzlers are much less useful nowadays compared to the 90's, some early T-90S tanks were fitted with the early cast turrets, until production on welded turrets fully commenced, it is known that India mainly received the cast turret variants. Despite it being an export model it has been used by Russian Forces in Ukraine, including the Wagner Group.
ciRvI5WNpfdf6JDFj_EB.name: T-90S

recognising_features.t90s_3aczs10tgktkefdofwx7.jpg: The T-90S in terms of the early models is easily identifiable by the lack of OTShU-1-7 electro optical dazzlers, instead the area is filled with Kontakt-5 where the dazzlers would be, the laser warning sensors are still present above the main gun. This is the main recognising feature between the early T-90S and T-90A.
recognising_features.t90s_k117xlp0i1a50o4l5fif.jpg: Shown here is the original Shtora-1 layout on a T-90A, showing the previously mentioned MTShU-1-7, which on the T-90S's is not present due to it being encased inside the OTShU-1-7 EO box.
recognising_features.t90s_wphh5paslvgnb93rab4w.jpg: Now the T-90S later versions have the OTShU-1-7 EO dazzlers, but they have the modernised version of this, Shtora-1M, which means that the modulator MTShU-1-7 is now encased inside the EO box (see next image for explanation on this). Now some T-90A's also have this later version fitted, but not all of them, so this is generally a good feature to go off when attempting to recognise a T-90S.

ckLDrjDrl1iES2nDzkbS.name: ZTZ-99A
ckLDrjDrl1iES2nDzkbS.description: The ZTZ-99A is the PLA's premier tank, It takes a big leap for China’s tank production, which before this was mainly copies/heavily inspired soviet designs, it seems to be inspired from western tanks more than its predecessors which were heavily soviet influenced.

recognising_features.ztz99a_bdy2j67bldz6n2fprwb7.jpg: The tracks are of a modern dual pin design, the lower glacis has what appears to be either a trench digger, there are 6 ERA bricks on the first layer of the hull, ending each to provide space for the headlights.
recognising_features.ztz99a_lur27yo76h0qfllby7gv.jpg: The ZTZ-99A has a much more western appearance, the frontal turret has a sharp, sleek look. It’s got ERA across the whole frontal turret, you can see the small squares. The gunners primary sight is a prominent rectangle on the left side of the turret, with a large box shape elevated behind his hatch, this is part of active protection system. The commander has a panoramic sight in front of his hatch with a meteorological sensor behind his hatch, above the 125mm MA you’ll see a small box, this is again part of the active protection system. On the turret sides you’ll see the SGD’s with a bank of 5 either side, behind that is a large ERA fitting around the bustle rack.
recognising_features.ztz99a_u4h4kz4b1j89hcxf2gl5.jpg: The ZTZ-99A’s hull has ERA on the front plate, with a thin drivers splash plate. The driver has 2 periscopes, the right periscope is smaller than the left, the hull gradually slopes upwards as it goes to the back, giving a raised superstructure look at the rear like an M1 Abrams series of MBT’s. There are 2 small square exhausts on either side. Along the hull sides there are 5 square holes, presumably footsteps, the tank has 6 roadwheels with prominent gaps between the 3rd-4th and 4th-5th.

dWjnsek8M7lZc-BD2YE1.description: The 9S932-1 Barnaul-T is an air defence command vehicle. It is contained within the MTLBu chassis. The system provides C2 for mobile surface to air systems such as the Buk, Tor and Pantsir as well as Manpad units. The system works by receiving data from surveillance radars and transmitting it to the SAM batteries, enabling them to layer air defences. It also has its own surveillance radar, the 1L122-1E 'Garmon', which can find air targets up from 1-40km.
dWjnsek8M7lZc-BD2YE1.name: 9S932-1 Barnaul-T

recognising_features.9s9321barnault_9ellqscivaamc3xswdd1.jpg: The MTLBu chassis is built higher than the standard MTLB, this means there is more space inside required for the crew to operate. The key recognising feature is the 1L122 'Garmon' radar, it is rectangular with 4 rows of 'fins' and a section of smaller squares at the bottom.
recognising_features.9s9321barnault_dd3ukre5hdm6azmo1nhd.jpg: On the right hand side of the vehicle, at the rear, is a collapsable mast.
recognising_features.9s9321barnault_iam4bpxmwl5d9ipodopk.jpg: This image shows the addition of a rectangular storage bin on the right hand side of the chassis and the mast in the elevated position.
recognising_features.9s9321barnault_l9n62v58kfdzuh1194xc.jpg: The left hand side of the MTLBu has two triangular mounting brackets with a pair of cable reels in between.
recognising_features.9s9321barnault_tb4yhrz19m5qjgyovgq6.jpg: 9S932-1 Barnaul-T captured in Ukraine, April 2022. Note the large bin on the rear right of the vehicle.

dgSEWB6CzISQYJ6VVFVD.description: The T-80BVK is T-80BV command tank, intended for company, battalion and regimental commanders in T-80BV equipped units. The tank was oringally a T-80BK but with Kontakt-1 ERA. The First models were just T-80BK tanks with ERA. Later models were T-80BV tanks with additional communications equipment listed later and an antenna, R-130 radio, TNA navigation set, a 2nd whip antenna and a telescopic mast. It does not have the GTN-12 Kobra guidance antennae system, so no ability to fire GLATGM. The Ukrainian 93rd Mechanised Brigade have a T-80BVK fitted with Kontakt-5, which causes much confusion with people attempting to recognise it.
dgSEWB6CzISQYJ6VVFVD.name: T-80BVK

recognising_features.t80bvk_dyx3dd5iuiqzjsqhsdkq.jpg: The T-80BVK command tank is recognised by its extra antennae near the 1G42 gunners sight, you can see it silhouetted against the wall behind it. The other main recognising feature is the lack of the GTN-12 Kobra GLATGM guidance antennae, instead you can see a stowage box, for reference this is the box in front of the commanders sight.
recognising_features.t80bvk_llutfe6ttf0dfgpwkp9h.jpg: On this image you have a much clearer view of the omitted GTN-12 system and can see the stowage box in front of the commanders hatch, you can recognise it with the 3 hinges.

doLArxtbXYdAUjIlqo5p.description: The 9K35 Strela-10, NATO designation SA-13 'Gopher' is a highly-mobile, short range surface to air missile system. It is the sucessor to the SA-9 'Gaskin'. The system is primarily used to engage low altitude targets like helicopters and drones. The system has integral 9S86 'Snap Shot' range only and 9S16 'Flat Box' passive radar which works in conjunction with the seperate PPRU-1 'Dog Ear' target acquisition radar.
doLArxtbXYdAUjIlqo5p.name: 9K35 Strela-10

recognising_features.9k35strela10_66x57jkcnab7nqbjpwlh.jpg: The 9K35 system consists of two banks of 2 missile launchers containing the 9M37 (or variants of) missile. In between the two banks is the 9S86 'Snap shot' range radar.
recognising_features.9k35strela10_ygk6hvauoy70xk1jup3r.jpg: The system is mounted on an MTLB chassis which has 6 evenly spaced road wheels and a slack track design. The SA-13 system is mounted in the centre of the hull.

dpmLKwP3ucrcC5dS7pnJ.description: The Krasukha-2 is Russian electronic warfare (EW) vehicle, with a primary role to jam and intercept AWACS, as well as other airborne radars, like radar guided missiles, once the missiles are jammed it presents a false target away from the complex it is protecting, so that it no longer poses a threat. It is for this reason that the Krasukha-2 protects complexes like command posts, air defence systems, industrial complexes in a time of war, the system assesses the kind of signal and provides impact on that radar signal with powerful jamming radiation, the result of this is that the aircraft being jammed are halted in an attempt of detecting targets, depriving them of being able to launch radar guided missiles. Krasukha-2 can also interfere with hypersonic aircraft, this means the Krasukha-2 is a cheap way of covering important and sensitive sites, without having to deploy valuable air defence systems. It has been used in Syria, as well as in 2018 in Eastern Ukraine, one system was captured by Ukrainian forces during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
dpmLKwP3ucrcC5dS7pnJ.name: 1L269 Krasukha-2

recognising_features.1l269krasukha2_0iut1bmqu1mjlyi8rkso.jpg: The Krasukha-2 system is mounted on a BAZ-6910-022 truck, the truck cab has a large overhang, with the first roadwheel behind it, it has 2 large rectangular frontal windows, with a front panel below them which have 2 horizontal lines across with a circle and a rectangle in the centre respectively. The headlight clusters are underneath a lip at the lower front of the cab. Behind the cab are stowage boxes for tools and equipment, the exhaust is a standard vertical truck exhaust, with a large cylindrical back box, leading upto the pipe with a flapper at the top.
recognising_features.1l269krasukha2_85rqw7g4k8bpewas6xqf.jpg: This view of the front gives a better look of the cab, moving onto the road wheels it has 2 pairs, the front have a prominent gap between them with a stabilising leg in between the 2 wheels, there is a large gap then the 2nd pair of wheels are there, they have a stabilising arm behind them. On the back deck is the EW system itself, mounted on a traversable table, it is shaped almost like the 9K330 Tor turret, with vertical slides then slopes up to the top, in front of this is the large radar dish.

e661hwttgZFMb6SEPltx.description: The MT-LBu based ARK-1M is a tracked artillery-locating radar operating in the H-band. Typically positioned in a division's reconnaissance battery, its primary purpose is to swiftly locate firing mortars, field artillery, multiple rocket launch systems, and tactical missiles. Additionally, it aids in directing counter-fire operations.
e661hwttgZFMb6SEPltx.name: 1RL239

recognising_features.1rl239_0h8yx2fyzpt2as27vk9h.jpg: The Ark-1M has a distinctive circular radar with a crossed pattern. Aside from the radar, the vehicle is an MTLBu with an electro optical sensor at the front.

eKDbIbpxBIDzCCsd_ntE.description:
The R-166 0.5 is a Russian radio communication vehicle based on the BTR-80, eight of these vehicles are in a brigade comms battalion, therefore the sighting of an R-166 0.5 likely means the sighting of a brigade HQ. The R-166 has an unjammable range of comms between 500-1000km. 
Max range:
HF, stationary (with deployed antenna) – up to 1000 km
HF, on the move – up to 250 km
UHF, stationary – up to 70 km
UHF, on the move – up to 25 km
Frequency range:
HF – 1.5-29.99999 MHz
UHF – 30-107.975 MHz
7 vehicles were lost during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
eKDbIbpxBIDzCCsd_ntE.name: R-166-05

recognising_features.r16605_dh868ozuq6fjjmszr8r6.jpg: The R-166 0.5 is evidently based on the BTR-80, it is immediately noticeable as a command vehicle with the sheer amount of antennae fitted to the vehicle, also the superstructure is much different, it is widened and heightened to accommodate the communications equipment. The top of the hull has a prominent frame antennae above the unarmed turret, behind this is the generator to keep the vehicle running without the need for the main engine to run. Moving down to the front there are 2 large hatches on the slope that open forwards, these are above the normal BTR BP glass windows. Above these is another frame antenna. Along the sides of the vehicle are antennas and masts to set up the brigade HQ.
recognising_features.r16605_lgjty2od0fh1n1cf7zy8.jpg: From the rear the R-166 0.5 has a lot of visible modifications from a standard BTR-80, you can see the antennae, the spool next to the generator and the masts, as well as the widened superstructure. Whilst the rear part of the vehicle is the same as the standard BTR-80, the front is widened. When comparing this to the R-149MA1, you will notice that the R-149MA1 does not have the antennae, or the masts on the sides.

eXJy9km84CEB3SQtISfw.description: The BM-27 Uragan is a 220mm multiple launch rocket system (MLRS). The base vehicle is a Zil-135, with 16 launch tubes. The system has a maximum range, depending on the rocket type, of up to 35km.
eXJy9km84CEB3SQtISfw.name: BM-27 Uragan

recognising_features.bm27uragan_9u8q6tc8rm8csmgr53iv.jpg: Captured Russian BM-27 Uralagan in Ukraine in 2022.
recognising_features.bm27uragan_uqwbodtd6vbj7rc6gi84.jpg: The Zil-135 chassis is an 8 wheeled vehicle in a 1-2-1 configuration. The rocket launcher is arrayed in two rows of 6 tubes and one row of 4, giving it the ability to fire 16 rockets in a 20 seconds.

eok01oXxtr3eJDyfcceL.description: The T-72AMT is a Ukrainian upgrade of the T-72A, upgrading the armour with the addition of Nozh ERA, new radios and the addition to fire the Ukrainian Kombat ATGM, the tank has recently seen service in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
eok01oXxtr3eJDyfcceL.name: T-72AMT

recognising_features.t72amt_nq6yo2oms00wcjiyq8kw.jpg: The T-72AMT sides are noticeable by the side ERA being the same mounts as seen on the T-80U. Towards the rear is a cage which covers the rear quarter.
recognising_features.t72amt_u2uysyo03ozsvacalhik.jpg: The T-72AMT is noticeable on the frontal hull by the small Kontakt-1 style blocks, as well as the rubber flaps on the lower glacis plate.
recognising_features.t72amt_vhq2jq1jnibbfmnayypk.jpg: The T-72AMT has many recognising features, the main being the addition of the Nozh ERA, this is seen on the turret. Nozh is fitted snugly to the turret, with no gaps in between the ERA, there are rubber flaps that hang off of the ERA, there is also Nozh covering the turret roof. The IR searchlight is on the right side of the gun, indicating no thermal capability.

epvGV9wPXM8xQVnYQL2S.name: 9T217
epvGV9wPXM8xQVnYQL2S.description: The 9T217 is a transporter-loader for the 9K33 Osa/Romb air defence system, based on the same BAZ-5937 hull as the air defence vehicles as well. There are 2x 9T217 transloaders in a 9K33 battery.

recognising_features.9t217_8bs1i2qemgavwc7juui0.jpg: The BAZ-5937 hull remains the same, on top of the hull is a large dome which is where the missiles are kept, the dome is folded up at the front and then retracted to gain access to the missiles.
recognising_features.9t217_2vtzev8xogurwfgsdhmf.jpg: Here the nose of the stowage compartment can be seen being raised.
recognising_features.9t217_45g9ranf3oj64warerbo.jpg: Here the stowage compartment is moved backwards which exposes the missile stowage and the crane.
recognising_features.9t217_vivatg5s2d5hfwgc70eg.jpg: View of the 9T217 transloader resupplying the 9K33 Osa.

es7C-LPGln29DE7zBdTO.description: The BMD-2 is an upgrade of the BMD-1, it was originally supposed to completely replace the BMD-1 but due to the declining economy of the USSR, this never materialised and it served alongside it. It has a new turret and a slightly modified hull, it has the 30mm 2A42 gun from the BMP-2.
es7C-LPGln29DE7zBdTO.name: BMD-2

recognising_features.bmd2_bu8dymc268g0aq31x2m4.jpg: The rear of the BMD-2 has a large gap in the centre, there are 2 exhausts, one either side seen here, the black rectangles. Below the exhausts are the openings for the water jets. The antenna whip is at the rear left.
recognising_features.bmd2_mp54nh2kdcpj0ln4fh29.jpg: When in an operational setting you will see the ATGM mount on top of the turret. The hull hasan air inlet grille at the front centre in front of the drivers hatch, which has 3 periscopes, the hatches either side of the drivers have 1 periscope on the right, and 2 on the left hatch. Below the air inlet is the splash plate for amphibious operations, moving to the running gear it has 5 equally spaced small ‘pork pie’ roadwheels, with the final drive at the rear.
recognising_features.bmd2_qoq8q4txm4beha8gkczz.jpg: The BMD-2 retains the same hull as the BMD-1, aside from some small changes. The turret is the biggest change, it is completely new, it is taller and has less of a conical shape, it has more of a ‘bucket’ shape than the classic soviet ‘frying pan’ turret shape. Its armed with a 30mm 2A42 Gun-the same as the BMP-2 which gives a prominent recognition feature with the square muzzle brake.

fKQ2An9fF9vOff7LtKSY.description: The 2A36 Giatsint-B is a Russian 152 mm towed field gun introduced in 1975. Designed to target enemy forces and equipment, it's adept for counter-battery actions and operates effectively in temperatures from -50°C to 50°C. This gun is the towed counterpart of the 2S5 Giatsint-S. It's utilized by nations like Russia, Finland, Iraq, Ukraine, and Lebanon, notably during Lebanon's Nahr el-Bared conflict, possibly acquired from Iraq before the Lebanese Civil War ended. The 2A36 features a semi-automatic breech, a hydro-pneumatic battery harnessing recoil energy, and a chain-driven rammer. Its hydraulic-powered carriage offers a two-speed elevation mechanism.
fKQ2An9fF9vOff7LtKSY.name: 2A36 Giatsint-B

recognising_features.2a36giatsintb_4mueg78g33sqxanesiy6.jpg: The gun has a protective shroud to shield the crew whilst operating the howitzer. The recoil systems sit direction above the barrel, similar to the D-30.
recognising_features.2a36giatsintb_yk3njd5jvykqh54369d8.jpg: The 2A36 Giatsint-B is a unique looking towed howitzer due to the 4 wheels that support it when in transit. It has a split carriage, with the trails being as long as the barrel.

fZy77l2U6CoTFerNM1CM.description: The D-20 is a towed 152mm howitzer, first introduced in 1950s. It is still in use by both the Russian Federation and various countries worlwide. It is simple but effective technology that can engage targets up to 17km away (24km with RAP).
fZy77l2U6CoTFerNM1CM.name: D-20

recognising_features.d20_50fu14uyfdyb5vd0pmsb.jpg: The D-20 can be identified by the armoured plate shield in front of the gun to protect the crew from small arms whilst firing. The muzzle break has unique baffles, a square one at the front and a rectangular at the rear. Two arms fold out whilst deployed and a circular plate jack raises the wheels up to level the gun whilst firing.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Algeria,Angola,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Brazil,Bulgaria,Burkina Faso,Burundi,Chad,Republic of the Congo,Cuba,Cyprus,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Equatorial Guinea,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Guinea,Hungary,India,Indonesia,Iraq,Kazakhstan,Kyrgyzstan,Libya,Mali,Mozambique,Myanmar,Namibia,Nicaragua,Niger,Nigeria,North Korea,North Macedonia,Pakistan,Peru,Poland,Russia,Rwanda,Serbia,Senegal,Sierra Leone,Sri Lanka,Sudan,Syria,Tajikistan,Turkmenistan,Uganda,Ukraine,United States of America,Uzbekistan,Venezuela,Vietnam,Yemen,Zimbabwe

fslrS16l4pLESawJP_Jq.description: The Mi-24 Hind is Russia's most successful multi-role helicopter, exported to many nations worldwide. Nicknamed by Soviet pilots as the 'Flying Tank', the Mi-24V was introducted in 1973. The aircraft is based on the Mi-8 Hip transport helicopter, with the addition of winglets for weapon storage and a 12.7mm Yak-B gatling gun.
fslrS16l4pLESawJP_Jq.name: Mi-24V

recognising_features.mi24v_6ry5scs204vp3n5myluq.jpg: The winglets of the Mi-24V sit in the centre of the fuselage, slightly behind the main rotor. The winglets have three pylons (hard-points) for weapons and external tanks.
recognising_features.mi24v_8hj6866p7hoqrlzeto3t.jpg: The Mi-24V is a single rotor helicopter. Is has air intakes above the double cockpit and downward sloping winglets. The tail boom leads to a single, backwards sloped rudder with a single tail propellor. There are large circular exhaust ports on either side of the fusilage, beneath the rotor mast.
recognising_features.mi24v_ovthw7fm8b4q16nv8s9n.jpg: The singe 12.7mm Yak-B Gatling gun sits at the front of the fuselage beneath the most forward cockpit.

geuSTpdJfSfeTXnIt34S.description: The 54K6 is the command post used by the S-300 (excluding S-300V) and S-400 system. It is mounted on the same MAZ-534 8-wheeler rigid body trucks as the majority of the S-300 series. In the case of the S-300PS, it works by receiving data from the early-warning and detection radars (36D6 "Tin Shield" and 76N6 "Clam Shell") and tasking the 5P85S master TEL to engage the target. It has a valuable role within the battery, and could be deemed as the critical element to S-300PS, although the TELs have the ability to launch missiles directly with the 5N63S "Flap Lid B" guidance radar.
geuSTpdJfSfeTXnIt34S.name: 54K6

recognising_features.54k6_bzaxshot330tpszdpnhk.jpg: The 54K6 command vehicle is on mounted on the same MAZ-534 chassis with the distinctive cut-out of the cab.
recognising_features.54k6_xh05pjotvvdp4cmlnj05.jpg: Internal view of the radar operators.

gg64T01GPOw4KgrKfVFi.description: Unified command vehicle (UCV) R-149MA1 was designed to command bridgade/regiment sized units both on the move and in static locations. This vehicle can also be used at the operational (battalion) level to coordinate the close fight. The vehicle is a modified BTR-80, with additional communications equipment and GLONASS navigation system.
gg64T01GPOw4KgrKfVFi.name: R-149MA1

recognising_features.r149ma1_aquq86gj7g8xqhj13503.jpg: Left side. There are two storage bins on the left hand side of the vehicle and with one rectangular bin immediatedly above the exhausts. There is a cable reel attached to the front of this bin. There is a single antenna port in front superstructure and one on the back left.
recognising_features.r149ma1_bt1zs13l3niaur74vayf.jpg: The R-149MA1 is a modified BTR-80, it has 8 wheels in 12-34 configuration. The superstructure of the vehicle is much taller and wider, with a generator on the very top. You can see the two square air vents on the left-hand side.
recognising_features.r149ma1_bzwlijcs8s7d28kh5mld.jpg: Front. The modified BTR-80 has a wider and taller superstructure. The drivers and commanders hatch sit higher than on the standard BTR-80. There is an IR searchlight beneath the right hand hatch.
recognising_features.r149ma1_cibholwn14hpqzjbbs1v.jpg: The rear of the R-149MA1 has a large cable reel on the back right and a collapsable mast on the rear centre (stowed in this picture).
recognising_features.r149ma1_jevvljwdg5j5thwobppn.jpg: Right side. The right hand side of the vehicle has various cable reel mounts above the exhaust and a long thin bin attached to the superstructure (this has two antenna ports attached)

gyEbkv0--hr27nLKM5yC.description: The T-62M Obr.2022 is an upgraded T-62M, the tank is upgraded with a 1PN96MT-02 thermal imaging sight, which greatly enhances the capability of the tank other than this the tank remains the same, some tanks do come out of the factory with Kontakt-1 on the hull and some don't, but either way, like with most eastern european vehicles they're fitted with Kontakt-1 ERA when the crews get hold of it, sometimes they have bar armour, either from factory or crew added, commonality on armour seems limited, the only solid commonality I can work out is the 1PN96MT-02 sight.
gyEbkv0--hr27nLKM5yC.name: T-62M Obr.2022

recognising_features.t62mobr.2022_jw07wuzdmkzatqoj9vck.jpg: T-62M Obr.2022 with Kontakt-1 on the hull and bar armour around the rear of the turret, the tank next to it is the T-62MV Obr.2022
recognising_features.t62mobr.2022_mgyg8q401idzpszoczqy.jpg: It is worth noting that the tanks are coming from storage in this state and being churned out looking brand new, the overhauls of T-62's from storage has been practiced on every Russian annual exercise for over 10 years now.
recognising_features.t62mobr.2022_ppe9d2bsnbikdr0luzma.jpg: So as already marked for us in this image we can see a lack of the large IR searchlight(small one remains), the IR searchlight is a good indicator between a T-62M and a T-62M Obr.2022, and also a good indicator of how likely the tank is to see you. You will notice a lack of the KDT-2 rangefinder which usually sits on top of the gun, this is due to the thermal sight having its own LRF.

hTlC1ciTQ2kdLkOnh_TP.description: The R-145BM1 is an upgraded version of the R-145BM, it has newer radios and has omitted the large AZI frame antennae.
hTlC1ciTQ2kdLkOnh_TP.name: R-145BM1 command vehicle

hYUV73BQW8K8ykPlUXOY.description: The 2B26 Grad-K, mounted on a Kamaz 6-wheeler, is a modernised 122mm Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS) from Russia, derived from the BM-21 Grad. This artillery system adeptly targets troop concentrations, soft-skin and lightly-armoured vehicles, command centres, and both artillery and mortar units, among other objectives.
hYUV73BQW8K8ykPlUXOY.name: 2B26 Grad-K

recognising_features.2b26gradk_krklyyn19qnc022rsgiw.jpg: The Grad-K rocket system is mounted on the KamAZ-5350 6x6 truck. Apart from software upgrades, the weapon systems remains the same, it now has the capability to be fired without the crew leaving the cab or even from a remote position to avoid counter battery fires.
recognising_features.2b26gradk_vahq1ywj2ey7ni07qz8q.jpg: A damaged Grad-K in Ukraine in 2023.

hpVSPE76KPYtnIDVWnOc.description: The 9K332 Tor-M2E, NATO reporting name SA-15D 'Gauntlet' is a medium level surface to air missile system. It is an upgrade to the M1 system, with an improved missile (9M332) and a new target acquisition radar. There is also a wheeled variant designated the Tor-M2K and a self contained unit, the Tor-M2KM, which can be mounted on supply vehicles or in static locations both on ground or on ship.
hpVSPE76KPYtnIDVWnOc.name: 9K332 Tor-M2E

recognising_features.9k332torm2e_pcvd7476ln297s097qxr.jpg: The square tracking radar has two globe shaped sensors in the top corners, this is unique to the Tor-M2E variants (the M1 only has one).
recognising_features.9k332torm2e_t5m9s0uh5ko643eyrrls.jpg: Captured Tor-M2 seen in Ukraine in 2022.
recognising_features.9k332torm2e_u2j8e27xx1913mlak00i.jpg: The key recognising feature of the Tor-M2E is the different target acquisition radar, instead of a mesh dish it is a rectangular plate dish.

iPDEMX8IQbZmmQpWBkr8.description: The BMR-3 is a mine clearance vehicle based on the T-72 hull, the vehicle, as with previous iterations of the BMR series has been modified to have a superstructure on top and mounts for mine rollers. It appears most BMR-3’s have been replaced by BMR-3M’s.
iPDEMX8IQbZmmQpWBkr8.name: BMR-3

recognising_features.bmr3_12mf9oam9v7x2n7xf65f.jpg: The BMR-3 has 2x hatches on either side of the superstructure, one is shown here. Behind the superstructure are 2 rails, presumably for stowage on the rear deck.
recognising_features.bmr3_3tointdc406h7hv3a78o.jpg: The BMR-3 like other de-miners is instantly recognisable as a de-miner vehicle due to the large mine roller that’s fitted, the lower hull is of a T-72 but the difference is in the superstructure fitted to the top of the hull. The driver is moved from the lower hull, to the upper superstructure with a single periscope and also an open vision hatch with an armoured shutter. There are headlights either side of the armoured shutter, one is IR the other is standard vision.
recognising_features.bmr3_lue3qwdbezecx9zmmw2w.jpg: Behind the driver is the rotating commanders hatch, taken from a T-72A with multiple periscopes, 3 at the front, 1 at the rear. Either side of the flat fronted superstructure are 2x banks of 6x smoke grenade dischargers.

idIsn7Skt8snE7DhkDk1.name: Ratel 81
idIsn7Skt8snE7DhkDk1.description: The Ratel 81 is a fire support variant of the Ratel IFV series, it houses an internal 81mm mortar on a 360 degree traversable turntable. It is used by SANDF mechanised mortar platoons.

j8PfQN-kjCfj3WM--UvQ.description: The TOS-1 is a heavy, short-ranged multiple launch rocket system (MLRS). It is a 24 barrelled, 220mm flame thrower system. The TOS-1 can launch 24 thermobaric rockets in 20 seconds and is designed to engage fortified positions and light vehicles in open terrain. The combat vehicle of the system is named the BM-1, each battery constists of BM-1s and 2x TZM-T reloading vehicles.
j8PfQN-kjCfj3WM--UvQ.name: TOS-1

recognising_features.tos1_1isug2fpwq17owdo5o2u.jpg: TOS-1A system captured by Ukrainian forces in 2020.
recognising_features.tos1_jzy6cuyrdebxm174rjd2.jpg: The TZM-T is the loading vehicle for the TOS-1 system. It is easily recognisable by the crane sitting between the two pods of rockets.
recognising_features.tos1_pfnmd211obcvknyssfdt.jpg: The TOS-1 is heavily armoured, mounted on the T-72 chassis - although it has no ERA. It has 6 roadwheels with the final drive at the rear. It has side skirts to protect the top rollers from attack by RPG.

jJ1Czep751ufOtXKysWy.name: 2S3 Akatsiya
jJ1Czep751ufOtXKysWy.description: The 2S3 Akatsiya is a 152mm self-propelled howitzer which forms the bulk of Russian artillery batteries, as well as former Soviet states and allies. It was designed and manufactured in direct competition to the American M-109.

recognising_features.2s3akatsiya_f5w8mnpiehi80pb36r74.jpg: On the right hand side of the turret there is a square door which is used to load ammunition into the turret during engagements.
recognising_features.2s3akatsiya_sq6wmptch4pq09zmg80p.jpg: The 2S3 is mounted on a modified GM-123 chassis (also used by the 2K11 Krug). It has 6 roadwheels, with a prominent gap between 1-2 and 2-3. The final drive is at the front with 4 inset top rollers.
recognising_features.2s3akatsiya_yrstyh4ry7drjbly22id.jpg: The turret is circular at the front and taller than a standard AFV turret, this is typically a good indication that it is an SPG. The rear of the turret is flat. The turret has a hatch on the right hand side, for the commander. The gun protrudes over the forward edge of the vehicle. There are two tubes sitting directly above the barrel, attached to the turret, these are part of the recoil system.
recognising_features.2s3akatsiya_z7337n07jm8ohq3nk8ie.jpg: Inside the gun compartment on the 2S3. The 152mm rounds can be seen to the left.

jTZE22gyoLzom35M2qgn.description: The 9A82 Transporter Erector Launcher and Radar (TELAR) is one of the missile systems associated with the S-300V. They have the same Object 831 chassis as the rest of the battery and fire the 9M82 "Giant" surface-to-air missiles, primarily designed to defeat hostile ballistic missiles. The TELAR has its own radar which provides illumination and guidance to its own missiles or an associated 9A84 Load Launcher Vehicle (LLV). It can also engage targets with guidance provided by the 9S32 "Grill Pan" radar.
jTZE22gyoLzom35M2qgn.name: 9A82 TELAR

recognising_features.9a82_b333cb5fwfob59ou11mn.jpg: The 9A82 can be identified by the circular radar on the front of vehicle, when erected it is the same height as the missiles. The key identifier between the 9A82 and 9A83 is the two missiles instead of a bank of 4, this is due to the 9M82 "Giant" missiles being larger.

jVtc9-DTVHLrh99PrB8Q.description: The T-90AK is a T-90A command tank, typically used by company, battalion and regimental commanders in T-90A equipped tank units, these tanks are extremely rare and it appears that not enough were produced for company level and they typically only reside at battalion and regimental command use. The tank has additional communication R-163-50K radio station and TNA-4-3 navigation equipment. Given the rarity of the tank, not many images exist.
jVtc9-DTVHLrh99PrB8Q.name: T-90AK

recognising_features.t90ak_fqnxokerigs5b2mp97rd.jpg: As you can see with this side view the extra antennae is next to the gunners sight, behind the SGD's and the IR searchlight.
recognising_features.t90ak_pm1k2jm9eny1xwf0o72o.jpg: The T-90AK is recognised by a single defining feature, this is the extra antennae next to the gunners sight, just behind the IR searchlight, this feature shows the tank is a command version, of course making it a HVT.

k2oKDwovEnQjuMtwQTL4.description: The 2B16 Nona-K is a 120mm towed gun with the same armament as the 2S9 Nona-S. Merging gun, mortar, and howitzer capabilities, it fires various projectiles, including NATO's 120mm rounds. Deployed in Russian motorised infantry, its effectiveness matches 152/155mm howitzer ammunition.
k2oKDwovEnQjuMtwQTL4.name: 2B16 Nona-K

recognising_features.2b16nonak_79w0tik3evdhnywws30b.jpg: The Nona-K is a small weapon system, with the gun sitting low to the ground with two small wheels. The shield is less than 1m in height and barely offers any protection to the crew.
recognising_features.2b16nonak_e43cgv623s5jxf1qu9p9.jpg: The 2B16 Nona-K has an obviously short barrel for a towed artillery piece, this is due to it in fact being classified as a 120mm mortar. Unlike a standard mortar it has a unique cage-like muzzle break. It has split trails, like all other Soviet towed howitzers. The key recognising feature is the short barrel.

kBgPcBK7BMOZE7fOxDMi.description: The T-72B3 Obr.2014 is a modification of the T-72B3, it was produced in small numbers for the 2014 Russian Tank Biathlon event, the upgrades include a commanders panoramic sight, mounted on the centre of the top of the turret, despite being produced for the tank biathlon, some of these tanks have seen service in the Russian Armed Forces, mainly during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, used in small numbers by the 37th Guards Motor Rifle Brigade, with Ukrainian forces capturing some. The tank is incorrectly known as the T-72B3M
kBgPcBK7BMOZE7fOxDMi.name: T-72B3 Obr.2014

recognising_features.t72b3obr.2014_q7dquvput9e4tqup7hjc.jpg: The single recognising feature of the T-72B3 Obr.2014 is the commanders panoramic sight in the centre of the turret, it is mounted on an elevated fitting, this feature massively increases the lethality and reduces engagement times of the tank, it is the only Russian tank alongside the T-90M which has a hunter killer system, similar to that of western tanks.

kql0-XJgsbUQePxEgF8R.description: The K2 Black Panther is a next generation South Korean main battle tank designed by the South Korean Agency for Defense Development and manufactured by Hyundai Rotem. The K2 Black Panther combines an auto-loaded 55 caliber 120 mm main gun, advanced composite armour along with hard and soft-kill active protection systems.
kql0-XJgsbUQePxEgF8R.name: K2

recognising_features.k2_24xlkcbovfllas6ps4gt.jpg: At this view of the rear you’ll see the large bustle rack for crew stowage, there is a prominent cutout for the final drive, there is also louvred for the cooling fans and the exhaust at the rear left.
recognising_features.k2_lw0hw7dw6uyotek9eaxf.jpg: The turret is almost wedge shaped, it is thinner at the front and gradually goes thicker towards the rear; you will notice the right rounded commanders panoramic sight in front of his hatch, the driver is seated on the left with 3 periscopes.
recognising_features.k2_mkrrk6ro3vv246ip4cgg.jpg: The K2 Black Panther is quite a distinctive tank with a very modern look, you will notice the hull is heavily based on the M1 Abrams series of tanks, the turret is of its own design, with a very prominent large gun mantlet, a prominent cut out for the gunners sight on the left side of the turret, also the rails down the side of the turret. There is a noticeable horizontal part of the frontal hull dividing the upper and lower glacis plates.

kyviQbHsEHPL89d4LV2p.description: The Tornado-G is the upgrade to the BM-21, mounted on on the same Ural-4320 6x6 truck, it has a number of missile and software improvements giving it a rumoured range of up to 90km with some rockets.
kyviQbHsEHPL89d4LV2p.name: 2B17 Tornado-G

recognising_features.2b17tornadog_243pplcbre2j0xnrvq5h.jpg: The key recognising features to identify it from the BM-21 are the cleaner appearance and darker green paint job, the addition of an air filter above the right-hand cab wheel.
recognising_features.2b17tornadog_3v9jo755rpe6dxpecg8i.jpg: An aerial shot of a captured 2B17 Tornado-G, note the rectangular shroud at the front of the rocket pods.
recognising_features.2b17tornadog_8mgkucdvat55y8v8fwmj.jpg: A Tornado-G destroyed during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.2b17tornadog_z51mo795fduk4vy9swqk.jpg: There is a rectangular shroud that sits at the front of the rocket pods that isn't present on the BM-21.

kzAd2YPzDS9ez-IwHKBX.description: The BMD-3 differs from the 2 with the introduction of a new hull and turret, although the crew layout remains very similar with the typical BMD fashion of 2 dismounts either side of the driver and 2 in the centre. It is larger than the previous iterations in the series; this hampers the effectiveness of the airborne forces as they cannot drop as many vehicles per plane as they could with the other BMD’s.
kzAd2YPzDS9ez-IwHKBX.name: BMD-3

recognising_features.bmd3_0nux8q8j2ezz9ef6142d.jpg: The ATGM launch tube is visible in this photo, moving down, the vehicle has 5 equally spaced diecast roadwheels, there are 4 top rollers for the track.
recognising_features.bmd3_e1vn2cxmumx4eqaqg300.jpg: Here is a size comparison of the series. Left to right - BMD-3, BMD-2, BMD-1
recognising_features.bmd3_fmdpzx6c6jop9g1q1n9x.jpg: Here you can see the hatches on the front hull, as well as the ATGM launch mount in the centre of the hatches on the turret, towards the rear you can see the similarity with the previous iterations.
recognising_features.bmd3_rh4dbp48tlqlt54su6po.jpg: The turret is reminiscent of the BMP-2, it is wider than that of the BMD-2 and is now a 2 man turret, it has the ATGM launch tube on the top of the turret-mounted centrally (Not mounted on this photo). It has 3 SGD's on either side of the turret. The BMD-3’s new hull has the general overall shape of the BMD style hull but is actually larger and has some new differences, the front hull has a lip which splits the upper and lower glacis plate, on either side of the upper glacis plate you can see the hull mounted weapon systems, moving up you can see the centrally mounted drivers position with 3 periscopes, he has 2 dismounts either side of his position.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Algeria,Angola,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Benin,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Bulgaria,Burundi,Cambodia,Cameroon,Cape Verde,Central African Republic,Chad,Republic of the Congo,Cuba,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Equatorial Guinea,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Guinea,Guinea-Bissau,Hungary,India,Iraq,Kurdistan,Ivory Coast,Kyrgyzstan,Laos,Lesotho,Libya,Madagascar,Maldives,Mali,Moldova,Transnistria,Mongolia,Myanmar,Namibia,North Korea,Palestine,Peru,Poland,Romania,Russia,Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic,Serbia,Slovakia,Slovenia,Somalia,Sudan,Syria,Tajikistan,Tanzania,Turkmenistan,Transnistria,Ukraine,Vietnam,Yemen,Zambia,Zimbabwe

l3BWJkmodiq36ROvJuiU.description: A Soviet developed Recce vehicle, designed to replace the BRDM-1, it would usually be found in the recce screen. The BRDM-2 was extensively exported like most Soviet vehicles and is still in service with more than 30 countries.
l3BWJkmodiq36ROvJuiU.name: BRDM-2

recognising_features.brdm2_boaa4pq3ofkmcc15b6hs.jpg: The BRDM-2 has a small one man ‘frying pan’ conical shaped turret, mounting the weapon systems centrally; it has no hatch. The commander and driver sit in the front hull side by side with 2 windows with armoured shutters, they also have periscopes above the windows for when they close the shutters. The hull is boat shaped with a large plate on the lower glacis, this is the trim vane for amphibious operations and can be internally raised by the driver. The side of the vehicle has a prominent bulge of viewing blocks in the centre below the turret on either side. There are 2 exhausts, one either side they look like the type of back box you’d see on an older car/van and give a good thermal signature.
recognising_features.brdm2_ns6l3558edhyzcdzva7o.jpg: There are 4 headlights overall, 2 day 2 IR, IR lights being on the outside. The lower hull has flat sides after the lip that goes around the hull for its amphibious capabilities, the roadwheels have large rounded cutouts, there are 2 half moon shaped cutouts in between the roadwheels.

lCZFijhUHZ33okDBnGgg.name: 9K33 Osa
lCZFijhUHZ33okDBnGgg.description: The 9K33 Osa, NATO designation SA-8 'Gecko', is a highly mobile short range surface to air missile system. The 9A33 TELAR was the first SAM to encorporate an integral radar, which allowed fire units to act autonomously. A battery consists of 4 x TELAR, 2 x transloaders and a variety of radar configurations including 'Long Track' or 'Flat Face'. The missile has a range of approximately 9 km, up to an altitude of 16,000ft.

recognising_features.9k33osa_4udnev9acc6qt90ard3o.jpg: The SA-8 has two banks of 3 x 9M113 missiles that flank the radar system.
recognising_features.9k33osa_80fkq1j7ffytat5lea53.jpg: The 9T217 transloader is used to reload the 9M33 missiles, it has a reported reload time of 5 minutes per TELAR.
recognising_features.9k33osa_flq66kvh6zqy5jn4oddn.jpg: The 9A33 TELAR is mounted on the BAZ-5937 amphibious chassis. It has 6 wheels with a sloped hull at the front and a flat section at the rear. The SA-8 superstructure is mounted slightly foward on the chassis.
recognising_features.9k33osa_uxp1m2ilxcfsjt2fyy65.jpg: The 'Land Roll' integral radar consists of a raised, oval-shaped meshed detection radar and three acquisition and fire control radars. The centre radar is rectancular with a curved bottom and is flank by two smaller circular radars.

lEhsAnUXqei8MKeGCT74.description: The T-72A is a Soviet/Russian MBT first entering service in 1979, it is an upgrade on the older T-72 including an LRF, an upgraded FCS, thicker composite armour on the turret and hull front. It is one of the most widely used tanks in the world, still in use today. The T-72 was first designed as an emergency model to be produced in a time of war, this was because it was cheaper to produce than the complex T-64.
lEhsAnUXqei8MKeGCT74.name: T-72A

recognising_features.t72a_er8j8yrrwj18agjrejoh.jpg: Moving to the hull, there are 6 equally spaced roadwheels, with a single pin track design signifying the tank isn’t as modern, the exhaust is on the rear left unlike the T-64’s which is on the rear. On the front you will see a ‘V’ shaped splash plate for the driver, with a single vision periscope.
recognising_features.t72a_h0chqm0pcf3yitrijwrn.jpg: The T-72A is easily confused with a T-64A, ways to differentiate between the turret are the SGD’s, on the right side a 5 dischargers in a ‘U’ configuration, on the left side there’s a row of 6 with one above the 6th discharger. There’s also a lack of storage boxes around the left front cheek, the IR searchlight now moves to the right hand side of the gun, the snorkel at the rear is also much smaller than that of the T-64A.
recognising_features.t72a_qn0zshnufvcwif87wvay.jpg: This is a view in TI, the heat from the exhaust will be significant on the left hand side. The exhaust points downwards so this will leave a prominent signature on the ground.

lTHuZCRm3XMWWOMHxgVQ.description: The Ka-52K 'Katran' is a naval variant of the Ka-52 'Alligator'. It is modified for use aboard naval vessels with shorter, foldable winglets and rotors. This means the aircraft can take up less space on the flight deck of aircraft carriers.
lTHuZCRm3XMWWOMHxgVQ.name: Ka-52K

recognising_features.ka52k_wscwsxj7puu1a0y3cr0r.jpg: The only external difference on the Ka-52K are the folding winglets that only have 2 hard points. This reduced width allows more platforms to be carried aboard ships.

lXf_dKHgsO0sAHNhDGxt.description: The 1V18 Klyon-1 'Maple-1' is an artillery command and forward observation for MLRS and mortar batteries. The vehicle is based on the BTR-60PB,  Its turret has been replaced with one of a different shape and unarmed, often called a “Darth Vader” turret due to its resemblance to the characters helmet.  The turret houses day and night observation equipment as well as a laser rangefinder and laser designator.  The turret has a hatch. The vehicle also has a 4kW generator so that the vehicle can operate it's systems without the main engine being on, a fire direction computer, 4 radios and an aiming circle inside the turret, an aiming circle is an instrument for measuring horizontal and vertical angles and magnetic azimuths in determining gunnery data and laying guns and in artillery surveying.  Later versions replace the radio teletype with a ruggedized laptop computer and one of the long-range radios with a data-capable version, and add more vision equipment and GLONASS.
lXf_dKHgsO0sAHNhDGxt.name: 1V18 Klyon-1

recognising_features.1v18klyon1_9s623unt137iiyvc49cs.jpg: The 1V18 is based on a BTR-60PB hull, with the main difference being the turret on top. It is rounded at the bottom with a rectangular shape at the front for the specialised sighting systems, one on each side with a gap in the centre of the frontal turret, the turret is traversable.
recognising_features.1v18klyon1_yw0ld59q9z0ehnoq29uu.jpg: Seen here is the turret with the sight doors open, they open towards the centre of the vehicle. The sight on the right side(left as you look at it) has 2x optics, one being rounded. The sight on the left is a single large square.

ld060HviDF2BBIQNSvvV.description: The T-72B3 Obr.2022 is the latest iteration of the T-72 tank series, leaning into lessons learned from Ukraine the upgrade brings enchanced protection above all. It includes more 4S22 ERA around the turret rear, the snorkel kit and stowage bins have been omitted, probably due to bridge crossings being preferred instead of amphibious assaults, more Kontakt-5 blocks on top of the turret, protection around the gun mantlet, which previously was a weakpoint and also an ERA plate on the mudflap. This entry is not complete as the tank has only been seen and photographed a few times, so this entry will be updated when more information is available.
ld060HviDF2BBIQNSvvV.name: T-72B3 Obr.2022

recognising_features.t72b3obr.2022_6m9b1ov4fj6dudvk4kjk.jpg: This photograph shows the turret roof has been completely covered with ERA blocks, it must be noted that individual crews on both sides of the war in Ukraine have done this to some of their tanks.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2022_b6y7s21968aupzmag7a9.jpg: The T-72B3 Obr.2022 resembles the T-72B3 Obr.2016 overall, but brings some new features previously unseen on Russian tanks, going off the numbers you can see an ERA plate on the mudflap, which gives protection to the track and idler. The protection around the gun mantlet in the form of ERA, this is a weakspot on Russian/FSU tanks as previously it was not covered by ERA.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2022_ndwwbke473t4xxyqud4p.jpg: The sideskirts are now the full length of the vehicle side, previously they were 3/4 length with bar armour at the rear, it now seems bar armour has been omitted from the tank. The side of the turret shows 4 ERA blocks arranged in a square, very similar to the T-80BV style of layout.
recognising_features.t72b3obr.2022_ru868qepzifh9ndnna02.jpg: The rear of the turret is completely covered with 4S22 ERA blocks to enhance protection and the snorkel kit and stowage bins have been omitted, probably due to bridge crossings being preferred instead of amphibious assaults.

lhp7Ims_I_dTqm_BHd4Y.description: The D-30 is a towed howitzer in service since 1960. It uses the 122mm 2A18 gun, mounted on a tripod which folds away to become the towing aparatus when in transit. The D-30 is one of the most commonly used light role howitzers in the world and has a range of up to 21km (RAP).
lhp7Ims_I_dTqm_BHd4Y.name: D-30

recognising_features.d30_xjukbvdp6l7igmzc0hjw.jpg: The D-30 is easy to recognise to the D-20 from its unique mounting, the arms fold out to form a tripod. The muzzle break is similiar to the D-20, however it has a large towing eye welded to the bottom of it, allowing the gun to be towed. Another key recoginise feature is the recoil system that is a tube that sits directly above the barrel. The raised wheels also tell this system apart from other towed guns.
recognising_features.d30_zbm29pcrc0js86291wpn.jpg: When stowed, the D-30s arms are folded towards the front of the gun and secured to the barrel, allowing the howitzer to be towed.

lm6clPa2YCyHuxVMW1QE.description: The GAZ-Tigr is a Russian designed IMV (Infantry Mobility Vehicle), it has replaced the BRDM-2 as the in service recce vehicle for the Russian army, it is resistant to calibres up to 7.62mm and is extremely mobile.
lm6clPa2YCyHuxVMW1QE.name: GAZ Tigr

recognising_features.gaztigr_578cawg22p8pmuzxn7e0.jpg: The vehicle has a hatch on top with pintle mounts for the mentioned weapons, the windows are armoured glass, down the sides there are 2 small pill shaped windows. The front engine bay is curved towards the front with a raised section in the centre. The front has bull bars with 2 circular headlights, with indicators on each side, moving down there is a mount for the winch.

lz92lbxKJp7sag2PkNOX.description: The Achzarit Mk.1 is a Heavy-APC, based on the T-54/55 hull. The turret has been removed to make space for the dismount compartment, as well as the original superstructure. The engine was moved to make way for the rear door. The vehicle is extremely heavily armoured, given that it weighs 44t, approximately 14t of that is armour alone.
lz92lbxKJp7sag2PkNOX.name: Achzarit Mk.1

recognising_features.achzaritmk.1_ajxplmhokn45gyn0a5ge.jpg: The Achzarit is wide due to its armour package, the front glacis plate is heavily sloped. The armour panelling on the sides ends around 3/4 of the way down, the running gear is the same as a T-55, with a prominent gap between the 1st and 2nd roadwheels, with the rest being equally spaced.
recognising_features.achzaritmk.1_k6wcool5kd4q37aq4m52.jpg: The rear door is off to the right.

m1CWTge_6P2mrNc7--hP.name: ZTZ-99
