m1CWTge_6P2mrNc7--hP.description: The ZTZ-99 is an advancement of the ZTZ-98, taking obvious inspiration from both Russian and Western designs, the tank, like its advanced relative the ZTZ-99A is the superior MBT fielded by the PLA, it is found in Heavy Combined Arms Manoeuvre Brigades. The tank has a fire control system and a high first round hit probability, the gunner is equipped with thermal sights and the commander also has an independent thermal sight, showing the modernity of the tank.

recognising_features.ztz99_nvrier190s4et26aqv0o.jpg: The side of the hull is low profile, the exhaust is a small square approximately 3/4 of the way down the hull, there is an exhaust on both sides. The roadwheels have prominent gaps between the 2nd and 3rd, 3rd and 4th and 4th and 5th. The sideskirts are pointed at the bottom and have small rectangular holes on each skirt, likely to aid in mounting/dismounting the vehicle. The turret side and rear has a bustle rack which is covered with ERA, where the number is painted you can make out the lines of each ERA tile.
recognising_features.ztz99_vr27spxd2u9byjw581x7.jpg: The ZTZ-99 has a generally quite Russian looking hull, with a sloping upper frontal plate and a single drivers periscope, in front of the drivers periscope are 5 ERA blocks, which then end to provide space for the 2 headlights which are placed quite high up the hull. At the nose of the hull, there are 7 ERA blocks which also give way for the tow hooks. The turret is very western looking and is reminiscent of a Leopard 2A5, it has the wedge style frontal turret, which is provided by the integral ERA on the turret front, a point to note is that on the ZTZ-99A the turret front is less wedge shaped and is slightly more flat on the front. There are 2 banks of 5x SGD's on either side of the turret which stick out prominently. The gunner has a rectangular low profile sight and the commander has an independent sight fitted just underneath his HMG. Behind the gunners hatch is the JD-3 laser warning and dazzler system.
recognising_features.ztz99_3tp60qr6xhzv7sr1ut7b.jpg: A few distinguishing points between the ZTZ-99 and ZTZ-96/99's are as follows. The drivers periscope is centrally mounted with a single periscope, the headlights on the ZTZ-99 are round, the headlights on the ZTZ-99A are square, the ZTZ-96 has 6 smoke grenade dischargers per bank, whereas the ZTZ-99 has 5.

m82Kwc6OKG2bqlel3ky9.description: A dedicated combat recce variant of the BMP-1, it retains the same hull but has a new larger 2 man turret with new capabilities, including new sighting sytems, terrain surveying and mine detection devices and the PSNR-5K ‘Tall mike’ radar system. It has the autoloader for the 73mm 2A28 removed and carries significantly less rounds; due to its role not needing as much ammunition to the recce nature of the vehicle. The BRM-1K is usually found in recce coys of armoured/mechanised brigades.
m82Kwc6OKG2bqlel3ky9.name: BRM-1K

recognising_features.brm1k_amywgiuch5zzj40cxp2v.jpg: Some more recognising features are the difference in periscopes in the hull; the drivers periscopes remain the same but what was the BMP-1 Commanders position now has only 1 periscope instead of 3. You can see at the rear it changes from 4 hatches to 2 on the infantry compartment, it now contains operators for the radar and other devices.
recognising_features.brm1k_gm2eou66179acs0kzde3.jpg: The most prominent recognising features on this vehicle is the new wider turret, although reminiscent and easily confused with BMP-2, remembering the 73mm 2A28gun is key to saving confusion, as well as that is the difference sighting systems and also the PSNR-5K radar at the rear (when raised). Another feature is the addition of the 6 SGD’s fitted around the turret, 3 on either side. Firing ports have been reduced from 8(BMP-1) to 3.
recognising_features.brm1k_yjq688f6gpom51yjrnmd.jpg: Underneath the moss and tree bark is a BRM-1K, you can see the radar cover is open, although the radar itself is not raised.

mPhus_YglByULR-1dzg3.description: The BMP-1P was the first large modernisation of the BMP-1, lessons learnt from the 1973 Yom Kippur war and the Angolan civil war, firepower was enhanced with the addition of the 9M113/9M113 Konkurs ATGM, this massively increased firepower and armour protection, with the downside that the gunner had to exit his hatch and stand outside to fire and guide the missile.
mPhus_YglByULR-1dzg3.name: BMP-1P

recognising_features.bmp1p_vs1hdi6w3nmlsb45s2p3.jpg: Recognising features of the BMP-1P, there is only one main feature which is the addition ofthe new ATGM fitted to the top of the turret, whilst this is a small feature, it is a key one as this greatly increases how threatening this variant is, due to the increase in range, armour penetration and missile speed. Whereas the BMP-1 has the 9M14 fitted above the gun as a bare missile, the BMP-1P now has an 9M113 on the top right of the turret. Although this may seem intricate and unnecessary to learn, the change in ATGM hugely changes the potency of this IFV, for example the effective range of the 9M14 compared to the 9M113 is as follows, 9M14-3km, 9M113-4km. This significantly enhances the lethality of these vehicles, therefore showing the need to recognise the differences with these vehicles.

mY89R4T2dI036TDOfSZN.description: The 9K31 Strela-1, NATO designation SA-9 'Gaskin', is a highly mobile short range surface to air missile. The system was usually deployed alongside ZSU 23-4 'Shilka' anti-aircraft artillery system. The system was succeded by the 9K35 Strela-10.
mY89R4T2dI036TDOfSZN.name: 9K31 Strela-1

recognising_features.9k31strela1_eq6see1dmr8i69xyegtw.jpg: In place of the turret mounted KPVT on the standard BRDM is the SA-9 system comprised of 2 banks of 2 x 9M31 missiles.
recognising_features.9k31strela1_q2kkfmivddq9a8fw6lox.jpg: The Strela-1 is mounted on the BRDM 2 chassis which has 4 wheels and a boat shaped hull. The vehicle is fully amphibious. On the sides at the rear are fold down rails, for use by crews when reloading the system.

mZCd217RPyIlKzcy6AXs.name: CV9035NL
mZCd217RPyIlKzcy6AXs.description: The CV9035NL is a Mk.3A CV90, armed with a Bushmaster III 35/50mm cannon. The Royal Netherlands Army was the first to adopt this version, also selling some to the Estonian Defence Force. The vehicle was the first of the CV90 series to be fully digitised, thanks to the electronic architecture upgrades.

recognising_features.cv9035nl_5v2t2zefh9xhhsa3xqr9.jpg: The CV9035NL is distinctive with it's sloping frontal turret, the turret is also distinctive with it's inset smoke grenade dischargers, of which there are 5 on each side of the turret. The main armament mantletless and has a prominent muzzle brake. The coax is on the extreme left of the front turret (right as you look at it).
recognising_features.cv9035nl_0l4tmr2h3migfqh23wew.jpg: The hull is heavily sloped with the driver sat on the left side (right as you look at it) with 3 periscopes. The gunner has a tall prominent sight on the right side (left as you look at it) along with a long stowage bin on the right side as well.
recognising_features.cv9035nl_rn70ege1rcl5s2bwfv7k.jpg: The rear entrance for dismounts is a ramp, the hull is raised at the dismount compartment, the exhaust is on the right rear, this is where you will get the thermal signature of it.
recognising_features.cv9035nl_03423spx1pndq1e6yvuh.jpg: The CV9035NL has the final drive at the front, with 7 equally spaced roadwheels and an idler at the rear, the hull is flat and is prominently raised towards the rear in order to make room for the dismounts.

moTJOOgnQAu9n4DeBj4F.description: The Leer-2 is a Russian EW vehicle based on the Gaz Tigr-M, the EW suite can be used both static and on the move, all of the antennae are mounted on the platform on the vehicle roof, when static there are another 2 additional antennae which are telescopic and can be raised. The EW suite is capable of jamming, and suppressing radio-electronic means including cell phone systems.
moTJOOgnQAu9n4DeBj4F.name: Leer-2

recognising_features.leer2_sgvv3t1a1vwxqrwi6ls2.jpg: When the vehicle is static, two other antennae can be raised by the crew.
recognising_features.leer2_xxznniq2dtdg80704alu.jpg: The Leer-2 hull is based on the Gaz Tigr-M. The main differences here are the centre side windows have been omitted, the left side one being replaced with an electronic panel. The roof of the vehicle has a large structure, with antennae fitted to it, including a large black object in the centre, which is reminiscent of the streamlined roof storage boxes on civilian cars.

nRc0ho4s8k7w9DCq-EW3.description: The ZSU 57-2 is a self-propelled anti-aircraft gun (SPAAG). The naming convention is simple, the 57 is the calibre of the autocannons and the 2 is the number. This convention is applied to all soviet anti-aircraft guns. It was designed primarily to engage low flying aircraft such as helicopters and was the largest calibre anti-aircraft gun of its time.
nRc0ho4s8k7w9DCq-EW3.name: ZSU 57-2

recognising_features.zsu572_3ezqza5rw9e6syvd3uq7.jpg: The ZSU 57-2 is mounted on on a modified T-54 chassis, with only 4 roadwheels. The turret is a large dome, with the two auto-cannons protruding from the front.

oJ3ZtLCQpEbO98DWcdmp.description: The 2S19 Msta-S is an upgrade to the 2S3 Akatsiya system and is the current primary in service 152mm howitzer in Russian ground forces. The 2A46 howitzer is mounted on a T-80 chassis, although it has the T-72 diesel engine instead of the gas turbine engine used in T-80s. It rivals in service NATO howitzers such as the US M-109 A6 Paladin and British AS90. It has a range of 25km with standard projectiles and up to 40km with rocket assisted projectiles (RAP).
oJ3ZtLCQpEbO98DWcdmp.name: 2S19 Msta

recognising_features.2s19msta_4igqgp5h6n98xpt3hzv2.jpg: The key recognising feature of the 2S19 is the massive square 2A46 gun turret. The barrel lock is another obvious feature, the triangular frame being nearly as wide as the tracks.
recognising_features.2s19msta_52g87vsqimnc3f2lcwgv.jpg: The barrel is as long as the chassis, with a fume extractor exactly half way along the barrel. The muzzle break has 3 baffles, unlike the 2S3 (which has 2) or the 2S35 (which has 5).
recognising_features.2s19msta_nt8s60laca3up9gp8n1c.jpg: View from the commanders hatch showing the NSVT and two recoil tubes above the barrel.
recognising_features.2s19msta_tf85qvbj9h23ftcvdzsi.jpg: The 2S19 is mounted on the T-80 chassis, because of the size difference however, the road wheels are in a slighty different configuration (1-2-3-456). As per the T-80 the final drive is to the rear, with the top rollers being obscured by flaps.
recognising_features.2s19msta_zyb7jrostwcr2f1iytcy.jpg: 2S19 Msta-S that was abandoned in Ukraine after going off road (2022).

about.operators: Jordan, Poland, Romania, Singapore, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, United States of America, Australia, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Morocco, Taiwan

o_7Of5_isEKkCuX92fdb.description: HIMARS, short for High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, is a highly mobile and versatile weapon system used by various armed forces. Mounted on a 5-ton truck chassis, it features a rocket pod capable of launching up to six rockets or a single missile. With its compact design, the HIMARS offers rapid deployment and maneuverability on different terrains. It provides long-range precision firepower, enabling effective strikes against various targets, including enemy positions and armored vehicles. The vehicle's advanced communication systems enhance its integration into modern warfare networks, allowing for real-time target information and synchronized attacks. Overall, HIMARS is a reliable and effective artillery system that combines mobility, firepower, and versatility.
o_7Of5_isEKkCuX92fdb.name: M142 HIMARS

recognising_features.m142himars_37rv5cu19eb5pod2koh4.jpg: The M269 launcher loader module (LLM) configured for ATACMs.
recognising_features.m142himars_47gkda5vmgkj4l6r8ym1.jpg: The M142 is mounted on the FMTV 6x6 tactical truck.
recognising_features.m142himars_bdi745boa4tgf4prctdu.jpg: The cab of the vehicle has two windows, the one on the drivers side (left) is wider to give a better field of vision.
recognising_features.m142himars_x6yasmuzwcuca7p5m7ix.jpg: The M269 launcher loader module (LLM) is wedge shaped with an extendable crane secton on top used to reload missiles. The LLM can be configured with 6 missiles in 2 banks of 3 or with one large section for ATACMs.

odQejwCiEnsbSJu1LNCo.description: The BMP-T (incorrectly called the terminator) is classed as a tank support fighting vehicle, the idea first sprouted from the Soviet-Afghan war as well as the First Chechen War, the idea essentially is that of a dedicated anti-personnel vehicle, to provide intimate support to tanks for them to continue with their role and not get bogged down, or killed by infantry. Its army trials were long and drawn out, beginning in 1998 and only entering service in 2021, with the 90th Guards Tank Brigade, in Boguchar, part of the Central Military District. It is heavily armed and armoured, the guns are fed different ammunition, for example one 30mm is loaded with HEI-T and one with APDS. The turret is unmanned with all the crew sat in the hull. It first saw service in Eastern Ukraine in May, 2022.
odQejwCiEnsbSJu1LNCo.name: BMP-T

recognising_features.bmpt_0bbs16k7ay7fmfdf72jw.jpg: A crewman loading the 30mm gun feed with ammunition.
recognising_features.bmpt_3ujdq3y7rq0va1x8hkeh.jpg: 4 x BMP-T being transported prior to the invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.bmpt_iqf8fe4hos8cwjfmsalw.jpg: The front of the BMP-T has multiple vision windows and cameras for the crew, on either side of the superstructure are the 2x AGS-30 GMG launchers in ball mounts, down the side you can see where the exhaust is, the bar armour provides sufficient space for the exhaust gas to escape as well as still providing some protection.
recognising_features.bmpt_prk5m3shxb88lz6tsllc.jpg: The BMP-T hull is essentially that of a T-72, although the superstructure changes, as does the side, the side skirts are now fully armoured all the way down, the exhaust is covered by bar armour. The turret  is extremely prominent, with its 2 ATGM launchers sticking out of either side of the gun mounts, these carry 2x 9M120 Ataka ATGM’s each. On the rear left of the turret is all the meteorological sensors for the weapon systems, in the centre of the turret is a sloped mount for the twin 30mm 2A42 autocannons, on the right of the turret is the commander's panoramic sight. Moving down the turret is a hatch with periscopes covering the front and sides, next to that is the gunner's primary sight.
recognising_features.bmpt_rzb7xytgdsd94dukaui5.jpg: The rear of the BMP-T shows how the superstructure has been raised, you can also see the addition of extra stowage boxes and the bar armour covering the rear part of the vehicle.
recognising_features.bmpt_wtoi99cf12kyvqxh3pf4.jpg: It should be noted that some of the BMP-T’s seen in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine had the 2S24 ERA bags fitted to the sides in place of the standard ERA side plates.

pngsFa6SQsJB8MJ_LZHz.name: 9T452
pngsFa6SQsJB8MJ_LZHz.description: The 9T452 Transporter loader is a part of the BM-27 Uragan family, its role is to transport and load missiles for the launchers, it is based on the same ZIL-135 8x8 truck as the launcher, it has a capacity of 16 missiles, the same as the launcher, so it can load 1 launcher system, the loading process takes around 20 minutes.

recognising_features.9t452_cgvsiwqfmynbhvbohx5z.jpg: The ZIL-135 chassis remains the same as the one on the BM-27, apart from the flatbed at the rear, as we can see with the cab it is unchanged. The key is the lack of any obvious launcher, instead a flatbed with 2 guide holes for the missiles to sit in, which have a format of 3 at the top, 2 in the centre and 3 at the bottom, adding up to 8, its the same on both sides. With a large crane system in the centre, as you can see here the sides are lowered during loading.
recognising_features.9t452_p875bfajn8lupuzvqkjb.jpg: Rear of the vehicle showing the differences between the launcher vehicle (left) and the 9T452 on the right.

ppK6NR_lK4ynbBU33NDD.name: ZTD-05
ppK6NR_lK4ynbBU33NDD.description: The Type 05/ZTD-05 is a fire support vehicle version of the Type-05 IFV, designed to give heavier fire support to the Type-05 IFV, it is based on the same platform, albeit with a change in turret to accommodate the larger gun. The hull remains very similar.

recognising_features.ztd05_2u5mmso1ynaklikbiweu.jpg: Here is the Type 05 in the amphibious role, the only feature that could help with recognition for this against the Type 05 IFV is that this version always seem to have side skirts fitted, whereas the Type 05 IFV does not, for hull recognising features, please see the Type 05 IFV.
recognising_features.ztd05_yq5lzlhv18ax61cq3jzu.jpg: The turret and long hull can give this vehicle the appearance of an SPG, namely the 2S1 Gvozdika. To differentiate the turret is much taller, the turret cheeks slope to sides with the centre of the turret front sloping upwards. The gunner has a sight on the left hand side of the turret, towards the front. There are 2 banks of 4 SGD’s on either turret cheek, laid out in a horizontal row configuration.

prSDUP3P-yXaEEXEzdux.description: The ZBL-08 is an IFV belonging to the Type-08 wheeled AFV family, this is the original IFV variant with a turret containing a 30mm ZPT-99 auto-cannon and a dismount compartment at the rear, it can optionally carry 2x HJ-73C ATGM's on the turret sides. This vehicle family forms the backbone of the Chinese medium manoeuvre brigade vehicles, the vehicle is fully amphibious and is in service with both the PLA Ground Forces and PLA Naval Marine Corps.
prSDUP3P-yXaEEXEzdux.name: ZBL-08

recognising_features.zbl08_89t7om8963vm53gbiyx7.jpg: The vehicle has a single rear door which can be seen here, as mentioned previously the propellors can be seen here. The rear of the turret has a bustle rack for stowage, it is worth noting that with the PLA naval camouflage worn by the dismounts, this vehicle belongs to the PLA Naval Marine Corps.
recognising_features.zbl08_cmv6eju5qmetsp4oa0jl.jpg: The ZBL-08 has the look of a large modern wheeled IFV, the hull is distinctively western inspired, it is sloped on the front with the driver seated on the right side of the vehicle as you look at it, with the dismount section commander sat behind the driver, the driver has a single wide view periscope. There is a straight bar across the frontal hull before it slopes downwards which contains a pair of headlights with protective grilles over them. The hull sides slope slightly upwards and have grab handles at the top for mounting/dismounting the vehicle with a single periscope towards the rear for the dismount compartment. The 4 roadwheels are equally spaced with a prominent gap in the centre, there are 2 propellors at the rear for amphibious operations, you can see it just behind the final roadwheel.
recognising_features.zbl08_vppopex5kker8gsu721a.jpg: The ZBL-08 has the engine mounted on the left hand side as you look at it there are some grilles on the upper hull side next to the engine, this potentially may be for the air induction. Above this is a small exhaust coming out the top of the hull. On this side of the hull there is a single grab handle as well as another grille towards the hull rear. The turret is angled with the main gun in the centre, two pairs of 6x SGD's sit either side of the main gun, the 2x HJ-73C ATGM's are seen on the turret sides, the missiles are exposed and are not tube launched. The gunner and vehicle commander have two small boxes in front of their hatches, their hatches open forwards.

about.operators: Egypt,Greece,Japan,Saudi Arabia,Turkey,Bahrain,Finland,France,Germany,Israel,Italy,South Korea,United Kingdom,Ukraine,United States of America

qP90SmAoDAU-cpapfkv1.description: The M270 Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS) is an long-range artillery system that can fire up to 12 rockets. It first saw use in the Gulf War in 1991 and was developed to match Soviet weapons of the time, such as the BM-21 'Grad' and BM-27 'Uragan'. The system is designed to be fully autonomous, with the launcher capable of recieved targets and engaging independantly from a command post, this enables MLRS batterys to disperse on the battlefield to avoid the threat of counter battery fires. It has several designations given by different countries; United States of America M270A1/A2 (upgraded engine & FCS to enable use of the PrSM), United Kingdom M270B1, Germany MARS II, France Lance Roquette Unitaire (LRU), Italy MLRS-I, Finland M270D1.
qP90SmAoDAU-cpapfkv1.name: M270

recognising_features.m270_4xbrs1a9bk1f22nzkrgm.jpg: The Loader, Launcher, Module (LLM) is a large rectangle that takes up approximately 2/3's of the hulls length. Each pod contains 6 rockets, a total of 12.
recognising_features.m270_7c1ia97xczpm4pzj46ab.jpg: The M270 system is mounted on a lengthened Bradley IFV chassis. The roadwheels are in a 2-2-2 configuration with the drive sprocket at the front and two rollers above the spaces between the wheels.
recognising_features.m270_b4yvxic1m9afqve32v90.jpg: The cab is rectangular with a slant on the front face. It can be uniquely identified by the three windows, two small and one large (the drivers window). Note that nation dependant, the windows may have different types of protection.
recognising_features.m270_k9yi9lkagrku7yeu9zks.jpg: An M270 with its LLM raised, ready for firing.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Algeria,Angola,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Brazil,Bulgaria,Burkina Faso,Burundi,Chad,Republic of the Congo,Cuba,Cyprus,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Equatorial Guinea,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Guinea,Hungary,India,Indonesia,Iraq,Kazakhstan,Kyrgyzstan,Libya,Mali,Mozambique,Myanmar,Namibia,Nicaragua,Niger,Nigeria,North Korea,North Macedonia,Pakistan,Peru,Poland,Russia,Rwanda,Serbia,Senegal,Sierra Leone,Sri Lanka,Sudan,Syria,Tajikistan,Turkmenistan,Uganda,Ukraine,United States of America,Uzbekistan,Venezuela,Vietnam,Yemen,Zimbabwe

qPXUAek5Buqrrx06aRSF.description: The Mi-35M was originally an export only variant of the Mi-24 Hind. However, as a capable attack helicopter, Russia has encorporated into its air force designated the Mi-24VM. It is similiar in many respects as the originally Hind, just with improved sensors, armament and a defensive suite (including radar warning sensors and flares).
qPXUAek5Buqrrx06aRSF.name: Mi-35M

recognising_features.mi35m_4kwxfyum4ygbcksxjg5w.jpg: The Mi-35M key recognising feature is the smaller winglets, with only 2 pylons (hard points).
recognising_features.mi35m_t95igyup7rsynecfukke.jpg: Another recognising feature of the Mi-35M is the twin tail rotor blades.
recognising_features.mi35m_vrznwmnl62539yganju5.jpg: The twin GSh-23V 23mm cannons sit in the same place as the Mi-24, beneath the forward most cockpit. An addition to the Mi-35M is the sensors ball that sits behind and right of the guns.

qiCsEAcfy1E8GjV-xdqO.name: 2S34 Hosta
qiCsEAcfy1E8GjV-xdqO.description: The 2S34 Hosta is a modern Russian self-propelled gun/mortar derived from the 2S1 Gvozdika, initially named 2S1M before its present designation. It's an affordable version of the advanced 2S31 Vena, as it repurposes existing vehicles without APS. The 2S34 retains the hull, engine, and drivetrain from the 2S1 but swaps its 122mm 2A31 howitzer for a 120mm 2A80-1 gun/mortar with a distinct square muzzle brake. This gun/mortar is aided by a semi-automatic loader, enhancing the loading speed at high elevations. It offers comparable firepower to the 2S31 Vena, supporting various shells and direct fire capabilities. The 2S34 has armoured protection, an NBC system, and newly added smoke grenade dischargers. Its 300 hp diesel engine maintains mobility in challenging terrains and allows amphibious capabilities. Russia, its sole user, has a limited number of 2S34s, despite its potential advantages.

recognising_features.2s34hosta_8xxl3hzi2och0s7shbsj.jpg: The key recognising feature when compared to the 2S1 Gvozdika is the new 2A80-1 gun, it has a square muzzle break compared to the cylindrical one on the 2S1.
recognising_features.2s34hosta_vee16hb04n496ma25yz8.jpg: The 2S34's upgrades include the addition of smoke dischargers on the sides of the turret, in banks of 3. The vehicle maintains the same MTLBu hull as the 2S1.

r-rjs0XfMhc4C53IA0xV.description:
The BTR-D is the backbone of the VDV mechanised platoon.
The BTR-D was designed on the BMD platform, it was found that space for 4 dismounts was not enough, it was extremely cramped. It was soon decided to design the BTR-D, the hull was extended and the turret removed and replaced with a hatch and a pintle mount.
r-rjs0XfMhc4C53IA0xV.name: BTR-D

recognising_features.btrd_ulp6iqipd4t7lajur1v8.jpg: You will see here the 2 firing ports on the flat side, also the addition of SGD’s at the rear of the raised superstructure,there are 2 either side. The exhaust is in the same place as the BMD-1, for more recognising features of the hull see BMD-1 under the IFV category.
recognising_features.btrd_zcpa0j74xn6u0m0g0p0l.jpg: The BTR-D is based on the BMD-1 hull, it is extended with an extra roadwheel, all of which are evenly spaced, it has 6 Roadwheels, 3 top rollers and the final drive at the rear. The hull is boatshaped with flat sides, at the front there is a splash plate for amphibious operations, you can see it raised here, there is no turret and instead it has a slightly raised superstructure with periscopes around it. The driver has 3 periscopes, with 1 on either side of his hatch.

r0b1F1fOJdnArLPk2e7h.description: The 9S32 "Grill Pan" is the target guidance radar used with the S-300V system. It takes tracks from the 9S457-1 command post and also external assets like an AWACS. It is used to guide the missiles from the S-300V TELARs and LLVs.
r0b1F1fOJdnArLPk2e7h.name: 9S32

recognising_features.9s32_2e2wyfz5juohuzh2iuh7.jpg: The "Grill Pan" radar can be identified by its slightly smaller surface area than the 9S19 "High Screen" detection radar, although it has a similar shape, the corner cutouts are more pronounced.. There is also a tall mast with an antenna used to talk to the missiles in flight.
recognising_features.9s32_8xtaz1mtklsgkvcpjyig.jpg: This image shows the complete S-300V engagement system. From left to right: 9S19 "High Screen", 9S15 "Bill Board", 9A83 TELAR (with 4 x 9M83 "Gladiator" missiles), 9A82 TELAR (with 2 x 9M82 "Giant" missiles) and 9S32 "Grill Pan".
recognising_features.9s32_hcxfaaytnobbu4tb4q69.jpg: The radar has a rectangular array on top of the main radar and three circular sensors below, giving it a unique appearance.

rH267cb21bxWhPjh4TY3.description: The 9S15 "Bill Board" is the all-round search radar used in the S-300V system. It provides initial tracks for the command post, to be refined by the 9S19 "High Screen" before being passed to the 9S32 guidance radar for engagement with "Gladiator" and "Giant" missiles from the TELARs or LLVs.
rH267cb21bxWhPjh4TY3.name: 9S15

recognising_features.9s15_63qs5frvb1cdsya6wknh.jpg: 9S15 "Bill Board", 9S19 "High Screen", 9A82 TELAR, 9A83 TELAR and 9S32 "Grill Pan",
recognising_features.9s15_b3aa4fxfsb38ng075j1f.jpg: Looking at the "Bill Board" from the side makes you understand how it got its NATO designation.
recognising_features.9s15_r4ylj3l88b7bl8e3n7go.jpg: The 9S15 "Bill Board" is a distinctive looking radar, it is large and rectangular without any cut outs. There is what looks like a corrugated rectangular section beneath the main array.

rOB2pE59mm_tL3te_4wr.description:
The 2S5 Giatsint-S is a Soviet produced 152mm SPG, the chassis used is the GM-123 chassis, also used for the 2K11 Krug SAM, Deploying to fire the gun takes 3 minutes, and it can sustain a rate of fire of 5 to 6 rounds per minute. Most of the crew, with the exception of the gunner, deploys outside of the vehicle while firing. It is usually accompanied by an ammunition carrier with an additional 30 rounds of ammunition. It is capable of firing nuclear projectiles.

The 2S5 Giatsint-S is a Soviet produced 152mm SPG, the chassis used is the GM-123 chassis, also used for the 2K11 Krug SAM, Deploying to fire the gun takes 3 minutes, and it can sustain a rate of fire of 5 to 6 rounds per minute. Most of the crew, with the exception of the gunner, deploys outside of the vehicle while firing. It is usually accompanied by an ammunition carrier with an additional 30 rounds of ammunition. It is capable of firing nuclear projectiles.
rOB2pE59mm_tL3te_4wr.name: 2S5 Giatsint-S

recognising_features.2s5giatsints_dd7igmg1a9tnmdft7njt.jpg: The rear of the 2S5 shows the exposed gun breech, along with a large earth stabiliser that is lowered when firing to reduce recoil and keep the vehicle in the same position.
recognising_features.2s5giatsints_ttawel78lmkmur9qb7xn.jpg: The 2S5 Giatsint-S has a prominent 152mm gun, with the breech exposed at the rear, a gun clamp halfway down the vehicle for transport and a prominent 6 baffle muzzle brake. The hull has a prominent look, the vehicle commander has a large cupola on the left side, the driver is seated in front of him with 2 periscopes.It has a splash plate at the front, with 2 headlights either side of the hull. The crew mostly ride in a TCV (Troop carrying vehicle-Truck) until the time to fire comes.
recognising_features.2s5giatsints_zwdx33ibn4bqvnjzv73g.jpg: The running gear has prominent gaps between the 1st-2nd-3rd-4th, the final 3 are equally spaced, the final drive is at the front.

sxqL3waI0d8_sROINmL8.description: The Leopard 2A4 is the 4th variant of the Leopard 2 line of MBT’s it has been upgraded from the previous iteration, having a fire and explosion suppression system, a new digital FCS and an improved turret with titanium/tungsten composite armour. It’s been license produced in Switzerland as the Pz.87 and exported widely, some export variants are modified to suit the nation purchasing.
sxqL3waI0d8_sROINmL8.name: Leopard 2A4

recognising_features.leopard2a4_7iw37m0r5sfzno2gaevb.jpg: The Leopard 2A4 is distinguishable between other Leopard variants by looking at the turret, the turret has flat frontal cheeks, the gunners sight is on the right side of the gun in a cutout portion of the armour, the commanders sight behind it in front of the commanders hatch. Down the rear sides the turret there are SGD’s in rows.
recognising_features.leopard2a4_ddx108oqrkh8onx5wnd9.jpg: The upper glacis plate is almost horizontal, the driver sits on the right side with 3 periscopes; sometimes you will see CES items on the sloped front as seen here with track link.
recognising_features.leopard2a4_ooraaog1brnzlhtlffao.jpg: The rear of the Leopard 2A4 shows Louvre covers for the engine fans, below them you’ll see the dual circular exhausts at the rear. In the centre you have the cross shaped convoy light commonly used by NATO vehicles.
recognising_features.leopard2a4_qe15zxcm4cnfpv64o1q1.jpg: Looking at the hull, it has 7 equally spaced roadwheels, there are 2 footsteps in the side skirts, there’s also 3 armour plates on the front quarter of the hull sides.

tN3VyNEkOocOhbR1a1Sr.description: The T-80BV is an upgrade of the T-80B, although typically a ‘V’ signals the fitting of Kontakt-1, the T-80BV is actually quite different from the T-80B, it includes thicker composite armour on the hull as well as the Kontakt-1 ERA. The T-80BV is famous for the myth of its poor performance in Chechnya, records of T-80 and T-72 losses barely differ, it was just due to the embarrassment that it was blamed, the Russian Army failed to blame the poor crew training and corruption, a lot of tanks went in to Grozny with no ERA due to the plastic explosive being sold off by crews.
tN3VyNEkOocOhbR1a1Sr.name: T-80BV

recognising_features.t80bv_f4seb1shi9f8t0l05sn8.jpg: The turret has some distinctive features, the larger 1G46 gunners primary sight, behind that you will see the TPN-3-49 sight, which has a much more square shape than the sight on the T-72. On the right side in front of the commanders hatch, notice the long rectangle, it is the 1G42 kobra guidance box(with cover fitted), the smoke grenade dischargers fitted at both sides of the turret behind the ERA, the ERA fitted in a one brick clamshell design, the IR searchlight on the right side of the MA.
recognising_features.t80bv_h5f4i0ly8w1x970sjo1z.jpg: You will see here the 4 ERA bricks covering the SGD’s on the right side, also the tracks  now consist of a dual pin design, showing it’s a more modern tank.
recognising_features.t80bv_j2ydtww1orj2j17r5cqr.jpg: The T-80BV differs a lot from previous vehicles covered, the turret is based on that of the T-64B, the hull is of a new design, noticeable features on the hull are the drivers position, it has 3 periscopes opposed to every other T-Series tank which has 1 periscope, the suspension is of a new layout, smaller roadwheels with thick rubber fitted, the road wheels have prominent gaps between the 1st and 2nd, 5th and 6th. You will also notice the rubber flaps on the lower glacis, it has 2 rubber flaps, to save confusion remember it has 2, as the Polish PT-91 has 5 flaps.
recognising_features.t80bv_y7cqnljywb3ox45q879k.jpg: Seen here at the rear of this T-80BV you will notice the exhaust is at the rear of the vehicle, this gives a huge thermal signature at the rear, but also helps you noticing that it’s a T-80 due to the lack of an exhaust on the sides.
recognising_features.t80bv_z990ig885lz7ezd8xr68.jpg: The ERA on the right side is 5 bricks long, the left side is much longer, the ERA on the front glacis is in a widened almost ‘U’ Shape. The snorkel is also a lot thicker than that of T-72.

tTC0W1ty0lI-qm2ZMrd1.description: The Vityaz DT-30P is the amphibious variant of the DT-30, it is an articulated tracked carrier, designed to operate in extreme weather conditions. It was designed to operate in extreme climatic biomes like northern Russia, Siberia and the Far East. They can also be used as recovery vehicles due to the high pull ratio, they also have a very low ground pressure, which is useful for preventing the detonation of mines. The vehicles are used by Russian Army units in extreme climates, as well as civilian companies who conduct scientific research in extreme climates like the Arctic as well as remote and isolated regions like the Northern Islands of Russia. Some vehicles were used in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mostly by the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade. More than a hundred Vityaz vehicles are used in Russia for the transportation of cargo, such as: blocks, cranes and even towers for power lines in hard to reach regions. They serve rescue teams in extreme conditions. When a natural disaster occurs, there are no roads, the Vityaz all-terrain vehicle is a great help.
tTC0W1ty0lI-qm2ZMrd1.name: DT-30P

recognising_features.dt30p_zc3mp7jgs7cmcu4wbami.jpg: The DT-30P differs from the standard 30, the cab is the main difference. The cab has 4 windows across the front instead of 3, the front is also much more flat before the downward slope and the headlights are inset in to cut out squares, the doors are larger than the ones on the DT-30 and the rear of the cab is different, it has large oval exhausts on each side which can be seen here just behind the cab, the rear stowage compartment on the front section is also longer than on the standard DT-30.

tin1afdkmh0bjv3Q7k3W.description: The 5N63S "Flap Lid B" radar, later designated the 30N6 for use with the S-300PMU systems, is the target tracking and missile engagement radar for the S-300PM/PS system. It is an advancement from the "Flap Lid A" radar which could only guide four missiles at a time, the newer version can guide two missiles per target up to max of 6 targets (12 missiles total). It is mounted on the same MAZ-7910 (derived from the MA-543) 8-wheeled utility vehicle as the rest of the S-300PS family (the "Flap Lid A" was trailer mounted). The flap lid works in conjunction with the "Big Bird" detection and "Clam Shell" low altitude radars to be handed targets for engagement.
tin1afdkmh0bjv3Q7k3W.name: 30N6

recognising_features.30n6_3jkjimip7uihnydt57d1.jpg: The front of the radar is relatively featureless, it is large and rectangular with slight curving on the corners. Its simplicity is its key recognising feature, along with the 'what you see is what you get' naming convention of radars by NATO - it is quite simply a flapping lid.
recognising_features.30n6_8yrkog59yehufb68c0il.jpg: The under-side of the 30N6 "Flap Lid B" radar array, note the four circular bulbs on each corner - assumed to be used to separate the radar from touching the roof of the MAZ-7910 when in the collapsed position. There is a mast on the front of the vehicle, just behind the cab to communicate the radar data to the 5k55 "Grumble B" missiles during engagement. The cab features that distinctive cut out on the passenger side like the rest of the S-300PS series. There is a tubular return array that has a canvas shroud directly behind the cab.
recognising_features.30n6_f6f5b7go1bgs0v2fjx4u.jpg: Armenians 30N6 "Flap Lid B" radar seconds before destruction during the 2022 Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict.

tltksFmsvADGsiB1k6mL.name: MT-LB
tltksFmsvADGsiB1k6mL.description: The MTLB is an amphibious APC, it is still widely used by Russia, most commonly in units based in boggy areas, like 138 Bde in St.Petersburg and other units in the far east, this is due to its extremely low ground pressure. It is the base for many variants built upon it.

recognising_features.mtlb_5w2dx1a4lkejm62hwk8w.jpg: The MTLB is a very distinctive vehicle, with an extremely low hull, a tiny one man turret and a very prominent boat shape hull. The front hull has a a prominent point with a clear boat shape for its amphib capabilities. The driver and commanders positions have bullet resistant glass windows with metal covers.
recognising_features.mtlb_kbhy5ekvp7zgw6abrxp8.jpg: The rear of the MTLB has 2 square doors that open outwards.
recognising_features.mtlb_nu1h90tmg9fugrw0e6fr.jpg: It has a centrally mounted engine, so most of the TI signature will appear there, the 6 road wheels are equally spaced on a slack track, the final drive is mounted at the front.
recognising_features.mtlb_w81y22drgie7crvw5p85.jpg: An MTLB in the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine with a self-modified RPO-A Shmel launcher above the turret.

tpflXxC0h7unl38BZONE.description: The T-64BM ‘Bulat’ is a Ukrainian modification of a T-64B, Ukraine has around 2000 T-64’s in various states, due to the Kharkov plant within Ukraine, this was once a Soviet powerhouse for building tanks, after the collapse of the USSR it fell in to Ukraine’s hands, who were left with thousands of ageing models of T-64’s. This modification is extensive, featuring a new autoloader, upgraded power pack, new Nozh (Knife) ERA.
tpflXxC0h7unl38BZONE.name: T-64BM

recognising_features.t64bm_gykv2kuw2w86jf4ag4ph.jpg: The turret of the T-64BM looks very similar to that of the T-80U, some ways to differentiate are with the smoke grenade discharges at the rear sides of the turret rather than across the front, you can also see a meteorological sensor at the rear of the turret for the FCS, the T-80U has an IR searchlight and gaps either side of the gun where there is no ERA, the T-64BM does not have this. It also has a commanders sight different to the T-64BM.
recognising_features.t64bm_hzjtkc1fbevgtgct0s2h.jpg: This is a T-80U, easily confused with the T-64BM, you will notice the differences I mentioned before in ERA, Commanders sight, Meteorological sensor, IR searchlight and SGD’s. Also the obvious differences in roadwheels, Drivers periscopes.
recognising_features.t64bm_tjnjfvu11vc9wykcjmxh.jpg: On the Hull the front glacis plate has ERA snugly fitted giving it a much thicker appearance, there are also ERA panels down the sides towards the front. The roadwheels remain the same as the standard T-64, this is a good feature, as well as the drivers periscope being singular whereas T-80U has 3 periscopes.

tqqySV70s8x-MG_5C9f7.name: 1S19
tqqySV70s8x-MG_5C9f7.description: The 1S19 radar, NATO reporting name 'Straight Flush', is an acquisition and guidance radar assigned to the Kub family of surface to air missiles. The system consists of the 1S11 target acquisition radar and the 1S21 target tracking radar. The radars are mounted on the GM-568 chassis. The detection range is 50km.

recognising_features.1s19straightflush_lhgmk3ru9ycs9wuvb3g5.j: The system can be identifed by its two radars. The bottom rectangluar radar is the 1S11 target acquisition radar, with the circular 1S21 guidance radar mounted on top. The chassis of the GM-568 has 6 road wheels in a 1-1-4 configuration.

tu0Glil8I6wJCLWbk-2n.description: The BMP-3 is a radical modernisation of the BMP series, it is of a completely new design. It is one of the most heavily armed IFV’s in service, with a 100mm main which can fire GLATGM, a 30mm coaxial gun, as well as a 7.62mm coax. It is also amphibious like most of the Russian IFV/APC’s in service. Russia are currently modifying their BMP 3’s.
tu0Glil8I6wJCLWbk-2n.name: BMP-3

recognising_features.bmp3_egq4s6elngqn2ziynb0b.jpg: The hull still resembles a boat shape due to its amphibious capability, there are 3 hatches at the front of the hull, 1 for the driver and 2 for dismounts, when seated they can also operate the 2 hull MG’s. The driver has 5 periscopes, the other 2 hatches have 1 each.
recognising_features.bmp3_esmeaqov71z5g0tkgd91.jpg: The hull remains flat sided all along, the right side has a long rectangular exhaust, the tracks are skinny, it has small roadwheels with prominent gaps between the 2nd-3rd and 5th-6th, with the final drive at the rear, unlike most IFV’s.
recognising_features.bmp3_msu72rpedrkmofck9mqz.jpg: The BMP-3 is a completely new iteration with a newly designed hull and turret, the turret has a similar shape to the BMP-2 except it is larger. It has a much longer 100mm main gun with a 30mm coax, to the right of the gun is an IR searchlight, on either side of the gun are 3 SGD’s. At the rear turret it has 2 whip antenna either side, the gunners sight is a large box shape on the left side of the turret roof.
recognising_features.bmp3_ruu7j8jnoymlxo0b2s0x.jpg: Here is a view of infantry dismounting a BMP-3, the rear doors are small and open outwards with the ceiling hatches providing most of the opening to dismount.

u1RUovZsGxaewjmHagfA.description: The Z-STS Akhmat is a protected mobility vehicle built on the 6x6 chassis of a KamAZ-5350. It is used by Chechen Rosgvardia forces and has seen usage in Ukraine, the vehicle was designed and created in 25 days, solely for use in Ukraine by Chechen troops. The vehicle has protection similar to other Russian protected mobility vehicles, likely protection from small arms up to 7.62mm and fragments.
u1RUovZsGxaewjmHagfA.name: Z-STS Akhmat

recognising_features.zstsakhmat_4hqeb2iq7y4lwucaqv9y.jpg: The front windows have the typical style from Russian MRAP's with a single pane in the centre. There is also a slight visor over the window. The front of the vehicle has a large engine bay, with wide wheel arches. Each door on the aside has windows with the front being the largest. The wheel arches over the rear wheels have stowage bins incorporated into them, above that wheel arch is a small rectangular window.
recognising_features.zstsakhmat_9luta9jfvr80jrybznyd.jpg: The vehicle is typically fitted with an armoured shield for the top cover, the engine compartment slopes heavily. The headlights are angled upwards, with a large grille in the centre.

v5zeizo38QH0PR5frNdu.description: The 5P85T is the trailer TEL of the S-300PS system. The trailer is usually towed by a KrAZ-260 6x6 tow tractor, which is much more affordable than the MAZ-543 rigid body vehicles used to move the self-propelled TELS (5P85S/5P85D). The system can not engage on its own, and must be controlled by a 5P85S 'master' TEL.
v5zeizo38QH0PR5frNdu.name: 5P85T TEL

recognising_features.5p85ttel_5tma7ic2dxfkki666cns.jpg: The S-300PS 5P85T trailer being towed by a KaMAZ-260. The TEL trailer is configured with the same bank of 4 missiles as the rest of the S-300PS family.

vICX3lmI_D7bpeC36V0Y.description: The FV510 ISV (Infantry Section Vehicle) Warrior is a British IFV, originally designed to replace the FV430 APC line, despite this the FV430 is somehow still in service, it appears to be attempting to go for a record of the longest serving armoured vehicle. The Warrior was first delivered to 1st Battalion Grenadier Guards in 1987, with a total of 789 Warriors produced. The Warrior was produced with British armoured infantry doctrine in mind, this being that the IFV drives the infantry section up to the position under armour, the section then dismounts and attacks the position with fire support from the vehicle, none of this lazy infantry stuff like firing ports. The Warrior has lived up to its name, namely in Iraq and Afghanistan. There are varying theatre entry standard applique kits for the Warrior, which will be covered in recognising features.
vICX3lmI_D7bpeC36V0Y.name: FV510

recognising_features.fv510_f17guecbndhqje68rnk8.jpg: Warrior OES (Operational Entry Standard) is the up-armoured version of Warrior for operations, it can be scaled up or down depending on the threat, the versions on Op Herrick in Afghanistan just had bar armour for example. The Warrior shown here seems to be the current OES standard, it is heavily armoured with additional armour to the frontal hull as well as bar armour, ERA along the upper sides with bar armour on the lower sides. The turret has bar armour as well as perspex protection from debris and shrapnel, there is also some kind of ECM antennae at the rear right, left as you look at it.
recognising_features.fv510_n88yuwsue9gue9bjmhxt.jpg: The running gear is typical of that of most IFV's, with final drives at the front, 6 roadwheels with a prominent gap in between the 3rd and 4th and an idler wheel at the rear. There are 3 top rollers with a large one in the centre and 2 smaller ones either side of it, the smaller ones are shorter and further inside the track. The tracks have single track pads on each link which is long and rectangular. As seen here, the exhaust is on the right side, this is where the thermal signature will be seen from mostly, behind it is a long cage stowage bin.
recognising_features.fv510_rf2wvij76o14uswt4vy6.jpg: The Warrior has a quite a large distinctive hull for an IFV, the front of the hull is prominently sloped with engine decks on the right hand side and the driver on the left, as you look at it. The driver has a single periscope on their hatch, but with OES (up-armoured) variants there may be 3 periscopes. The engine louvres usually have a plastic cover over the lower half, as shown here which is mounted on to the four prominent hinges for the engine decks. There are light clusters on either side, behind those are sloping sections which have some equipment stowed on them, as well as camouflage pole mountings, the hull then squares off in order to make room for the fighting compartment, the sides are flat with a large hatch on the left hand side and a stowage bin towards the rear, as well as 2 red squares on either side, which are covers for the engine bay fire extinguishers. The lower frontal hull has 2 large bulges for the final drives, as well as a foot step on the right side, as you look at it.
recognising_features.fv510_uqgvcodxehbxyyfxw6hx.jpg: The rear door is a large square with a perisope on the left hand side, it opens to the right side as shown, there are 2 stowage boxes either side on the rear and a registration plate on the left underneath the stowage box.
recognising_features.fv510_x6xrpjgedvkpkwchxz08.jpg: The Warrior turret is generally quite low profile with the 30mm RARDEN cannon fitted which has a large muzzle, halfway down the gun barrel is a gun cradle. The gun mantlet is a large triangular shape, the L94A1 Chain Gun is mounted on the left side, the mantlet has an eyelet on the top of it. The turret has 2 banks of SGD's, 1 on either side, there are antennae bases just behind them. The commanders and gunners sights are large rectangular shapes with upward folding sight doors, the doors have a prominent ridge at the bottom which is noticeable when raised, as shown here. The commander and gunner have 3 periscopes each, 2 facing sidewards and one rearwards, the hatches open to the rear of the vehicle. There are stowage bins on the turret sides and one large bustle rack at the rear.

vIZ8m8JWuEqY9Q3Vu75s.description:
Following the collapse of the USSR, the breakaway region of Transnistria in Moldova found itself in possession of a substantial inventory from the 14th Guards Army, which was stationed in Transnistria, Ukraine, and Moldova. However, this acquisition did not include Infantry Fighting Vehicles (IFVs) or Self-Propelled Guns (SPGs). Instead, Transnistria ended up with a collection of unique and specialized engineering vehicles that are rarely found in the arsenals of other countries worldwide. Consequently, the region had to make interesting modifications to compensate for the lack of IFVs and Armored Personnel Carriers (APCs).

One of these modifications is the BTRG-127, which was transformed from a GMZ-3 minelayer into an APC. The minelaying equipment was removed, and benches were installed inside along with a rear door. Additionally, a turret was added, accommodating a 12.7mm Heavy Machine Gun (HMG). Due to restrictions on weapons, it is likely that Transnistria, along with the Operational Group of Russian Forces (OGRF), will continue to showcase intriguing modifications that are unparalleled in any other European country.
vIZ8m8JWuEqY9Q3Vu75s.name: BTRG-127

recognising_features.btrg127_8ea8cdjz8z9gh0l6y48b.jpg: The BTRG-127 will be easily confused with the GMZ-3, which it is based on. Although the modifications giveaway its purpose as not engineering, but an APC. There is an opened top turret in the centre with a 12.7mm HMG fitted, there are now 3 firing ports along the sides which are shaped like small arches. There are also single small periscopes above the firing ports with one on either side, the rear section of the superstructure has been redesigned, doing away with the 3rd crewmans hatch from the GMZ-3 and now being sloped downwards.
recognising_features.btrg127_ortzj9w83f2b67qbaq8u.jpg: The rear has had all minelaying equipment removed and now has a single door with a porthole style window, for the dismounts to exit from. There are 2 brake lights on either side of the vehicle.

vVbdlK7zyOXGZPdFwVv1.description: The FV512 MCRV (Mechanised Combat Repair Vehicle) is operated by REME light aid detachments in armoured infantry/armoured units, which are regimental/battalion attachments of mechanics and technicians. The FV512 can tow the T4 high mobility trailer which is used to carry two complete Warrior power packs, or one Challenger 2 powerpack. The FV512's hydraulic jib can lift 6.5t at 4.5m outreach, with a 360 degree traverse.
vVbdlK7zyOXGZPdFwVv1.name: FV512

recognising_features.fv512_2201cd6c2czwe0vys5un.jpg: Seen here is the rear of an OES fit FV512 in Iraq, it has smaller door which is on the right side, the left is taken up by a stabilising arm for when the crane is in use, as seen on the top right this one has an ECM module fitted, which was a common sight on British vehicles in Iraq and Afghanistan.
recognising_features.fv512_gog3xpj8a09dm6ciwpx4.jpg: The FV512 Warrior is of course a variant of the FV510 Warrior, for a full recognition guide on the hull please see FV510. The FV512 has a small one man turret for the commander on the right hand side of the vehicle, containing a chain gun the turret with 360 degree vision provided by periscopes, on the left side of the vehicle is the crane on a rotating base, on the frontal hull there is mounting points for the tow bars, although in this picture the tow bars are being used to tow the FV510 Warrior in the background.
recognising_features.fv512_kfow74udju8043dbuoga.jpg: The right side of this variant has a lot of stowage bins for tools as well as oils and lubricants, the exhaust is in the same place but has a cover over it.

vXchPbRKwpOesap5OVJv.description: The 9S19 "High Screen" is the detection radar used with the S-300V "Gladiator/Giant" (SA-12) system. It provides sectored detection of ballistic missiles, taking tracks from the 9S15 "Bill Board" radar and passing to the 9S457-1 command post to track and engage with the 9S32 "Grill Pan" and 9A82/9A83 TELARs or 9A84/9A85 LLVs.
vXchPbRKwpOesap5OVJv.name: 9S19

recognising_features.9s19_9931atkcwpn7xsgwa04d.jpg: This image shows the complete S-300V engagement system. From left to right: 9S19 "High Screen", 9S15 "Bill Board", 9A83 TELAR (with 4 x 9M83 "Gladiator" missiles), 9A82 TELAR (with 2 x 9M82 "Giant" missiles) and 9S32 "Grill Pan".
recognising_features.9s19_mji3abvjv1frs4t1jrrc.jpg: "High Screen" radar in Ukraine in 2023 moments before being destroyed by GMLRS.
recognising_features.9s19_reqvvur0felut8188sb8.jpg: The 9S19 has a radar similar to the Zoopark-1, large and rectangular with cut-outs in each corner. The key difference being the size of the vehicle, it is mounted on a specially designed chassis based on the 2S7 Pion. There is also a rectangular section beneath the main radar array which is not present on other radars in the S-300V family.

vfGsWqAcM7fLWYNYo4Iy.description: The 9P148 Konkurs NATO RN:AT-5 Spandrel is an ATGM carrier based on the BRDM-2, it carries 5 missiles on a retractable mount that means it can be lowered inside the vehicle for stowage or reloading.
vfGsWqAcM7fLWYNYo4Iy.name: 9P148 Konkurs

recognising_features.9p148konkurs_hqekm8uk4un1mku15wke.jpg: Here is the 9P148 with the launch tubes lowered and stowed inside, giving it the appearance that it is not an ATGM carrier.
recognising_features.9p148konkurs_ykkx9j34icvn7zq8yg6l.jpg: The hull remains unchanged from the standard BRDM-2, the largest difference is the missile launch tube which replace the turret, the mount can be lowered and raised by the gunner. The sighting system is the square box above the commanders hatch.

vuZQeKSdBMAuUoRtpOwZ.description: The 2K12 Kub, NATO reporting name SA-6 'Gainful', is a medium range surface to air missile. The launcher is armed with 3 x 3M9M4 missiles that have a range of 24km and an altitude of up to 46,000 ft. The system is mounted on a GM-578 chassis and within the firing battery there are different elements. The transporter erector & launchers (TELs), the 1S19, NATO reporting name 'Straight Flush' target acquisition radar and various wheeled supply trucks.
vuZQeKSdBMAuUoRtpOwZ.name: 2K12 Kub

recognising_features.2k12kub_2m0yk3gob9g0gtf7vs41.jpg: This image shows the 2K12 without missiles fitted and the TEL in the collapsed position. Note the high, tear shaped rails - this disguishes it from other SAMs.
recognising_features.2k12kub_kiuhx776g9jbx7gq0ycc.jpg: The 2K12 is mounted on the GM-578 chassis which has slack tracks and a 6 roadwheel configuration of 1-1-4. The final drive is at the rear. The most obvious recognising feature is the three M39M4 missiles which sit within a framed cradle.
recognising_features.2k12kub_uyqr5ex4wdhj7n4otfj7.jpg: The 2T7M 'Gainful' wheeled transloader is used to reload the 2P25 TEL.

vzJ4tgFtDv4qS6AEQBri.description: The K-53949 Typhoon-K is a mine resistant ambush protected vehicle part of the KamAZ Typhoon family, it is used to transport troops and cargo in mine/IED saturated environments.
vzJ4tgFtDv4qS6AEQBri.name: K-53949 Typhoon-K

recognising_features.k53949typhoonk_j0z02ow8r3wuodvra8mf.jpg: The K-53949 is clearly identifiable as an MRAP, there is a RWS on the top of the vehicle, the front windows are large with a small pane down the centre, the wipers are mounted along the top of the windows. There is a snorkel on the right side next to the window. The bonnet is smooth and slopes downwards, with a large intake grill at the front centre, the intake grill splits on the left side. The light clusters consist of 2 headlights, an indicator and a sidelight.
recognising_features.k53949typhoonk_kawf3h86521br16qpg87.jpg: The vehicle has 4 wheels, with a step in the centre side for entry/exit. The doors are small with with a large window on the front door and a smaller rectangle one at the rear door, there is a also another rectangle window at the rear.
recognising_features.k53949typhoonk_qvf6i5wagme5byitxt11.jpg: The rear of the vehicle has folded steps attached to the door which are lowered for entry/exit. There is a large plastic wheel arch on the side, with stowage bins on the rear of the vehicle for tools and equipment.

w7I0ckgMoeUTuzzkO4aT.description: The AS90 is a 155mm self propelled gun (SPG) used by the British Army. Its official designation is Gun Equipment 155mm L131, and was brought in as the 'Artillery system for the 1990s'. The AS90 replaced the Abbot and M109 guns previously in service.
w7I0ckgMoeUTuzzkO4aT.name: AS90

recognising_features.as90_4zrynpisfxwbiacxehrv.jpg: There are three storage boxes on the right hand side of the turret, with a gap between the first and second. At the rear of the AS90 there is a configuration of overhanging storage bins that sit above one large rear door.
recognising_features.as90_990l1fquuceo4tlmn8dg.jpg: The L31 gun turret is sloped at the front and straight at the rear. The gun extrudes from the centre of the sloped section via a large rectangular shroud. On the left hand side of the turret there are two storage bins with a hatch between them.
recognising_features.as90_a65plskydbq4cmcatjgq.jpg: The fume extractor is positioned 1/3rd of the way up the barrel, with a rubber bellow extending from it down to the shroud. The muzzle break has two baffles, the forwardmost being rectangular and the other triangular in shape.
recognising_features.as90_o7kpn4v3n4kn8xxtpw0e.jpg: The drivers hatch is position front left on the hull and there are two hatches in the turret, one for the commander and one for the GPMG (FN MAG) gunner.
recognising_features.as90_oun2nrc5zf5zdfsnrg9p.jpg: The AS90 chassis is scratch built, although shares many internal features as the CRII. It has 6 evenly spaced road wheels, with the final drive at the front. The front glacis plate is curved slightly, with an inset centre. Each track link has a pair of track pads.
recognising_features.as90_x3vpxh8cosl1vlnw5gbl.jpg: The hull of the AS90 is sloped at the front and straight at the rear. The L31 gun turret is attached to the hull on the flat rear section. The barrel clamp is triangular and is attached at the very front of the hull, just above the front glacis plate.

wBo2jba1jRdZznXPgPcc.description: The Leopardo 2E is a Spanish modernised Leopard, produced and designed almost indigenously by Spain, it includes thicker armour on the turret and glacis plate than the 2A6, it also uses a Spanish C&C system and also has the longer more powerful L/55 120mm gun.
wBo2jba1jRdZznXPgPcc.name: Leopardo 2E

recognising_features.leopardo2e_lasp1uchce356u775w53.jpg: Seen here at the rear of the turret you will notice the Spanish addition of SABBLIR ERA, these are the X shaped boxes.
recognising_features.leopardo2e_q150j8z78yicswv26edi.jpg: The final drive differs to the standard Leopard 2 with a more circular final drive, as opposed to the 'cogged' shape found on other Leopard 2.
recognising_features.leopardo2e_ylcrowkszyb1pu7k1d5c.jpg: You will notice the thicker armour on the hull front straight away, the headlight mounts are also in armoured boxes on the upper glacis, this is different to the German Leopard. The addition of bar armour is common for variants deploying on operations.

wLf035Vl2k8dnMEbA7BD.description: The Leer-3 is a Russian drone based EW system, it the RB-341V (Leer-3 designation) combines a jamming station and 3x Orlan-10 UAV’s, this allows it to disable and spoof cellular networks. It can effectively become a fake cellular data station, by sending SMS and controlling a ‘subscribers’ device once it replaces a base station. It can transmit the data of the phones locations to artillery crews. Once it takes the place of a cell tower, it can then begin a psychological warfare aspect and send messages, videos, audio messages and even calls to the phones in the area, as well as blocking the mobile devices too. This was seen in the build up to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, when Ukrainian soldiers began to receive text messages saying ‘Ukrainian military serviceman! The Russian army is already in Donetsk and Luhansk. Return home while it isn’t late!’ This is the kind of messages expected from the Leer-3 in order to impose psychological decomposition of soldiers mentality and will to fight.
wLf035Vl2k8dnMEbA7BD.name: Leer-3

recognising_features.leer3_3cezd1aiymgvgkfvw45z.jpg: The Leer-3 system is based upon a Kamaz-4350 truck, this is a common general purpose truck of the Russian army, so the recognising features are absolutely key as this is a HVT. On the truck bed is what appears to be a standard KUNG module, which is a metal housing fitted to the rear of Russian military trucks, the difference here is that it lacks as many windows that a normal KUNG module will have, it also has the very prominent antennae at the rear for the cellular spoofing. This can be folded away, which can again give the appearance of a standard Kamaz truck. On the right of this picture is an Orlan-10 UAV.
recognising_features.leer3_cy0vzlxtfsckg415moau.jpg:
Ukraine's 53rd brigade received SMS 
The text reads, 'Ukrainian military servicemen! The Russian army is already in Donetsk and Luhansk. Return home while it isn't late!'
recognising_features.leer3_gw01dfu9vzjgstg3d5bf.jpg:
Ukrainian soldiers of the 54th Brigade received these messages of what is assessed to be cellular interference from Leer-3. 
The text reads, 'Moscow gave a go to the use of RF Armed Forces in the Donbas! There's still time to save your life and leave the JFO zone'
recognising_features.leer3_it5onfhkrmle9ya2wtmx.jpg: Leer-3 in use in Syria, you can see here the antennae, it is prominent in the sense that it has cables wrapped around it and also has a bell shaped object towards the top.
recognising_features.leer3_tzz39z30mxkf5n1oxpz5.jpg: The truck has some rails around the top of the rear module, the standard truck would not have this.

wfWZUTDftdNLc1esvI-k.description: The TZM-T is a loading vehicle for the TOS-1 MLRS; it is fitted with a crane and two pods to store 12 rockets each, this system along with the TOS-1 launcher, forms the full system.
wfWZUTDftdNLc1esvI-k.name: TZM-T

recognising_features.tzmt_lkrwh9u6exnvlxfp21jx.jpg: Here is the TZM-T with the containers removed, this is the configuration it will be in when reloading the TOS-1. Another recognising feature is the crane in the centre, between the 2 containers.
recognising_features.tzmt_u9fcuyarhpw3g2uqvuui.jpg: The TZM-T is a very prominent vehicle, with its 2 large rectangular blocks on top of the hull it can be easily confused as a TOS-1 itself, the way to recognise this is the gap between the 2 containers, as well as the lack of holes in the containers.

wl0qIp7RH2yUyMuWsvdW.description: The Vityaz DT-10 is a Russian articulated all-terrain vehicle, designed for usage in remote and extreme conditions, commonly found in the Russian Far East, Far North and the Arctic Regions. They can also be used as recovery vehicles due to the high pull ratio, they also have a very low ground pressure, which is useful for preventing the detonation of mines. The vehicles are used by Russian Army units in extreme climates, as well as civilian companies who use them for logging in the Far East and also scientific companies who conduct scientific research in extreme climates like the Arctic as well as remote and isolated regions like the Northern Islands of Russia. Some vehicles were used in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mostly by the 200th Motor Rifle Brigade. This and the DT-30 series are commonly confused, it is key to remember that the DT-30 is larger and longer than the DT-10. More than a hundred Vityaz vehicles are used in Russia for the transportation of cargo, such as: blocks, cranes and even towers for power lines in hard to reach regions. They serve rescue teams in extreme conditions. When a natural disaster occurs, there are no roads, the Vityaz all-terrain vehicle is a great help.
wl0qIp7RH2yUyMuWsvdW.name: DT-10

recognising_features.dt10_m73kv2jor34itj6tggmm.jpg: The DT-10 is very similar to the DT-30, the key is that it is smaller by 2m and has less roadwheels on the first cab, the DT-10 has 4 roadwheels whereas the DT-30 has 6. The cab has 3 windows at the front as well as roof mounted headlights and a searchlight, there are also 2 square cut outs for the headlights and indicators on the front centre flat face, below this the cab slopes down. There are 2 towing eyes at the lower front centre, next to the noticeably wide tracks.
recognising_features.dt10_yy26w51d2zr1pu4yvv25.jpg: This sideview of the DT-10 shows the roadwheels, this is the main recognition feature between this model and the DT-30.

xCvrY_9r3bTdPpBnHxMg.description: The FV513 MRV(R) (Mechanised Recovery Vehicle (Repair)) is operated by REME light aid detachments in armoured infantry/armoured units, which are regimental/battalion attachments of mechanics and technicians. The FV513 MRV(R) is used more by REME recovery mechanics, who provide support to vehicles who cannot move, whether that be bogged in, M-killed or mechanical failure, the FV513 represents this with a straight pull capacity of 20t, 38t when double reeved, the FV513 also has a large earth anchor at the rear. The FV513 MRV(R) is still able to tow the T4 HM trailer like the FV512 MCRV.
xCvrY_9r3bTdPpBnHxMg.name: FV513

recognising_features.fv513_2c7prey840oss274thlo.jpg: The main recognising feature on the FV513 is the large earth anchor at the rear, which takes up the full length of the rear and is spiked at the top, it stays upwards in its stowage position, for a full recognising features of this platform see FV512. This FV513 has been fitted with the latest version of Warrior ERA.

xjtj5BceC2lo24ZM1bzn.description: The BMP-2M ‘Berezhok’ is a modernised BMP-2, it has a new berezhok turret, with mostly the same armaments aside from the addition of 2 launchers either side of the turret for the 9M133/9M113M Kornet-M and an AGS-30 GMG on the rear turret roof, as well as a new day/night sight from the BMD-4. The upgrades bring it up to a much more modern standard, massively enhancing lethality.
xjtj5BceC2lo24ZM1bzn.name: BMP-2M

recognising_features.bmp2m_fkzf1tzwi7547o8pp0pg.jpg: On this photo you will see the new sighting systems, a new panoramic sight for the cmdr and a new gunners sight, Cmdr’s on the right and Gunners on the left, you can also see a better view of the launchers and SGD’s, the SGD’s are mounted on the sides on previous iterations of the BMP-2.
recognising_features.bmp2m_ohjfah4s2vj6g2usutkz.jpg: The hull remains the same, the turret noticeably has the differences with the ATGM mounts either side, unlike the BMP-2 which has the mount on top of the turret. Another noticeable difference is the cluster of SGD’s which sit at the front of the turret either side of the MA. Moving rearwards you will see the AGS-30 at the turret rear, when firing you will see it is elevated.

xlxlAja-P-jYUnmajdWX.description: The BMP-1M is a Russian modification of the BMP-1, it was developed to bring the thousands of BMP-1's Russia had to BMP-2 standard, though this never materialised. According to Russian computer simulation tests, the BMP-1M outperformed the M2/M3 Bradley.
xlxlAja-P-jYUnmajdWX.name: BMP-1M

recognising_features.bmp1m_8bb9u4kx3y4fq72sly5o.jpg: A key point to note with the BMP-1M is the Ukrainian variant, the BMP-1U, the 2 vehicles are very easily confused, key points to remember is the turret differences. It has 2 ATGM launchers instead of 4, it has 6 SGD’s around the front lower turret, the BMP-1M does not have this cylindrical lower part of the turret.
recognising_features.bmp1m_j54lphka9r1hl9lszypr.jpg: This photo shows the sighting system in full view, it has 2 pill shaped sights with the one on the left being shorter.
recognising_features.bmp1m_sr0e911h17jf7fqqbi5o.jpg: The BMP-1M is a modernised BMP-1 with a new TKB-799 Kliver turret, this includes new weapon systems, the 30mm 2A72 has prominent rails on the exterior of the barrel, the 4 ATGM pods are a key indicator, they can be replaced with 4 SAM’s too, meaning the launch tubes will be skinnier, on the left of the turret there is a large sighting system.

xqjwoVID3cmde6tYWqpG.description: The Gaz Tigr Kornet-D (NATO:AT-14 Spriggan) is an ATGM system based on the Gaz Tigr-M, it contains 2 missile pods of 9M113M Kornet-M missiles, the system is automatic and does not require operators aid, although the operator can override the system and take over if necessary. It is due to replace the 9P148 Konkurs.
xqjwoVID3cmde6tYWqpG.name: GAZ Tigr Kornet-T

recognising_features.gaztigrkornett_aygxyemysoslifhvjuyh.jpg: The hull remains very similar to the GAZ-TIGR-M, the main points are the 2 launch pods with 4 missiles each, these can be folded down inside to give the appearance of a standard Gaz-Tigr IMV. The main differences to remember, if the missiles aren’t in view is the lack of windows on the side, also the 2 banks of 2 SGD’s on the front roof.
recognising_features.gaztigrkornett_f5zwtbkipdhtcg6edtao.jpg: The 2 pods can fire independently of each other. Note the lack of side windows and the SGD’s.

yArmrLBTReIz8dhGpIYm.description: The M1A2 is the second major upgrade for the M1 Abrams series of MBT’s, the M1A2 is the baseline for the SEP models (System enhancement package), SEPV1 is an armour upgrade, SEPV2 adds a CROWS, improved interfaces, new operating system improved armour with the TUSK (Tank Urban Survival Kit) and an upgraded transmission. The SEPV3 will be rightly covered on its own page.
yArmrLBTReIz8dhGpIYm.name: M1A2

recognising_features.m1a2_djusy894kjnuhpaep0iy.jpg: Here you can see the armoured cupolas in a better view, as mentioned with the similarity to the cupola on the HMMVW you can see one in the background.
recognising_features.m1a2_ezgcaeqrh5nuusr6jon9.jpg: Here is an M1A2SEPV2 model with the TUSK fitted, you can see the addition of ERA along the sides, the CROWS is sometimes swapped with a transparent armoured cupola for the Cmdr and Op, similar to those seen fitted to HMMVW’s in Iraq/Afghanistan.
recognising_features.m1a2_uv6rnw6bs74evbb2eahm.jpg: Shown here is an M1A2SEPV2 model, you can tell this by the CROWS above the gunners primary sight.
recognising_features.m1a2_xpa19m6rrqqb3bwlnme8.jpg: The M1A2 baseline only really has one new recognising feature which is the addition of the commanders panoramic sight on the left side of the turret in front of the loaders hatch.

yVaPPKPhzwR-1TttIeFH.description: The BMD-1 is based on the BMP-1, but is produced for the airborne forces (VDV), BMD literally translates to ‘Combat vehicle of the airborne’. It shares commonality with the BMP-1, the turret and armaments are the same, it is also the basis for the BTR-D series of APC’s.
yVaPPKPhzwR-1TttIeFH.name: BMD-1

recognising_features.bmd1_e2piyh3q3ii8f9y4k3mu.jpg: The front has an air intake grille centrally mounted in front of the drivers hatch, the driver has 3 periscopes for his position with the 2 hatches either side of them having 1 hatch for the right and 2 for the left, on the running gear it has 2 prominent top rollers, with 5 equally spaced roadwheels with the final drive at the rear. The antenna whip is at the rear left.
recognising_features.bmd1_qztjmtf7ry82udpu42mn.jpg: This is how the turret appears when the missile is fitted; it is a bare missile rather than a launch tube.
recognising_features.bmd1_ui3lnyzdf3qqdjnw5f87.jpg: The BMD-1 is a much smaller version of the BMP-1 for airborne use, the turret is the same as that on the BMP-1, small conical shaped and armed with the 73mm 2A28 Grom main gun, it also has the 9M14/9M14 Malyutka ATGM fitted above the gun mantlet. The hull still retains a boat-like shape due to its amphibious capabilities; it has a splash plate at the front which is folded down for normal operations.

yb-Q_rXp1OVQDMlG1OTr.description: The BMR-2 is an upgrade on the BMR-1, it appears to be more purpose built than the previous iteration, which was essentially just a superstructure on a T-54 hull with a mine roller, this one was designed based on feedback from the Soviet-Afghan War. These vehicles have seen a resurgence in the Russo-Ukraine war, during the Ukrainian counter-offensive of June 2023.
yb-Q_rXp1OVQDMlG1OTr.name: BMR-2

recognising_features.bmr2_7f1afe6lee9udawhhcin.jpg: The lower hull of the BMR-2 differs from the BMR-1, namely with the roadwheel config, the BMR-2 has a more traditional T-55 layout which has a prominent gap between the 1st and 2nd roadwheels, with the rest being equally spaced. The upper hull has larger rubber flaps on the sides, it now also has 2 banks of 4x smoke grenade dischargers.
recognising_features.bmr2_hj6qs6av966h42fkbx0a.jpg: The crew hatch is now on the side of the hull, which is open in this image. As shown here the de-mining equipment can be folded upwards for transport.
recognising_features.bmr2_o338xsy524jtqbek64r3.jpg: The superstructure is now larger and revised, the driver has 4 lines in front of him, likely splash plates and has a protective cover over his hatch, the commanders hatch is evident with the 3 sided armoured hatch that you can see protruding from the front of the superstructure.

ycVAgR2ABEu12K89SFB3.description: The Krasukha-4 is a Russian wheeled, EW vehicle. It is a broadband multifunctional jamming station, with a range of upto 300km, it is mounted on a Kamaz-6350 Truck. The Krasukha-4 is primarily designed to counter AWACS as well as UAV’s The Krasukha-4 has the range to, in theory, disrupt Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites and it can also cause permanent damage to targeted radio-electronic devices. Ground-based radars are also a viable target for the Krasukha-4. It is a 2 part system consisting of a command post and the EW system itself. Additionally, the mobile system can be deployed to jam ground-based large radars and shield Russian assets from surveillance systems.
ycVAgR2ABEu12K89SFB3.name: 1RL257 Krasukha-4

recognising_features.1rl257krasukha4_25hcb5dpwrndam7gnzwx.jpg: Pictured here is the captured Krasukha-4 command post during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.1rl257krasukha4_98w3avzyb3wcrpn8qo4j.jpg: From a rear view you can see the large mast, at the top it has many antennae that point out horizontally, at the rear of the vehicle is a large box and also ladders, there are also stabilising points at the rear and the front behind the truck cab.
recognising_features.1rl257krasukha4_khzkolwydgk4v0xjnev4.jpg: Seen here is a complete Krasukha-4 unit, the vehicle on the left carries the command post which is essentially an iso container, it can be removed from the vehicle and placed on the ground, one of these was captured by Ukrainian forces during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.
recognising_features.1rl257krasukha4_s2eik36mbrdwsvog7ry6.jpg: The Krasukha-4 is mounted on the Kamaz-6350, it has a KUNG style mobile command room on the back of the truck, above this is the EW system itself, noticeable with its 3 circular dishes, almost like mickey mouse ears, with a smaller dish at the top, behind these is a mast.
recognising_features.1rl257krasukha4_z5k0r5kgtpd455xyd71j.jpg: Krasukha-4 shown on Russian TV, reportedly in Ukraine.

about.operators: Afghanistan,Albania,Algeria,Angola,Argentina,Armenia,Azerbaijan,Belarus,Bhutan,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Bulgaria,Burkina Faso,Cambodia,China,Colombia,Republic of the Congo,Republic of the Congo,Croatia,Cuba,Czech Republic,Djibouti,Egypt,Eritrea,Ethiopia,Georgia,Germany,Guinea,Guinea-Bissau,Hungary,India,Iran,Iraq,Kazakhstan,Kyrgyzstan,Latvia,Laos,Libya,Lithuania,Maldives,Mexico,Mali,Moldova,Mongolia,Mozambique,Nepal,North Korea,Pakistan,Peru,Poland,Romania,Russia,Serbia,Slovakia,Somalia,Sudan,Syria,Turkey,Turkmenistan,Tajikistan,Ukraine,United States of America,Uzbekistan,Venezuela,Vietnam

yu2lDnuCHGxkdN_4it3A.description: The Mil Mi-8MT, or M-17T is the attack variant of the M-17. Like the Mi-8TV, it has the addition of weapon pylons but can carry more and upgraded weaponry.
yu2lDnuCHGxkdN_4it3A.name: Mi-8MT

recognising_features.mi8mt_lfy2qrux9uj3vi4tsqlg.jpg: Like the Mi-17, the tail rotor is on the starboard (port) side of the rudder.
recognising_features.mi8mt_tnlm94ucbmb2kevf7r52.jpg: The weapon pylons have three hardpoints, enabling a total of six weapons or rocket pods to be employed.

zFXbTfhBrLRGTIsgrrE5.description: The T-80U (U-Improved) is an improved version of the T-80, this design was quite revolutionary and led the west to design new APFSDS rounds. The tank was equipped with the new Kontakt-5 armour, a better turret, improved sights, a new engine and thermal sights. The T-80U also has an organic trench digging system fitted due to the lower glacis. Due to the blame on the T-80 series from Grozny the T-80U never saw action, although the T-80UD was involved in firing at the presidential palace during the Russian constitutional crisis.
zFXbTfhBrLRGTIsgrrE5.name: T-80U

recognising_features.t80u_4yxu92z39z5n4bdmrl3v.jpg: At the rear as previously mentioned on T-80BV you will see the exhaust for the GT engine, which will give off a huge heat signature in TI.
recognising_features.t80u_oou4xczrrvsqbqyyxu5n.jpg: Thermal View Rear, showing the heat from the exhaust on idle.
recognising_features.t80u_rd45ikx0bcg5eyo2kl2g.jpg: There are Kontakt-5 ERA plates fitted across the frontal glacis plate, also 3 mounts down the sides of the hull. There are 4 Kontakt-5 mounts on the left turret cheek, with 3 on the right to make way for the IR searchlight.
recognising_features.t80u_tul2uh42k5rwbcltgv05.jpg: The T-80U changes a lot compared to the T-80BV, you will see the Kontakt-5 armour fitted around the turret with flaps covering them, the SGD’s are strangely, fitted over the top of the ERA, with 2 banks of 4. The turret also has a large fitting prominent at the rear, it is stowage for the snorkel adapters for the GT engine, the T-80UD would not have these due to it being diesel.

zHwhKV-NROiS1VlqRRie.description: The T-90M is a heavily modernised T-90, completely modernising almost all features of the tank, it has a new gun, new FCS, new sights, new GPS systems, new Relikt ERA and a new engine to name a few, it is the latest version of T-90, also the most modern tank in the Russian Army.
zHwhKV-NROiS1VlqRRie.name: T-90M

recognising_features.t90m_180ny8hh5pd7zoavmhm5.jpg: The T-90M looks like a completely new tank, the turret resembles that of the T-80BVM due to the application of the new Relikt ERA, which gives it that distinctive flying saucer shape. On the T-90M it’s fitted with a mesh RPG net on the bottom half of the turret.
recognising_features.t90m_3mx4npap667u17bnkqis.jpg: Another view of the turret showing the gunners sight, met sensor and the SGD’s.
recognising_features.t90m_45cjqyqjowrhszpb8yq5.jpg: The hull looks very similar to the T-72B3 due to it having the new long side skirts, the bar armour around the rear quarter and the new exhaust system. The front glacis plate is now very heavily armoured with Relikt. You can also see here the long length of the turret.
