At the rear left there is a large square, this is a good recognising feature, as the high modernisation of the tank now gives this tank a very western style silhouette.
recognising_features.t90m_mrvugxj12sj65nyk8krr.jpg: The turret is highly modernised, you will see the LWS boxes either side of the MA, there is also what appears to be an MRS at the end of the gun barrel, indicating a highly modernised FCS. The gunner has a new sight, behind it you will see the Meteorological sensor. The commander now has a remote weapon station with an independent sight with it, giving the T-90M the hunter-killer capability which it’s taken Russian tank building a while to catch up on.

zmLS4tHT9LUy481-Ths1.description: The T-72B1 is a T-72B without the ATGM capability, it also has the optics from the T-72A.
zmLS4tHT9LUy481-Ths1.name: T-72B1

recognising_features.t72b1_54fhx3lk0ojujtt45iyi.jpg: The T-72B1 only has one recognising feature when compared to the T-72B. The prominent feature is the TPN 3-49 Sight replacing the 1K13 sight. The key feature is that the sight is square and has 4 screws. The best way to remember is the T-72B has a sight door and the T-72B1 doesn’t.
recognising_features.t72b1_lybq8iwwjnj2e1v32zxo.jpg: T-72B1’s shown with no ERA fitted in Georgia, 2008. This shows the mounts, unlike other models the mounts for the Kontakt-1 are directly on the hull, unlike clamshell mounting brackets. The ERA was probably fitted in theatre.
recognising_features.t72b1_mwajftd2kfbyo2sggb67.jpg: You can see here the sight with the 4 screws.

zmZ1aEJ7nAg8fx4528_o.description: The Leclerc tank is a main battle tank built by GIAT, now Nexter of France. It was named in honor of General Philippe Leclerc de Hauteclocque, who led the French element of the drive towards Paris while in command of the Free French 2nd Armoured Division (2e DB) in World War II. The Leclerc is in service with the French Army, Jordanian Army and the United Arab Emirates Army.
zmZ1aEJ7nAg8fx4528_o.name: Leclerc

recognising_features.leclerc_31cp5ktgjvbs58r6bh46.jpg: The gun is distinctive in its lack of fume extractor and it’s completely covered in a thermal shroud, there are periscopes on each side of the turret for the commander and gunner, the hull has a highly slopes upper glacis plate with 2 headlight mounts on top of each mudguard, the driver sits on the left side with 2 periscopes.
recognising_features.leclerc_6sauj8g5qvaw4pzg3m8v.jpg: At the rear of the Leclerc you’ll see a large stowage box and bustle rack on the rear of the turret, moving down the large exhaust at the rear left which almost looks like a drain pipe.
recognising_features.leclerc_h70osqvkz27uzlny4wld.jpg: The Leclerc has a lot of recognising features as it’s quite a distinctive tank, the turret is long and has a lot of prominent features including the large gunners sight, the commanders panoramic sight (bucket shaped) on the left, the smoke grenade cut outs at the rear turret sides.
recognising_features.leclerc_yasg7p20fg626f4eoph3.jpg: Thermal view of the Leclerc showing the exhaust at the rear.

zzC4ToGuXEaeIDXu0AOU.description: The BTR-3DA is a variant of the BTR-3U with a different turret, purchased by the Ukrainian Armed Forces; they are used by the Azov Battalion and some other army formations.
zzC4ToGuXEaeIDXu0AOU.name: BTR-3DA

recognising_features.btr3da_1fbarsb1am2ydah6e9xt.jpg: The major differences with the BTR-3DA, the turret has changed as its part of the Shturm-M weapon station. It now has a rounded box on the left side instead of the square.
recognising_features.btr3da_51rlzugw5t3l5vpmvvpk.jpg: There is now a prominent storage box on the left side behind the door. The rear exhaust now moves places and is a small circular exhaust on the top rear right, rather than a rectangular slit in the centre like on BTR-3U.
recognising_features.btr3da_kxs1tmce4e6hhplb4xp9.jpg: The side has changed with the long cylindrical tube at the rear right for the exhaust.

ND17W7lm3RcicNN1kRxP.name: ZTZ-96B
ND17W7lm3RcicNN1kRxP.description: The ZTZ-96B is the latest iteration of the ZTZ-96 series, first appearing at the tank biathlon in 2016, it won a gold medal. This variant has seen significant upgrades, the majority of which are internal, including an improved engine and transmission, improved fire control system and comms equipment. The ZTZ-96B is somewhat comparable to the Russian T-72B3.

recognising_features.ztz96b_9wwe38mk1q0iecq0n422.jpg: The best way to distinguish the ZTZ-96B from the previous iterations is that the due to the new powerpack, the exhaust outlets are now at the rear, as seen here with two outlets, as well as this the grille (likely for cooling fans) is a new feature, one which isn't present on the ZTZ-96A.

y34EU7wAJwRIx0Okk55y.name: A-222 Bereg
y34EU7wAJwRIx0Okk55y.description: The A-222 Bereg (coast/shore in Russian) is a coastal defence artillery system, produced during the USSR era as it was thought that guns were required to plug the dead-zones of the anti-ship missiles. The platform is a MAZ-543 8x8 truck, with the gun turret based on that of the 2S19 Msta-S, only 36 vehicles were produced (that's including command and support variants) and are used solely by the Black Sea Fleet (Russian Navy Coastal Troops). The gun can use all of the ammunition that is available to the naval version, including anti-air rounds. Targets are given by the command vehicle via radio. The Bereg can also engage ground targets, and to devastating effect given it can fire12 rounds per minute.

recognising_features.a222bereg_xubx0fj0u1hm8ffevtk2.jpg: The A-222 Bereg is recognisable by it's chassis, the MAZ-543 8x8, this chassis is commonly used with many Russian air defence and anti-ship platforms, so it could be easily confused. The easiest way to recognise this platform will be via the large turret at the rear and of course the main gun, when in a firing position the turret is usually traversed to the rear.
recognising_features.a222bereg_81rzne4l83z7s5no7egv.jpg: As seen here, it is common to see the vehicle dug in on exercises with the turret exposed but the rest of the vehicle covered in camouflage netting, meaning this is likely how they will be deployed, it is worth mentioning that the Russian Black Sea Fleet coastal area probably has a lot of pre-dug positions for the deployment of air defence platforms, radars and anti-ship missiles, so I'd assume it will be unlikely to see them static in the open. The turret here from some distance could be confused with the 2S19 Msta-S, the way to distinguish from that is it's larger size and also the railings on top as well as the large antennae, also use the compare tab on the bottom right to compare the two vehicles.
recognising_features.a222bereg_accod38y8qs2us3ry7xk.jpg: When the gun is in travel mode it sits in a recess and extends towards the frontal cab.

GjWEiHh8qRfBI7SAZ5F0.name: A-222 CPU
GjWEiHh8qRfBI7SAZ5F0.description: The A-222 CPU is the command and control vehicle for the A-222 Bereg coastal defence complex, it is based on the MAZ-543 chassis and consists of a large KUNG module on the rear, it has a radar fitted towards the front of the KUNG module, this is how it is differentiated between itself and the A-222 MOBD support vehicle. The CPU of the A-222 complex is equipped with a radar and optical location system. They provide detection and tracking of surface objects of various sizes at a distance of at least 35km. Two detection channels can operate in several modes, from manual to fully automatic. Commands are transmitted to the guns via radio channel, typically the same as a normal artillery battery. Images of this variant have proven somewhat difficult to find, therefore I apologise for the lack of imagery.

recognising_features.a222cpu_6bvb3n6kcismhoine7uz.jpg: he easiest way to recognise this vehicle is via the obvious large structure, although that could be confused with the support variant, so the best way is to look at the radar systems fitted on the right hand side towards the front of the KUNG module.
recognising_features.a222cpu_ayrxutsve3v5ux409p7g.jpg: Another view of the radar system on top of the vehicle, with the gun system itself in the foreground.

KNw39b97JQ1i1VXNtEDd.name: A-222 MOBD
KNw39b97JQ1i1VXNtEDd.description: The A-222 MOBD is the support vehicle for the A-222 complex, it consists of a MAZ-543 truck with a large KUNG module fitted, inside the module are rest areas and even a kitchen. As with the A-222 CPU (Command Variant) images are somewhat hard to come by for this vehicle, so apologies for a lack of imagery.

recognising_features.a222mobd_rwlackw7hnrwganajyrk.jpg: The vehicle is recognised by it's large KUNG module, to distinguish between itself and the command variant, note the lack of any radar or detection systems.
recognising_features.a222mobd_4xq84gkzibch40n2qs67.jpg: The frontal cab is the same as ours, with the drivers cab on the left side (right as you look at it) and a large air conditioning module which hangs over the cab.

5sv84sDflznjkx5G2v8f.name: MT-LB 2M-3
5sv84sDflznjkx5G2v8f.description: The MT-LB 2M-3 is an MT-LB APC with a 2M-3 naval twin 25mm gun turret fitted on top to create a makeshift IFV/fire support vehicle, it was first seen in Ukraine early-mid 2023. The platform isn't made to handle twin 25mm firing, so it is likely to effect dispersion, though the fact the vehicle is used to suppress rather than directly engage point targets it is unlikely that it matters much. The vehicles aren't standardised, some have a large tower with the turret on top, whereas others are fitted on a smaller mount giving them a lower profile.

recognising_features.mtlb2m3_lnky2kpvfiqzbhp4fqmg.jpg: This version is what could be called the 'low profile turret' version, where the turret is essentially fitted straight on to the hull, the hull itself remains unchanged from the standard MT-LB. Note, some may be fitted with roof mounted cages.
recognising_features.mtlb2m3_j7x6px834xn8ddz48c98.jpg: The hull remains unchanged to a standard MT-LB, so to learn how to identify that, look for MT-LB in the APC section. As mentioned in the description, there are different variations, this one is what can be called the 'high profile mount' and is mounted on top of a large tower. The turret is the same and is recognisable by it's large boxy shape, sloped front and dual cannons, as well as this it's relatively common to see the turret still painted in naval grey colours, despite this one being green, its relatively rare to see them painted this way.

x0UQ3ZR9C1JRV3W5md4w.name: Foxhound
x0UQ3ZR9C1JRV3W5md4w.description: The Foxhound is a British protected mobility vehicle, it was produced for Operation Herrick and has all the typical features of a vehicle built for such an operation. This includes emphasis on IED/mine protection and composite armour. It is currently used in the British Army's light brigade combat teams, there is a package called the Public Order Vehicle, which enhances protection to windows, vents/grilles and light fittings, this variant is commonly deployed to areas where civil unrest is a high likelihood, it is commonly seen being deployed to Op Althea (British contribution to KFOR).

recognising_features.foxhound_alwoj4d4mxowv69k8cwz.jpg: The Foxhound is clearly identifiable as a protected mobility vehicle due to the V-shaped hull, it is generally distinguished from other British protected mobility vehicles via the lack of bar armour. The front of the vehicle is dominated by the large intake grille for the frontally mounted engine, with headlights flanking the large grille. The bonnet/hood is heavily sloped and has two prominent boxes on the front facing inwards. Note on the grille there is towing equipment, this is commonly (but not always) stowed in this position.
recognising_features.foxhound_437no1ng714vmm6pybnz.jpg: The rear of the vehicle is V-shaped and tall, with the doors in the centre and two boxes at the upper left and right of the doors, the top rear of the vehicle has a camera fitting.
recognising_features.foxhound_h93jdmblifa3v27ukrww.jpg: The Foxhound Public Order Vehicle (POV) shown here, it adds protection to the windows, vents and grilles and light fittings, as well as sometimes a bull bar at the lower front for breaking through potential barriers, the POV variant is easy to identify via it's black additional parts, it is unknown whether they will be sprayed to match the vehicles in the future, but for now it is a good recognition tool to identify a POV variant over a standard Foxhound.

EC9sMgI8RgRPZWemYgbP.name: Foxhound Command
EC9sMgI8RgRPZWemYgbP.description: The Foxhound command is a command variant of the Foxhound protected mobility vehicle, it is currently in trials with the British Army's 7th Light Mech Brigade and if purchased, 50 Foxhound protected mobility vehicles will be converted to this version. Being a command variant it provides enhanced VHF, HF and UHF capability, it will also have extra batteries for the comms fit as well as crew display systems.

recognising_features.foxhoundcommand_d10cu4q3s5hxuc2sd4gc.jpg: The Foxhound command variant is recognisable by it's comms fit, namely the large antennae mount on the frontal hull above the left side headlight. There are also another 3 antennae on top of the vehicle, adding up to 4 antennae in total, compared to 2 antennae on the standard Foxhound. Another point to note is that this vehicle has been seen almost exclusively with woodland barracuda MCS, it is unknown whether this kit will be fitted to all in service Foxhounds or just the command variants.

8x6fv2U6a48OtROYmym4.name: ZS-88 PsyOps
8x6fv2U6a48OtROYmym4.description: The ZS-88 PsyOps vehicle is a BTR-80 APC with a loudspeaker set, the loudspeaker has a range of around 5-6km when at maximum volume, of course this depends on background and ambient noise. The vehicle is used in both aspects of propaganda, to demoralise enemy troops and also to broadcast messages to friendly troops to bolster morale, sometimes playing music like national anthems. They were also used by the Russian Internal Troops, notably during civil unrest in 1991 and 1993 (see image 2) to broadcast messages to protestors, I cannot confirm but I imagine they are still used by the Internal Troops alongside their BTR-80's.

recognising_features.zs88psyops_ru6ec8p160g6mitwgqmf.jpg: The obvious way to identify the ZS-88 is via the large loudspeaker fitted to the rear of the turret, it gives the vehicle a taller profile, it may also be broadcasting messages, which are usually pre-recorded messages looped, typically spoken in Russian. The loudspeaker in this image has a cover over it.

GpLHtKhD4GfiUM8d05N6.name: PT-91 Twardy
GpLHtKhD4GfiUM8d05N6.description: The PT-91 is a Polish upgrade on the T-72M1, it was designed by OBRUM and consists of mainly exclusively domestically produced upgrades. These upgrades include a new stabiliser, fire control system and sights, engine and transmission, laser warning system and a modified autoloader amongst others. It's use in Ukraine has been the tanks first operational deployment.

recognising_features.pt91twardy_kt8zn10kgo2f5iu5ptgi.jpg: The PT-91 at a glance could be confused with a Russian T-72B, but upon closer inspection you will notice a lot of differences, the main one being the huge banks of smoke grenade dischargers, with 12 on either side of the turret protruding like ears. Moving to the turret front you can see the two cylinders on either turret cheek, these are the laser warning sensors, moving up to the gunners sight the old 'doghouse' gunners sight remains the same, but where the night sight typically sits is now a much larger sight. Another point is the black triangle with orange background on the hull, this is a common feature on Polish tanks and AFV's.
recognising_features.pt91twardy_538s870e268uopyampdn.jpg: The ERAWA ERA is square shaped and smaller when compared to the rectangular shaped Kontakt-1. The PT-91 is also recognised by it's Polish camouflage pattern, as seen here, which is different to most other NATO vehicle camouflages. Due to the rubber flaps below the hull the PT-91 is often confused with the T-80 series of tanks, the PT-91 rubber screens are made up of 5 separate pieces, whereas the T-80 has 2 larger pieces, also note the single drivers periscope for T-72 series tanks, instead of the T-80's three periscopes.

8XuhoAkIl851u37p7xPE.name: Chonma-Ho 216
8XuhoAkIl851u37p7xPE.description: The Chonma-Ho 216 is a unique tank designed by the DPRK. Incorporating elements from the T-62, T-72M and T-80BV, it features a 115mm cannon, a KPVT and a coaxial PKT (Type-68). The Chonma-Ho 216 is the primary production model from the post Arduous March tank modernization program. Featuring an improved T-72 style engine deck, soft kill APS with LWS and automated smoke systems. The 216 features ERA on the hull front.

gdN6G5pj7lFu76a7fnVS.name: WZT-3M
gdN6G5pj7lFu76a7fnVS.description: The WZT-3M is a Polish armoured recovery vehicle based on the PT-91 MBT series, which in turn is based on the T-72M. It is a modernised version of the T-72M based WZT-3, all WZT-3 in Polish service were upgraded to WZT-3M standard. In Indian service it is license produced by Bharat Earth Movers Limited (BEML), it is referred to as ARV-3 in Indian service.

recognising_features.wzt3m_y4gkcketn2leazejpmoq.jpg: The vehicle is recognisable as Polish due to the Polish vehicle camouflage pattern that it is commonly seen in, it also has the prominent smoke grenade discharger banks, similar to the ones seen on the PT-91, with 2 banks of 6 on either side of the front of the vehicle. The orange circle with black triangle common to Polish AFV's is also a distinctive feature.
recognising_features.wzt3m_ty2o0zwuycu8li343zt2.jpg: The crane is on the left side of the vehicle (right as you look at it), the exhaust is also on that side in the typical T-72 exhaust location, for thermal signature reference.

GT7Rgl7Ac78zJlSJPz1m.name: Songun-Ho 915
GT7Rgl7Ac78zJlSJPz1m.description:
The Songun Ho 915 is a unique tank designed by the DPRK. Incorporating elements from the T-62, T-72M and T-80BV, it features a 125mm hand-loaded cannon, a KPVT and a coaxial PKT. The Songun Ho features ERA of an unknown type on the hull and turret front.
The  Songun Ho 915 is the first production model from the DPRK to feature a 125mm cannon. Featuring an improved T-72 style engine deck, soft kill APS with LWS and automated smoke systems. Examples have been seen with a single MANPAD, mounted on a stick mount but that is believed to be a parade mounting to show the missile, and that crews carry one for dismounted to protect the tank. The name comes from Songun, which is the "military-first" policy of North Korea, prioritizing the Korean People's Army in the affairs of state and allocation of resources.

recognising_features.songunho915_9z6c34ja3s45v3jgmn09.jpg: The early production model of the Songun-Ho 915 has no turret ERA fitted, the turret is recognisable by it's large size when compared to the T-62 it's based on. The smoke grenade dischargers are on the turret sides, with the stowage rack behind those and a turret extension which sets it apart from it's Soviet ancestry. The huge 14.5mm KPVT commanders HMG is also a recognising feature, with it's AA sight fitted atop. Above the gun is a laser rangefinder, not too dissimilar from the Soviet KTD-1, to the side of that is an IR searchlight.
recognising_features.songunho915_w1ws38ckjunuw9farr8w.jpg: The ERA placement is relatively sparse when compared to Soviet and Chinese tank ERA placement, it would be likely in a time of war to see the tanks with more ERA provided the stocks are there. The ERA has 4 rows on the left side of the gun (right as you look at it) and 3 rows on the right side of the gun, then the turret ceiling has some tile coverage, but the turret sides are bare. The exhaust is on the left side of the hull, as seen here.
recognising_features.songunho915_rwcixqp893dek5zv3qqe.jpg: The side profile of the turret is more reminiscent of the Romanian TR tank series than the T-62 which it derives from, with an extended turret and stowage rack, as for running gear there are 6 equally spaced roadwheels.

cFcyi3wav1HgMUZaAIe0.name: VTT-323
cFcyi3wav1HgMUZaAIe0.description: The 323 is the most common APC within KPA service. It is equipped with dual KPVT's (ZPU-2) in the turret and is capable of elevating its armament to 80 degrees. Derived from the YW-531A Chinese APC, the 323 has a lengthened hull and a turret. They also received a water jet propulsion system derived from that found on the PT-76. The 323 is the basis for many vehicles currently in service with the DPRK.

recognising_features.vtt323_dvhujd8woz8p0qdznir6.jpg: The VTT-323 APC is recognisable thanks to it's unusual rear placed dual armament turret, there are 2 hatches at the front of the vehicle, the one on the right for the commander and the one on the left for the driver, the driver has 3 periscopes.
recognising_features.vtt323_z1nj5079kdoos9a646yu.jpg: There are 5 equally spaced roadwheels, 1 more than on the Chinese YW-531 on which it is based, the exhaust is on the right side of the vehicle.

IyE1z9UT15YXxP396ol9.name: Karrar
IyE1z9UT15YXxP396ol9.description: The Karrar MBT comes from a called off deal for the IRGC to buy T-90S's from Russia in 2015/16, Brigadier General Ahmad Reza Pourdastan in early 2016 said that 'since we can manufacture similar models within the country and we plan to do so in the near future, the deal is now off.' On the 12th of March 2017 the Karrar was unveiled and Tehran said it would enter mass production. The tank also uses a copy of the Russian Nakidka thermal resistant camouflage system. The turret ERA appears similar to Relikt, but it's ballistic properties are unknown.

recognising_features.karrar_s8mkwx3dppx2cbidv3co.jpg: The Karrar is aesthetically very similar to the T-90M, especially from a distance, but on a closer inspection there actually are quite a lot of differences between the two tanks. The hull and turret ERA more closely resembles taller Kontakt-1 blocks instead of Relikt, despite the turret layout more closely resembling the T-90M'S Relikt fitment. The headlights are rectangular LED lights. The gunners sight is more offset to the right and is wider and lower than the PNM-T sight of the T-90M, with what appears to be a 1K13 sight to the left of it (right as you look at it).
recognising_features.karrar_gsry3hfuhew8crt69w7y.jpg: This view from the top shows the differences between the ERA on this and the T-90M, as mentioned it appears more like smaller Kontakt-1 blocks. Another point to note is the cover over the gun which extends to approximately halfway up the barrel.
recognising_features.karrar_vd63gxig8o57dzka3837.jpg: The laser warning system is mounted on a large mast, with a mushroom shaped top.
recognising_features.karrar_wg4xhfatk8nnejr4zxio.jpg: A close up of the Karrar gunners sight, when compared to the T-90M's Sosna-U/PNM-T it is much lower and wider.
recognising_features.karrar_16k64t13itj1fyanbi7q.jpg: A Karrar fitted with a copy of the Nakidka thermal resistant camouflage kit, colours are changed to represent the biomes present in Iran.

ehUm183JccKrWo4cxVFv.name: Mobarez
ehUm183JccKrWo4cxVFv.description: The Mobarez is an Iranian locally upgraded Chieftain, it consists of upgrades to the fire control system, sights, fuel tank, suspension and a much needed powerpack upgrade, given the severe unreliability of the Leyland L60 engine originally fitted to the Chieftain. It is unknown how many Chieftain's have been upgraded to the Mobarez version.

recognising_features.mobarez_sg6iqfmkw148eht2gwtv.jpg: The Mobarez is visually different from the standard Chieftain by looking at the rear section, which has been redesigned to accommodate the new powerpack and fuel cells, the hull is much more raised towards the rear, making it more reminiscent of the Challenger 1. The turret is the same as an early model Chieftain, namely that it doesn't have the cheek added stillbrew armour.

tWe9qyylpt1PesaPj1Yh.name: T-72S
tWe9qyylpt1PesaPj1Yh.description: The T-72S is an export version of the T-72B, it has less Kontakt-1 blocks, a simplified CBRN system and it lacks the Nadboi and Podboi anti-radiation liners that were fitted to the T-72B. Interestingly the Russian Army had some on a parade in Moscow in 1995, despite them being destined for export, so it is unknown if the Russian Army have some in storage, interestingly the Russian and Iranian variants have the DVE-BS crosswind sensor, whereas the Myanmar models do not. Some Iranian examples have been equipped with an unknown electro-optical jammer system, it is unknown how many of their fleet have these fitted.

recognising_features.t72s_syqilk3ij2lykw8eofyi.jpg: The T-72S is very similar to the T-72B, one of the most prominent differentiating features is the double Kontakt-1 row on the hull sides, on the T-72B the hull side is fully covered. Another point for the Iranian and Russian T-72S' is the addition of the DVE-BS crosswind sensor which is the mast behind the gunners hatch.
recognising_features.t72s_os4papjrbcr5gz5x4vj3.jpg: Some Iranian T-72S' are equipped with an unknown electro-optical jammer, consisting of two boxes either side of the main armament.

8IOVsmeJegU4UCi1PVSR.name: Boragh APC
8IOVsmeJegU4UCi1PVSR.description: The Boragh is an Iranian produced APC, it is believed to be a reverse-engineered and upgraded Type-86 which in turn is the Chinese copy of the BMP-1. It is lighter in weight, has stronger armour and can carry more dismounts, it also has been fitted with M113 roadwheels. It features a DShKM turret instead of a typical BMP-1 73mm gun turret.

recognising_features.boraghapc_kjx7pyrause3kis6gzgs.jpg: The Boragh's hull is very similar to the BMP-1, with the main differences being the smaller open-topped turret and the M113 roadwheels instead of the classic BMP 'pork pie' roadwheels.

lxDZ1Z8m1zgbQZxKeI7N.name: Safir-74
lxDZ1Z8m1zgbQZxKeI7N.description: The Safir-74 (also known as the Type-72Z and Al-Zubair 1 in Sudan) is an Iranian modification of Iran's stocks of dated Type-59 and T-54/55's. The 100mm D-10T was replaced with an Iranian produced 105mm based on the Royal Ordnance L7, it therefore is capable of firing NATO 105mm munitions. It also has upgrades consisting of a fire control system, dual-plane gun stabilisation, laser rangefinder, 2nd gen night sights, ERA and a V46-6 engine, which hugely improves mobility.

recognising_features.safir74_pgc9hwotlsongo0f8nge.jpg: The Safir-74 is based on a T-54/55, so it has the typical old school Soviet tank look. It has copies of Kontakt-1 ERA blocks liberally applied across the frontal arc and hull sides, with the turret sides and rear remaining sparse of ERA coverage, as we've seen with other conflicts it would be unsurprising to see crews add more ERA in a time of war, provided they could get hold of it.
recognising_features.safir74_482arergnz0bt78uqnuq.jpg: The gunners sight is much larger than that of the usual T-55, indicating it has an improved night sight capability. A recognition point to note is the top row of ERA, which is raised slightly above the hull sides.
recognising_features.safir74_cmftj68rft674wekgktf.jpg: The tank has 5 roadwheels with a prominent gap between the 1st and 2nd roadwheels, with the rest being equally spaced.
recognising_features.safir74_rcdu20majy92da427zki.jpg: The L7 based gun is obvious due to the fume extractor placement, which is larger towards the top, the T-55's 100mm D-10T fume extractor is at the very end of the main gun.

32upZ3WT5I4md6ay1WrE.name: Tok'chon M1974
32upZ3WT5I4md6ay1WrE.description:
The M1974 Tok'chon, first observed in the city bearing the same name, is the second most numerous SPG in service with the KPA, with over 2000 examples produced. This SPG is armed with a similar 152mm to the Romanian A411. The hull is based on the Soviet ATS-59 chassis.
This vehicle has the drawback of requiring the gun crew to dismount and operate the cannon from the rear of the vehicle due to limited cabin space for maximum efficiency, it can be fired mounted but with a significant reduction in the rate of fire.

recognising_features.tok'chon_h74jygzamuersfv768wi.jpg: The Tok'chon M1974 is based on the ATS-59 chassis, with running gear similar to that of a T-55 with some slight differences, the roadwheels are equally spaced with the final drive at the front. The exhaust is on the right hand side above the tracks and is a long rectangular slit.
recognising_features.tok'chon_ak5q3gq20ppjncwy9zy0.jpg: It is common to see these vehicles with glass viewports for the driver and vehicle commander.
recognising_features.tok'chon_nzs8loevu5ji6vooppje.jpg: The gun is essentially just a A411 (D-20) placed in the back, still with the gun shield fitted.

1W5zJwRNt604CzJjMvEm.name: VTT-323 ZPU-4
1W5zJwRNt604CzJjMvEm.description: The 323 ZPU-4 is a common SPAAG attached to Mechanized infantry battalions in place of the normal towed ZPU-4. It features a set of HT-16PGJ MANPAD's which are operated by an additional crew member outside of the vehicle. In 1985 an up-armoured variant was seen in a parade. Images are lacking for this one, as is expected with many KPA vehicles.

recognising_features.vtt323zpu4_rekrst09vb5u5qk40zgb.jpg: The VTT-323 ZPU-4 remains the same as the VTT-323 APC apart from the turret, which has been replaced by a ZPU-4 quad-barrel cannon.
recognising_features.vtt323zpu4_3wogip58mzl1vrdxxoqi.jpg: Close up of the vehicles main armament.

zwjc6WT84A2ZWyzV6243.name: Mobarez V-84
zwjc6WT84A2ZWyzV6243.description: The Mobarez V-84 is an Iranian locally upgraded Chieftain, of which there are two variants, one with a completely redesigned rear hull and engine compartment. The other which is this one is equipped with a V-84 engine but lacks the heavy modification to the rear, it appears visually the same frontally, with the main recognising features being the exhaust placement and rear hull differences due to the V-84 engine. The V-84 engine is also used in some T-72 variants, namely the T-72A, T-72B and 2S19 Msta-S. Mobarez V-84 is not the official nomenclature, but I have chosen to use in order to help with differentiating between two different vehicles with the same name.

recognising_features.mobarezv84_m93cdlbzzynsbnvgjxzl.jpg: The rear of the Mobarez V-84 is extremely similar to the Chieftain that it is based on, the main one being the lack of the two circular exhausts at the rear, instead moving to a rectangular slit on the left hand side above the tool stowage bin.

jRcT48Nvki9RyEiwORQ2.name: VTT-323 Sonyon
jRcT48Nvki9RyEiwORQ2.description:
The 323 Sonyon is the second most common APC in KPA service. Their role is supplemental to that normally taken up by an IFV in other armies. Their rockets are used in direct fire roles, unlike other similar vehicles also known as Sonyons which are dedicated light MLRS.
It features prominently in DPRK Propaganda, and is commonly used to showcase mechanized infantry units. It features the same water jets found upon the normal 323s. It combines the virtues of a light MLRS and an APC. Its KPVT is capable of significant elevation as part of the KPA doctrine emphasizing all arms air defence.
Its common name, Sonyon means child as the first examples presented in 1979 were done by several children's organizations. Its rocket launcher is a derivation of the Type-63, featuring 18 tubes instead of the normal 12. The mounting on this model is a turn table capable of 360 degrees of traverse, compared to the fixed forward mountings seen on early models. Unlike the later 1997 models it does not carry a reload and needs to rearm its rockets after each engagement.

88VO5p83Ced6Dh7Kos27.name: Tokchon M1991
88VO5p83Ced6Dh7Kos27.description:
The M1991 Tok'chon, first observed in 1991 is the last Tok'chon, armed with a modified M46 130mm incorporating the muzzle break of the SM-4-1 coastal defence gun. It is used as a counter battery piece within the KPA.
It shares the same vices as the earlier Tok'chons, as it's normal operation requires the gun crew to dismount and operate the cannon from the rear. Distinctively this model features a significantly heightened gun shield and two Manpads are carried within the vehicle for self defence. It is worth noting there are a lack of images for this model.

recognising_features.tok'chon_pixtz6o3qskxu5yyykfl.jpg: The M1991 Tok'chon has the typical ATS-59 derived hull of the Tok'chon which has 5 equally spaced roadwheels and a small crew compartment at the front, it has two large stowage boxes in front of the gun shield. The gun has a large muzzle brake, to operate the gun the crew must dismount the vehicle.

5SiJS76BnCtb7KWmJ60t.name: Tokchon M1978
5SiJS76BnCtb7KWmJ60t.description: The M1978 Tok'chon, first observed publicly in 1985 is the first dedicated SPAAG to be manufactured entirely within the DPRK. Featuring a twin 37mm armament it also has a dedicated space at the rear of the turret for a manpad operator to stand and fire one of the several missiles carried within the hull. These are a widespread model of SPAAG within the KPA, seen prominently in several parades, notably in 1985 and 1992 before disappearing from the public eye along with most SPAAGs during the Arduous March, hence the lack of images.  It is limited to daylight operations as it lacks a radar and likely has only marginal capabilities against fixed wing aircraft given its short ranged, slow firing armament, but its twin 37mm autocannons are still significant threats to helicopters, light vehicles and infantry.

recognising_features.tok'chon_ndhobzkvr1b8sk58iowg.jpg: The M1978 is often seen equipped with the driver and commanders glass visors fitted, the chassis is the typical ATS-59 based Tok'chon chassis with 5 equally spaced road wheels and the exhaust centrally on the right hand side.
recognising_features.tok'chon_1x43349hu0frpe2tp33i.jpg: The turret is open topped, aiding with high angles of elevation. There are prominent parts on the upper side which protrude, usually adorned with the KPA roundel.

r9tr8QeViY23l5fl1GCu.name: Tokchon M1983
r9tr8QeViY23l5fl1GCu.description: The M1983 Tok'chon, is armed with a variant of the T-12 100mm cannon, they are used in both AT units or as substitutes for T-68 Medium Tanks in armoured units. Based upon the ATS-59G chassis the Tok'chon 100 is a capable AT unit and within its magazine carries at least 2 Manpads for self defence against aircraft. It has no mounted machine gun and thus lacks some defence against infantry at close range. It possesses similar mobility to the T-55 but handles terrain better due to its lighter weight. Armor protection is unknown but it is believed to be frontally protected from 20mm autocannons and small arms from the sides and rear. Unlike most Tok'chons it does not require the crew to dismount to operate, though it does retain their lack of overhead protection. It can be utilized in indirect fire but is primarily seen in AT units.

recognising_features.tok'chon_41599j8g2mns91r4f91h.jpg: The M1983 is the same as all Tok'chon series vehicles with the regard of the hull, which is a common platform throughout the series with 5 equally spaced road wheels, rear fighting compartment and exhaust on the hull sides. The parts that are different are generally the armament and turret/gun shield, for the M1983 it is clearly identifiable as a direct role engagement platform by the lack of a muzzle brake on the 100mm T-12 gun and also that the guns resting position is level, whereas on most of the artillery vehicles they rest in a raised position.

oxAURrkLf2hvQ3G3NV6Y.name: Tokchon M1981
oxAURrkLf2hvQ3G3NV6Y.description: The M1981 Tok'chon, is armed with a D-74 122 and serves as a companion piece to the 1974 Tok'chon. These pieces primarily serve as counter battery elements but in better equipped Corps they fulfil the role of light artillery. It is the 3rd most common SPG in DPRK service and appears in training footage and propaganda footage frequently. It has a maximum firing range of 24km.
